questions.text: Preoperative assessment of oral cavity for endotracheal intubation in an adult is done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Mallampatti score

  • The Mallampatti score is a classification system used to assess the visibility of the structures in the oral cavity and predict the ease of intubation.
  • It grades visibility of the soft palate, uvula, and tonsillar pillars, ranging from Class I (full visibility) to Class IV (no visibility). Higher scores indicate more difficult intubation.

Incorrect Options

Option B: Cormack-Lehane

  • The Cormack-Lehane classification is used to assess the view of the vocal cords during laryngoscopy, not specifically the oral cavity.

Option C:ASA grading

  • The ASA grading system assesses a patient's physical status before surgery but doesn't specifically evaluate the oral cavity for intubation.

Option D:AHA grading

  • There is no commonly known anesthesia grading system called AHA grading.

questions.text: Which of the following Anaesthesia agent is hepatotoxic:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Halothane:

  • Halothane is a volatile inhalation anesthetic that has been associated with hepatotoxicity in some patients.
  • It can cause a rare but severe adverse reaction called halothane hepatitis, which can lead to liver damage or failure.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are not hepatotoxic.

questions.text: Anaesthesia given to dog:
questions.solution:
Correct option: D

  • The correct answer is D: All of the above. Ketamine, medetomidine hydrochloride, and midazolam are all commonly used anesthetic agents in veterinary medicine, including for dogs. Each of these drugs has specific properties and uses in anesthesia for different purposes and stages of anesthesia.

Incorrect options: 

  • None of the choices are incorrect since all of them can be used as anesthesia agents in dogs.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for hypotensive anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Both 1 and 2:

  • Hypotensive anesthesia involves deliberate lowering of blood pressure during surgery to reduce bleeding and improve surgical field visibility.
  • Isoflurane is an inhalation anesthetic that can be used to achieve controlled hypotension.
  • Nitroglycerin, a vasodilator, can also be administered to lower blood pressure during surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option D - Dantrolene: Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant used for the treatment of malignant hyperthermia, a rare but life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic agents, not specifically for achieving hypotensive anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest acting local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chloroprocaine:

  • Chloroprocaine is a local anesthetic with a short duration of action.
  • It is often used for short procedures and is suitable for regional anesthesia techniques where a rapid onset and short duration of anesthesia are desired.
  • Longest to shortest acting local anesthetics: Dibucaine (Longest) > Tetracaine > Bupivacaine > Lignocaine > Procaine > Chloroprocaine (Shortest)

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the most effective approach for verifying the accuracy of intubation during laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Capnography:

  • Capnography is the optimal method for confirming correct intubation during laryngoscopy. It measures exhaled carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration, providing immediate confirmation of proper tube placement in the trachea.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Air entry on auscultation: While auscultation for air entry is a common method for confirming tube placement, it may not be as reliable as capnography.

Option C - Ultrasonography: Ultrasonography can be used to visualize the structures of the airway, but it is not typically used to confirm tube placement during laryngoscopy.

Option D - Chest movement: Chest movement alone is not a reliable indicator of correct intubation and may not provide definitive confirmation.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Impetigo

 

Explanation:

 

The lesion shown in the image has the following classic features:

  • Location: Perioral (around the mouth)

  • Appearance: Reddish base with overlying golden-yellow or honey-coloured crusts

  • Surface: Crusted, shallow erosions without deep ulceration or scarring

  • Distribution: Localised, possibly multiple lesions

  • No systemic symptoms: Usually mild or absent fever

These clinical features are hallmark signs of impetigo, especially the non-bullous type.

  • Impetigo is a highly contagious superficial bacterial skin infection, most common in children.

  • Causative organisms:

    • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)

    • Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A strep)

 

Chickenpox (Option B): 

  • It presents with a generalised vesicular rash on an erythematous base ("dew drop on a rose petal") in different stages of healing.

  • Typically starts on the trunk, not just around the mouth.

Herpes Simplex (Option C): 

  • It shows painful grouped vesicles, later forming ulcers or crusts.

  • Lesions recur and are often associated with burning or tingling sensations.

  • HSV lesions are clear vesicles, not honey-coloured crusts.

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option D):

  • It presents as small, dome-shaped, pearly papules with central umbilication.

  • Lesions are not crusted or erosive, and there is no honey-coloured appearance.

questions.text: What are these lines called?
questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • The lines shown in the image are called Blaschko lines. Blaschko lines represent the patterns of embryonic cell migration and proliferation during the development of the skin. These lines are not visible under normal circumstances but become apparent in certain conditions, such as genetic mosaicism or certain skin disorders.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Lymphatic development: Lymphatic development refers to the formation and maturation of the lymphatic system, which is responsible for maintaining fluid balance and immune function. It does not directly relate to the horizontal lines seen in the image.

Option B: Dermatomes: Dermatomes are specific areas of the skin that are innervated by sensory nerves from a single spinal nerve root. They represent the sensory distribution of the spinal nerves and are not related to the horizontal lines seen in the image.

Option D: Vascular development: Vascular development refers to the formation and maturation of blood vessels during embryonic development. While blood vessels are present in the skin and may follow certain patterns, they are not directly associated with the specific horizontal lines shown in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is absent in individuals with congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Genital ulcers:

  • Genital ulcers are not typically seen in congenital syphilis.
  • Congenital syphilis refers to the transmission of syphilis from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy. It can lead to various manifestations in the newborn.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Higoumenakis sign: Enlargement of the sternal end of the clavicle as a sign of late congenital syphilis

Option B - Hutchinson teeth: Hutchinson teeth are notched, peg-shaped teeth with a characteristic screwdriver-like appearance.

Option D - Buneo's Triad: Buneo's Triad, also known as Wimberger's triad, consists of interstitial keratitis (inflammation of the cornea), eighth nerve deafness, and Hutchinson teeth. It is a classic presentation of congenital syphilis.

questions.text: What is the treatment used for vitiligo among the options listed below?
questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • Vitiligo is a skin condition characterized by the loss of pigmentation in certain areas, resulting in white patches on the skin. Various treatment modalities are available for vitiligo, and the choice depends on factors such as the extent of the condition and patient preferences. Psoralen PUVA (Psoralen plus Ultraviolet A) therapy is a commonly used treatment option. Psoralen is a medication that sensitizes the skin to UVA light, and PUVA involves the combination of psoralen ingestion or topical application followed by exposure to UVA light. This treatment helps stimulate repigmentation of the white patches in vitiligo.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Retinoids are a class of medications derived from vitamin A and are used in various dermatological conditions but are not a primary treatment for vitiligo.

Option B: Systemic steroids may be used in some cases of vitiligo, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

Option D: Nd-YAG laser is a type of laser used in dermatology for various purposes but is not the primary treatment for vitiligo.

questions.text: Tzancksmear as shown in the image shows:
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • A Tzanck smear is a diagnostic test in dermatology that involves scraping the base of a skin lesion and examining the cells under a microscope. It helps in the diagnosis of various blistering disorders and viral infections. The given image shows Acantholytic cells, which are characterized by the loss of cell-to-cell adhesion, are typically seen in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune disorder.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Acanthosis refers to the thickening of the epidermis, which can be seen in conditions such as psoriasis or acanthosis nigricans.

Option C: Smudge cells are abnormal lymphocytes seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

Option D: Anaplasia refers to the loss of cellular differentiation and organization, typically seen in malignant tumors.

questions.text: Gastric lavage, commonly known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is a procedure performed to remove the contents of the stomach. It has been widely used since the early 19th century as a standard method to eliminate toxins from the stomach. This procedure is typically employed for individuals who have consumed poison or overdosed on substances like ethanol. Additionally, it may be performed prior to surgery to empty the digestive tract. In which of the following situations is gastric lavage not recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Hydrocarbon poisoning

  • Gastric lavage, also commonly called stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is the process of cleaning out the contents of the stomach.
  • It is typically used in cases of poisoning or drug overdose. However, there are certain conditions in which gastric lavage is contraindicated. In this case, gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning (Option B).
  • Hydrocarbons, such as gasoline, kerosene, or petroleum-based solvents, have a low viscosity and can easily aspirate into the lungs during gastric lavage, leading to serious complications like chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia.
  • Therefore, gastric lavage should not be performed in cases of hydrocarbon ingestion.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Organo-Phosphate poisoning (Option A): Gastric lavage is indicated in cases of organophosphate poisoning to remove the toxin from the stomach.

Option C: Ethanol poisoning (Option C):  Gastric lavage is indicated in cases of Ethanol poisoning to remove the toxin from the stomach.

Option D: PCM toxicity (Option D): PCM toxicity refers to poisoning with paracetamol (acetaminophen). Gastric lavage is indicated in cases of paracetamol overdose within 4 hours of ingestion.

questions.text: Which confirmatory test is utilized by forensic experts to establish the presence of a bloodstain at a crime scene?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Spectroscopic test:

  • When it comes to identifying a bloodstain, the confirmatory test used is a spectroscopic test (Option A). Spectroscopic tests, such as infrared spectroscopy or UV-visible spectroscopy, analyze the absorption or emission of light by the sample to identify specific compounds or substances present in the bloodstain

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Kastle Meyer test: The Kastle Meyer test is a presumptive test It is not a confirmatory test.

Option C - Benzidine test: The benzidine test is another presumptive test for detecting blood It is not a confirmatory test.

Option D - Orthotoluidine test: The orthotoluidine test is a colorimetric test used to detect the presence of blood. It is also a presumptive test and not a confirmatory test.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was rescued from a village in Bihar where she had been sold off by her father for Rs. 25000 to a 45-year-old man. On examination, she was found to be 12 weeks pregnant. She was granted permission to abort the pregnancy, taking into consideration the age of the girl and the circumstances of her pregnancy. A doctor who will be eligible to perform the abortion for this girl should have performed at least how many MTP prior to this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 25: 

  • According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in India, a doctor must have performed at least 25 MTPs (Option C) to be eligible to perform the abortion for this girl. This criterion ensures that the doctor has sufficient experience and expertise in performing safe and legal abortions.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D - 10, 15 & 35: These options do not meet the requirement of having performed at least 25 MTPs as per the law.

questions.text: From the dense vegetation near the highway, the police have found the remains of a burnt body. The location was discovered with the help of a sniffer dog, as they were tracing a 25-year-old IT worker who had gone missing the night before. To determine the identity of the victim, the team needs to gather a suitable sample. Which type of tissue from a charred body is most effective for identification purposes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Teeth:

  •  The best tissue for identification purposes is the teeth (Option C)

  • Teeth are highly durable and resistant to heat, making them more likely to survive the burning process compared to other tissues.

  • Dental records, including dental charts, X-rays, and dental impressions, can be used to compare with the teeth recovered from the burnt body to establish a positive identification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hair: While hair can provide some information for identification, it is more susceptible to damage by fire and may not be as reliable as teeth.

Option B - Bone:  Bone can also provide information for identification, but it may be severely damaged or fragmented in cases of extensive burning.

Option D - Blood: Blood is not a suitable tissue for identification purposes in a burnt body, as it would likely be destroyed during the burning process.

questions.text: Death registration in India done within?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 21 days:

  • In India, death registration is required to be done within 21 days (Option A) of the occurrence of the death. The Registrar of Births and Deaths, usually located at the local municipality or panchayat, is responsible for recording deaths and issuing death certificates.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D: These options do not correspond to the prescribed time frame for death registration in India, which is 21 days.

questions.text: The most reliable criteria among Gustafson's criteria for age estimation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Translucency of root:

  • Teeth play a crucial role in the identification of individuals, especially in forensic odontology. Gustafson's technique, developed by Gustafson in 1950, is a widely used method for age estimation in adults based on dental characteristics.

  • Among Gustafson's criteria, the most reliable criterion for age estimation is the translucency of the root (Option C).

  • The technique involves attributing scores for various age-related changes observed in teeth, such as attrition, periodontal ligament retractions, secondary dentin formations, root translucency, and root resorption.

  • The translucency of the root is considered one of the most reliable indicators of age, as it gradually increases with age due to the deposition of secondary dentin and changes in the root structure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D - Root resorption, Paradentosis & Attrition:

  • While these criteria are also considered in Gustafson's technique, the translucency of the root is considered the most reliable indicator of age estimation among Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text: A patient came in with an unidentified fungal infection. Upon microscopic examination, spherical fungi with brown coloration and septate hyphae were observed.  Possible condition can be inferred from the presence of brown colored bodies on tissue biopsy.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chromoblastomycosis:

  • Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of brown-colored spherical fungi with septate hyphae. Tissue biopsy often reveals brown-colored bodies called sclerotic bodies, which are diagnostic of chromoblastomycosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum and presents with intracellular yeast forms.

Option C - Coccidioidomycosis: Coccidioidomycosis is caused by Coccidioides species and presents with spherules containing endospores.

Option D - Candida Albicans: Candida albicans is a yeast-like fungus that causes candidiasis, and its microscopic appearance differs from the description given.

questions.text: Bacillus Anthrax is:

choices.text: Gram positive rods with square ends

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gram-positive rods with square ends:

  • Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium responsible for anthrax, is a Gram-positive bacterium that appears as rods under a microscope. These rods have square or boxy ends arranged in a chain, giving a bamboo stick or box car appearance.

Incorrect Options:
Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Corona virus is incorrect?

choices.text: Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike
Human corona virus 229 E is alpha type

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Icosahedral Capsid:

  • Coronavirus has a Helical capsid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ssRNA genome: Coronavirus is a single-stranded RNA virus. All RNA viruses have ssRNA genomes except Reoviridae (dsRNA)

Option C - Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike: Spreads primarily through respiratory droplets and aerosols. Host cell entry occurs by attachment of viral spike protein to angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 receptor on cell membranes.

Option D - Human coronavirus 229E is an alpha-type: Human coronavirus 229E is indeed classified as an alpha-type coronavirus.

questions.text: DNA transfer in bacteria via phage is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Transduction:

  • DNA transfer in bacteria mediated by phages (bacteriophages) is called transduction. During transduction, a bacteriophage infects a bacterial cell and incorporates bacterial DNA into its phage particles. When these phage particles infect other bacteria, they deliver the bacterial DNA, resulting in the transfer of genetic material between bacteria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conjugation: It refers to the direct transfer of genetic material between bacteria through physical contact.

Option C - Transformation: It refers to the uptake of free DNA from the environment by bacteria.

Option D - Translation: Translation is the process by which the genetic information encoded in mRNA is used to synthesize proteins. It does not involve the transfer of DNA between bacteria.

questions.text: Sporulation occurs in this phase of bacterial growth curve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stationary Phase:

Bacterial Growth Curve:

  • It has 4 phases

 

Lag Phase

Log Phase

Stationary Phase

Dead Phase
  • No increase in the number of bacteria
  • Cell adaptation
  • Increase in size, enzymes and metabolite
  • The maximum size of bacteria is seen in end of the lag phase
  • Cell division
  • Smaller in size
  • Maximum metabolic activity
  • More susceptible to antibiotics
  • Some bacteria remain viable and some are dead
  • Bacterial growth ceases due to depletion of nutrients
  • Mnemonic STAB (STAT from stationary)
    • S in sporulation
    • T in Exo Toxin production
    • A in antibiotic production
    • B in Bacteriocin production
  • Antibiotic production happens in this phase
  • Decline phase
  • Cell death or involution

Incorrect Options:
Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is accompanied by his wife to the Neurology OPD. His wife expressed concern about her husband's condition and they were directed to this facility by a local doctor. According to the doctor's note, the patient is unable to repeat spoken words, but can comprehend them and respond appropriately by nodding. The patient also experiences difficulty in naming people and writing. The doctor referred the patient to a specialized facility for a CT brain scan. As the intern on duty, you would inform the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) that this condition could be indicative of a brain lesion in which specific area?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Arcuate fasciculus

Difficulty in repeating spoken words, trouble with naming and writing, yet intact comprehension of spoken language, suggests Conduction Aphasia. It's caused by a disconnection between language centers in the brain, possibly affecting the Arcuate Fasciculus. This white matter tract links Broca's area (speech production) with Wernicke's area (language comprehension). Damage here can lead to symptoms like those described in conduction aphasia, where patients struggle to repeat words or phrases accurately despite understanding them.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Anterior commissure: The anterior commissure is involved in the connection between the two cerebral hemispheres but is not typically associated with the specific language symptoms described.

Option C - Corpus callosum:  Damage to the corpus callosum can result in a variety of symptoms but is not specifically associated with the language deficits described.

Option D - Fornix: The fornix is a white matter structure involved in memory processes but is not typically associated with the language symptoms described.

questions.text: What are common causes of granuloma formation?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • A) Mycobacterial infections: This is correct. Mycobacterial infections, such as tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, are well-known for inducing granulomatous inflammation.

Incorrect options

Option B) Viral infections: This is generally incorrect. Viral infections are not typically associated with granuloma formation. Granulomas are more commonly seen in response to certain bacterial and fungal infections.

Option C: Actinomycosis:Can cause granuloma formation but it is not the most common cause.

Option D) Allergic reactions: This is generally incorrect. While allergic reactions can cause inflammation, they do not typically lead to the formation of granulomas. Granulomas are more commonly associated with chronic infections and certain non-infectious conditions.

questions.text: HUS in children is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - E. coli 0157:

  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a condition characterized by the combination of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. HUS can have several causes, but the most common and well-known association is with infection by the bacterium Escherichia coli (E. coli) serotype O157:H7 and shigella.
  • E. coli O157:H7 is a strain of E. coli that produces toxins called Shiga toxins. These toxins can cause damage to the lining of blood vessels, leading to red blood cell destruction, platelet clumping, and kidney injury, which are characteristic features of HUS.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted by infected mosquitoes. It is characterized by fever, and severe cases of cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum can be seen. It is not typically associated with HUS.

Option C - Parvovirus B19: Parvovirus B19 is a viral infection that primarily affects children and can cause a condition called erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).

Option D - Bartonella henselae: It is a bacterium that causes cat scratch disease, a usually benign infection characterized by swollen lymph nodes and fever. Bartonella infections can have various manifestations, including neurologic and cardiac complications, they are not typically associated with HUS.

questions.text: Which pathway provides afferent fibers to the mammillary body, a structure located beneath the brain's surface?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fornix:

  • The fornix is a bundle of nerve fibers that plays a crucial role in the limbic system, including its connection with the mammillary body. The mammillary bodies receive afferent fibers via the fornix, which connects the hippocampus (a critical component of the limbic system) to the mammillary bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Corpus callosum: The corpus callosum connects the brain's two hemispheres but isn't directly involved in the afferent pathways to the mammillary body.

Option B - Thalamus: While the thalamus is interconnected with the mammillary body through neural circuits, it does not directly send afferent fibers to the mammillary body.

Option C - Pituitary gland: Although pituitary gland has connections with the hypothalamus, it does not send afferent fibers to the mammillary body.

questions.text: Deficiency of which complement system increases the risk of N. meningitidis infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - C5-C9 deficiency:

  • Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that can cause meningococcal meningitis. The complement system plays an important role in the immune response against N. meningitidis.
  • Deficiency of the complement components C5-C9, also known as the membrane attack complex (MAC), impairs the ability of the immune system to form the MAC and lyse bacterial cells and increases the susceptibility to infections caused by this bacterium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C1-C4 deficiency: Deficiencies in C1-C4 components of the complement system are associated with an increased susceptibility to immune complex-mediated diseases like systemic lupus eryhtematosus,and glomerulonephritis.

Option C - C3 deficiency: C3 deficiency is associated with an increased susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic infections.

Option D - C2 deficiency: C2 deficiency is associated with an increased risk of systemic lupus erythematosus and immune complex diseases.

questions.text: At what level does the duct of the parotid gland, a paired salivary gland producing serous secretions, open?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Second maxillary molar: The duct of the parotid gland, Stensen's duct, opens into the mouth at the level of the second maxillary molar. This is the appropriate location where saliva from the parotid gland is released into the oral cavity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - First mandibular molar: Stensen's duct, from the parotid gland, opens opposite the second upper molar, not the first mandibular molar.

Option B - Second mandibular molar: Stensen's duct, from the parotid gland, opens opposite the second upper molar, not the second mandibular molar.

Option C - First maxillary premolar: The first maxillary premolar is located more towards the front of the mouth, while the duct of the parotid gland opens at a different location.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options triggers the classical complement cascade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ag - Ab complex:

  • The first step is the binding of C 1 to the antigen-antibody complex.
  • The recognition unit of C1 is C1q, which reacts with the Fc piece of bound IgM or IgG.
  • C1q has six combining sites. Effective activation occurs only when C 1 q is attached to immunoglobulins by at least two of its binding sites.
  • One molecule of IgM or two molecules of IgG can, therefore, initiate the process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C1: C1 is the first component of the classical complement pathway and is activated by binding to antigen-antibody complexes.

Option B - C3 convertase: C3 convertase is an enzyme complex formed during the activation of the complement system but does not specifically activate the classical pathway.

Option C - IgA: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is an antibody isotype involved in mucosal immunity and is not directly involved in activating the classical complement pathway.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for causing trismus due to spasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Medial pterygoid:

  • The medial pterygoid muscle aids in jaw closure and raising the mandible during chewing. If it spasms or becomes hypertonic, it can lead to trismus, which is difficulty fully opening the mouth. The buccinator muscle, responsible for cheek movement and actions like blowing and sucking, doesn't directly cause trismus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Buccinator: The buccinator muscle compresses the cheek during chewing and paralysis causes food buildup in the mouth's vestibule and hinders cheek puffing. It doesn't cause trismus.

Option B - Lateral pterygoid: The lateral pterygoid muscle helps in opening the mouth and moving the jaw sideways. Dysfunction or spasm of this muscle can contribute to TMJ disorders but isn't the main cause of trismus.

Option D - Mentalis: The mentalis muscle, located in the chin, helps with pouting and chin wrinkling but isn't involved in jaw movement. Therefore, issues with this muscle don't cause trismus.

questions.text: Which of the following virus is from Herpes virus family?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - EBV:

  • EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) EBV, also known as Human herpesvirus 4 (HHV-4), is a member of the Herpesviridae family. It is associated with infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever) and is also linked to several other diseases, including certain cancers, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Other members of Herpesviridae are

Type

Virus

Associated Diseases

HHV1

Herpes Simplex Virus 1

Oral herpes (cold sores), genital herpes, and encephalitis.

HHV2

Herpes Simplex Virus 2

Genital herpes.

HHV3

Herpes Zoster Virus

Chickenpox and shingles.

HHV4

Epstein–Barr virus

Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

HHV5

Cytomegalovirus (largest member)

Congenital infections, mononucleosis, organ transplant complications.

HHV6

Human Herpesvirus 6

Roseola infantum, febrile illness

HHV7

Human Herpesvirus 7

Febrile illness and a few cases of roseola infantum

HHV8

Human Herpesvirus 8

Kaposi's sarcoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rubella: Rubella is caused by the Rubella virus, which belongs to the Togaviridae family, not the Herpesviridae family.

Option B - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, is caused by the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family.

Option C - Rabies: Rabies is caused by the Rabies virus, which belongs to the Rhabdoviridae family.

questions.text: Which division of the facial nerve innervates the muscles located in the lower lip?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mandibular

  • Mandibular: The mandibular branch of the facial nerve, also known as the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower lip. This includes the depressor labii inferioris, mentalis, and other muscles involved in lower lip movement and expression

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Temporal: The temporal branch of the facial nerve supplies the muscles of the forehead and scalp. It is not involved in supplying the muscles of the lower lip.

Option B - Cervical: The cervical branch of the facial nerve supplies the platysma muscle. It is not responsible for innervating the muscles of the lower lip

Option C - Buccal: The buccal branch of the facial nerve supplies the muscles of the cheek. It does not directly innervate the muscles of the lower lip.

questions.text: Mark the false statement regarding testing of covid 19:

choices.text: Most predominant method of diagnosis of Covid 19 is RT-PCR
First line screening assay: N gene assay
Peripheral ground glass opacities on CT are frequently observed.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - First Line Screening Assay: N Gene Assay:

  • The first-line screening assay for COVID-19 is typically the RdRp gene assay, not the N gene assay.
  • The RdRp gene is commonly targeted in molecular diagnostic tests for SARS-CoV-2 due to its high specificity and sensitivity in detecting the virus.

  • N (nucleocapsid) gene assay is used in many COVID-19 diagnostic tests and is a crucial component of the testing process. However, it's often used as a confirmatory or secondary assay rather than the primary screening assay.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Most Predominant Method of Diagnosis of COVID-19 is RT-PCR: Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) is indeed the most common method for diagnosing COVID-19. RT-PCR is highly sensitive and specific for detecting viral RNA, allowing for accurate diagnosis even at low viral loads

Option C - Confirmatory Assay: RdRp gene assay: The RdRp gene assay is used as a confirmatory test in COVID-19 diagnosis.

Option D - Peripheral ground glass opacities on CT are frequently observed.​​​  Ground glass opacities on CT scan are commonly seen in COVID-19, although they are not exclusive to this infection.

questions.text: Neurocysticercosis is caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cysticercus Cellulose:

  • Neurocysticercosis is caused by the larva of Taenia solium called cysticercus cellulosae.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cysticercus Bovis: It is the larval stage of Taenia saginata responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

Option B - Taenia Saginata Asiatica: Taenia saginata asiatica is another species of tapeworm that resembles Taenia saginata, and cysticerci are located in liver.

Option D - Taenia Saginata: Taenia saginata is responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes to the outpatient department complaining of fever, cough, muscle pain and headache. On taking occupational history, she reveals working for a centrally airconditioned corporate company. The doctor sent a sputum sample for culture sensitivity. The microbiologist used buffered charcoal yeast extract to culture the suspected organism. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Legionnaire Disease:

  • The symptoms and occupational history described are consistent with Legionnaire's disease, caused by the bacterium Legionella pneumophila. The use of buffered charcoal yeast extract medium is specific for culturing Legionella species.
  • Legionella inhabits aquatic bodies, which could be either:
    • Natural water sources, such as rivers, streams, or even inside amoeba
    • Artificial aquatic sources, such as air conditioners, water coolers, shower heads, large plumbing systems, and decorative fountains.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brucellosis: Brucellosis is caused by Brucella species and is typically associated with exposure to infected animals or their products.

Option C - Pneumonia caused by Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae is a common causative organism of meningitis, pneumonia, croup, and suppurative lesions and requires Factor X and V for growth.

Option D - Acute gastroenteritis: Acute gastroenteritis is characterized by fever, nausea, vomiting or diarrhea.

questions.text: When should you perform Widal test in a case of typhoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2nd week:

  • The Widal test is a serological test used for the diagnosis of typhoid fever caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi. It detects antibodies in the patient's blood against specific antigens of the Salmonella typhi bacteria.
  • Performing the Widal test in the 2nd week of illness is considered the most appropriate timing for obtaining reliable and accurate results. During the 2nd week of typhoid fever, the patient's immune response has had sufficient time to produce detectable levels of antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens.
  • Tests performed for the diagnosis of typhoid during the course of infection.

Week of Infection

Test performed

Week 1

Blood culture

Week 2

Antibody test (Widal)

Week 3

Stool culture

Week 4

Urine culture

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an example.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation gets an ultrasound done for fetal well-being and is diagnosed with hydrops fetalis. Which of the following fetal infections could have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

  • Hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in fetal tissues and body cavities, resulting in significant swelling. It can be caused by various factors, including fetal infections. In this case, the infection most commonly associated with hydrops fetalis is Parvovirus B19 (Ans. C). Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe anemia in the fetus, causing congestive heart failure and subsequent hydrops fetalis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Epstein-Barr virus (Ans. A): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is primarily associated with infectious mononucleosis and is not a common cause of hydrops fetalis.

Option B: Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Ans. B): HPV is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause genital warts and increase the risk of cervical cancer but is not typically associated with hydrops fetalis.

Option D: Influenza virus (Ans. D): Influenza virus infection during pregnancy can cause maternal complications and increase the risk of preterm labor, but it is not a common cause of hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient visits the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of a mass descending through the vaginal opening. Upon examination, it is determined to be a second-degree uterovaginal prolapse. The patient does not have any chronic illnesses and does not smoke or consume alcohol. She has previously undergone two vaginal deliveries, one 8 years ago and the other 10 years ago with Episiotomy. The doctor proceeds to gather a detailed obstetric history pertaining to these two deliveries. Which of the following factors in the patient's history is unlikely to have contributed to her current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Episiotomy

  • The correct option that would not lead to the present condition (uterovaginal prolapse) is Episiotomy.
  • However, an episiotomy is not directly associated with uterovaginal prolapse. It is more commonly linked to issues like perineal pain, wound infection, and discomfort during sexual intercourse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Precipitate labor: Precipitate labor refers to an extremely fast labor and delivery process, often lasting less than 3 hours from the onset of contractions to the birth of the baby. This rapid delivery can put significant stress on the pelvic floor muscles and tissues, potentially contributing to uterovaginal prolapse.

Option B: Prolonged second stage: The second stage of labor is the phase from full cervical dilation to the birth of the baby. If this stage is prolonged, it means the woman has been pushing for an extended period. Prolonged pushing can strain the pelvic floor and supporting structures, increasing the risk of uterovaginal prolapse.

Option C: Premature bearing down: Premature bearing down refers to the urge to push before the cervix is fully dilated. Pushing too early can lead to excessive pressure on the pelvic structures and may contribute to the development of uterovaginal prolapse.

questions.text: What is the conservative approach used to treat pelvic organ prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct option C-What is the conservative approach used to treat pelvic organ prolapse?:

  • Conservative management options for pelvic organ prolapse include the use of a pessary . A pessary is a removable device that is inserted into the vagina to provide support to the prolapsed organs and alleviate symptoms. It is a non-surgical approach that can be effective in managing mild to moderate cases of pelvic organ prolapse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Perineorrhaphy: Perineorrhaphy is a surgical procedure that involves repairing and strengthening the perineal tissues but is not a conservative treatment for pelvic organ prolapse.

Option B:Shirodkar Procedure: The Shirodkar procedure is a surgical technique used for cervical cerclage during pregnancy and is not a conservative treatment for pelvic organ prolapse.

Option D: Le Fort Repair: Le Fort repair refers to surgical techniques used for the treatment of urinary incontinence and is not a conservative treatment for pelvic organ prolapse.

questions.text: Cut off point for 50 gram glucose challenge test at 1 hour mg%?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The 50-gram glucose challenge test is performed during pregnancy to screen for gestational diabetes. The test involves measuring the blood glucose level 1 hour after the ingestion of a 50-gram glucose solution. The cut-off point for a positive result is a blood glucose level equal to or greater than 140 mg% (Ans. B). If the result is positive, further testing with a glucose tolerance test (GTT) is usually recommended for confirmation.

Incorrect options:

Option A: 100: A blood glucose level of 100 mg% is not the cut-off point for the 50-gram glucose challenge test.

Option C: 180: A blood glucose level of 180 mg% is not the cut-off point for the 50-gram glucose challenge test.

Option D: 200: A blood glucose level of 200 mg% is not the cut-off point for the 50-gram glucose challenge test.

questions.text: 28 year old lady (G2 P1) who does not want to conceive after abortion, which is the preferred mode of contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-IUD:

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs) are considered one of the most effective forms of reversible contraception. They are a preferred mode of contraception for women who do not wish to conceive after an abortion. IUDs are long-acting, reversible contraceptives that are inserted into the uterus by a healthcare provider. They provide reliable contraception for an extended period, and their effectiveness is not dependent on user compliance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: OCP (Oral contraceptive pills): Although oral contraceptive pills are a commonly used form of contraception, they require regular daily intake and may not be the preferred choice for individuals who do not wish to conceive after an abortion.

Option C: Barrier methods: Barrier methods such as condoms or diaphragms provide contraception by physically blocking the sperm from reaching the egg. While they offer some level of protection, they are less effective than long-acting reversible methods like IUDs.

Option D: Implant: Implants are small, flexible rods inserted under the skin that release hormones to prevent pregnancy. While they are highly effective, they may not be the preferred choice for individuals who do not wish to conceive after an abortion.

questions.text: A 30 year old primigravida female delivers a full term baby. However she choses to formula feed her newborn. After how much duration can she start using combined oral contraceptives for avoiding a pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • After delivery, it is generally recommended to wait for a certain duration before starting combined oral contraceptives (COCs) to avoid the risk of thromboembolic events. In the case of a woman who chooses to formula feed her newborn, she can start using COCs for contraception after 6 weeks postpartum (Ans. B). This waiting period allows the body to recover from childbirth and reduces the risk of complications associated with COC use.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: 2 weeks: Starting COCs just 2 weeks after delivery may increase the risk of thromboembolic events, and therefore, it is not the recommended duration to initiate COC use.

Option C: 12 weeks: Waiting for 12 weeks postpartum is not necessary for a woman who is formula feeding her newborn. Six weeks is a sufficient waiting period in such cases.

Option D: Immediately after delivery: COCs should not be initiated immediately after delivery due to the increased risk of thromboembolic events. A waiting period is advisable before starting COCs.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient visits the doctor with concerns about her irregular menstrual periods and experiencing bleeding after sexual intercourse for the past 2 months. The patient comes from a low socio-economic background and has 4 children. She uses an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for birth control. Additionally, the patient has a long history of smoking and has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 5 years. The patient's vital signs are stable, and the physical examination does not reveal any significant findings. Further investigations indicate a positive test for type 16 human papillomavirus (HPV) and a biopsy confirms the presence of cervical cancer in its early stage. Which of the following factors from her medical history does not contribute to her current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-Hypertension and IUCD use:

  • The factors in this patient's history that are associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer are chronic smoking (smoking is a well-established risk factor for cervical cancer) and the presence of high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 infection.
  • However, hypertension and the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) do not predispose her to cervical cancer (Ans. B). Hypertension and IUCD use are not known risk factors for the development of cervical cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: HPV 16, smoking: Both high-risk HPV 16 infection and smoking are well-established risk factors for cervical cancer.

Option C: Multiparity and low socio-economic status: Multiparity (having multiple pregnancies) and low socio-economic status are associated with a higher risk of developing cervical cancer.

Option D: Multiparity and smoking: Multiparity and smoking are both known risk factors for cervical cancer.

questions.text: The calculation of the EDD (Expected Date of Delivery) is determined by?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The expected date of delivery (EDD) is calculated based on Naegele's formula, which is a commonly used method. According to Naegele's formula, the EDD is calculated by adding 280 days (40 weeks) to the first day of the woman's last menstrual period (LMP) and adjusting for the length of the menstrual cycle (usually assumed to be 28 days). Naegele's formula takes into account the average length of pregnancy, which is approximately 40 weeks from the LMP.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Young's rule: Young's rule is a method used for calculating pediatric drug dosages based on the child's age and weight. It is not relevant to calculating the expected date of delivery.

Option C: Cardiff Formula: There is no established "Cardiff Formula" for calculating the expected date of delivery.

Option D: Hadlock Formula: The Hadlock Formula is used for fetal biometric measurements and estimating gestational age during prenatal ultrasound examinations. It is not used for calculating the expected date of delivery.

questions.text: Which type of twinning is observed if a zygote undergoes division within 3 days of fertilization?
questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • When a zygote divides into two separate embryos 2-3 days after fertilization, it results in diamniotic, dichorionic twins. In this type of twinning, each embryo has its own amniotic sac (diamniotic) and placenta (dichorionic). The division occurs early enough for the embryos to develop their own individual structures.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Monochorionic, Monoamniotic: Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins result from the division of a zygote after the formation of the amniotic sac but before the development of the chorion. These twins share both the same amniotic sac and placenta.

Option B: Monochorionic, Diamniotic: Monochorionic, diamniotic twins occur when a zygote divides after the formation of both the amniotic sac and chorion. These twins share the same placenta but have separate amniotic sacs.

Option D: Dichorionic, Monoamniotic: Dichorionic, monoamniotic twins involve the splitting of a zygote after the formation of the chorion but before the development of the amniotic sac. These twins share the same placenta but have a single amniotic sac.

questions.text: What is the chromosomal pattern in complete mole?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C-46 XX both paternal origin:

  • A complete mole, also known as a complete hydatidiform mole, is an abnormal pregnancy characterized by the absence of a fetus and the presence of abnormal trophoblastic tissue. In a complete mole, the genetic material is entirely paternal, meaning both sets of chromosomes (XX or XY) are derived from the father. The maternal chromosomes are absent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 46 XY both maternal origin: This option is incorrect because a complete mole is characterized by a complete absence of maternal genetic material.

Option B: 46 XX both maternal origin: This option is incorrect because a complete mole is characterized by a complete absence of maternal genetic material.

Option D: 46 YY both paternal origin: This option is incorrect because the presence of YY chromosomes is not possible in humans.

questions.text: In the case of failed medical management, which part of the fallopian tube is most likely to experience the earliest rupture of an ectopic sac?
questions.solution:
In the case of an ectopic pregnancy, the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation. If medical management fails, the ectopic pregnancy may continue to grow, potentially leading to a rupture of the fallopian tube.

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrowest part of the fallopian tube, located adjacent to the uterus. Typically, tubal ectopic pregnancies in the isthmus rupture within the first few weeks of gestation, with the ampulla being slightly more expandable . Other implantation sites, including the cornua and abdomen, allow for further gestational development due to increased space and ability to distend

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Interstitial: This option is incorrect

Option C. Ampulla: The ampulla is the most common site of ectopic pregnancies. Rupture of an ectopic pregnancy in the ampulla can cause significant abdominal pain and bleeding. It is a common site for tubal ectopic pregnancies.

Option D. Infundibulum: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped distal end of the fallopian tube, close to the ovary. Ectopic pregnancies in this location are less common. Rupture in the infundibulum can also cause abdominal pain and internal bleeding.

questions.text: In a patient who is a 32-year-old female, experiencing her first pregnancy at full term, and has a previously diagnosed fibroid uterus, an elective cesarean section is being planned due to the baby being in a breech presentation. The patient expresses her desire to have the fibroid removed during the surgery. However, she has been informed about the potential drawbacks of undergoing myomectomy. Which of the following conditions is a reason to consider removing the fibroid in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A-Pedunculated subserosal:

  • In this scenario, the patient has a known history of the fibroid uterus and desires its removal during the cesarean section. However, in certain cases, myomectomy may not be recommended. One such indication for removal is a pedunculated subserosal fibroid. Pedunculated fibroids have a stalk-like structure that allows them to protrude from the uterus.
  • A pedunculated subserosal fibroid located on the outer surface of the uterus is more accessible for removal during the cesarean section, and its removal can prevent potential complications such as torsion or obstruction during future pregnancies.

Incorrect options:

Option B: In the broad ligament: Fibroids in this location can be challenging to access and remove during surgery, and their removal may increase the risk of bleeding and damage to nearby structures.

Option C: Posterior in location: The location of the fibroid, whether anterior (front) or posterior (back) in the uterus, does not necessarily determine the need for removal during a cesarean section.

Option D: Small in size: Small fibroids that are not causing symptoms or complications do not typically require removal during a cesarean section.

questions.text: After 28 weeks of POG what is the  primary source of amniotic fluid secretion ?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • "Fetal urine.": During the later stages of pregnancy, particularly after 28 weeks of gestation, the primary source of amniotic fluid is fetal urine. The developing fetus continuously produces urine as a byproduct of its metabolic processes. The urine is then excreted into the amniotic sac, contributing to the volume of amniotic fluid.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Fetal skin: Fetal skin does contribute to the production of amniotic fluid, but it is not the major source. Fetal skin secretes a substance called vernix caseosa, which, along with other fetal skin cells and glandular secretions, contributes to the composition of amniotic fluid. However, the amount of fluid generated from fetal skin is relatively small compared to fetal urine.

Option C: Placental cell membrane: The placental cell membrane, also known as the amnion, plays a crucial role in enclosing the amniotic sac and protecting the fetus. While it does contribute to the overall volume of amniotic fluid, it is not the major source of fluid secretion. The amnion primarily acts as a barrier between the fetal and maternal circulation, rather than actively secreting fluid.

Option D: Plasma: Plasma refers to the fluid component of blood. While maternal blood does contribute to the composition of amniotic fluid through passive exchange across the placenta, it is not a significant source of fluid secretion compared to fetal urine.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent infections is frequently associated with infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Chlamydia:

  • Chlamydia infection is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. If left untreated, chlamydia can lead to various complications, including pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which can cause scarring and damage to the reproductive organs. This scarring can lead to infertility in both men and women.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. While it can cause symptoms such as vaginal discharge and discomfort, it is not commonly associated with infertility.

Option C: Candidiasis: Candidiasis, commonly known as a yeast infection, is caused by the overgrowth of the fungus Candida. It typically affects the vagina but does not usually lead to infertility.

Option D: Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is an imbalance of the normal vaginal flora, characterized by an overgrowth of certain bacteria. While it can cause symptoms and discomfort, it is not commonly associated with infertility.

questions.text: What initial tests should be recommended to this couple, a 29-year-old woman who has been unable to conceive for 3 years, and her husband, who have been married for 4 years, live together, and are sexually active without using contraception? The woman's menstrual cycle occurs at regular 28-day intervals, and her husband is a professional cyclist.

choices.text: Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test
Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test

questions.solution:
Correct option: B

  • In the evaluation of infertility, initial tests should focus on assessing factors that could contribute to the difficulty in conceiving. In this case, the couple has been trying to conceive for 3 years without success. The initial tests that should be advised are:
  1. Semen analysis: It assesses factors such as sperm count, motility, and morphology, which are important for successful fertilization.
  2. Tubal patency test: This test assesses the patency (openness) of the woman's fallopian tubes. Ovulation test: This test helps determine if the woman is ovulating regularly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Semen analysis, CXR, Mantoux test (Ans. A): A chest X-ray (CXR) and Mantoux test are not relevant in the initial evaluation of infertility.

Option C: Ovulation, tubal patency, Mantoux test (Ans. C): The Mantoux test is used for diagnosing tuberculosis and is not necessary in the initial evaluation of infertility.

Option D: Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test (Ans. D): Testicular biopsy and sperm penetration test are more specialized tests that are typically reserved for specific situations or after initial evaluations have been conducted.

questions.text: A G4P2 female presented with history of two abortions at 16 weeks and 20 weeks POG. Which of the following could be the most likely reason for these abortions?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Recurrent mid-trimester abortions (abortions occurring between 14 and 24 weeks of gestation) can be caused by various factors. One of the common causes is cervical incompetence, also known as cervical insufficiency. Cervical incompetence refers to the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy, leading to repeated second-trimester pregnancy losses.
  • In cervical incompetence, the cervix is structurally weak or lacks the normal ability to remain closed during pregnancy. As a result, the cervix may start to efface (thin out) and dilate prematurely, leading to the loss of the pregnancy. Cervical incompetence is often associated with painless cervical dilation and bulging of the amniotic sac through the cervix.
  • Other causes of mid-trimester abortions, such as chromosomal abnormalities, placenta previa, or thyroid abnormalities, can also contribute to pregnancy losses, but given the history provided, cervical incompetence is the most likely reason in this scenario.
  • Cervical incompetence, also known as an incompetent cervix or cervical insufficiency, is a condition where the cervix begins to dilate and efface prematurely during pregnancy, often leading to late miscarriages or preterm births.
  • In women with cervical incompetence, the cervix is unable to support the weight of the growing pregnancy, resulting in painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss, typically occurring in the second trimester.
  • Cervical incompetence is a likely cause for recurrent mid-trimester miscarriages in this scenario.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Chromosomal abnormality: Chromosomal abnormalities can be a cause of pregnancy loss, but they are not specific to mid-trimester abortions.

Cervical incompetence, also known as an incompetent cervix or cervical insufficiency, is a condition where the cervix begins to dilate and efface prematurely during pregnancy, often leading to late miscarriages or preterm births. In women with cervical incompetence, the cervix is unable to support the weight of the growing pregnancy, resulting in painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss, typically occurring in the second trimester. Cervical incompetence is a likely cause for recurrent mid-trimester miscarriages in this scenario.

Option C: Placenta previa: Placenta previa, a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, is associated with third-trimester bleeding but not necessarily mid-trimester abortions.

Placenta previa, a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, can lead to bleeding during the later stages of pregnancy. While placenta previa can cause complications, such as bleeding and preterm delivery, it is not the most probable cause for the described recurrent miscarriages.

Option D: Thyroid abnormality: Thyroid abnormalities can contribute to pregnancy complications, but they are not commonly associated with mid-trimester abortions.

Thyroid disorders, particularly uncontrolled hypothyroidism, can contribute to infertility and pregnancy complications. However, in the context of recurrent mid-trimester miscarriages, cervical incompetence is a more likely cause compared to thyroid abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about endometriosis?

choices.text: Presence of endometrial gland in deep myometrium
Presence of endometrium at ectopic locations

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Endometriosis is a condition characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus. The endometrial tissue can implant and grow in various ectopic locations, such as the ovaries, fallopian tubes, pelvic peritoneum, and other sites within the pelvis and abdomen. This ectopic endometrial tissue responds to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle, leading to inflammation, scarring, and pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Presence of endometrial gland in deep myometrium: This statement is not true. In endometriosis, the endometrial tissue is primarily found outside the uterus, in areas such as the pelvic cavity or other ectopic sites, rather than within the deep myometrium (muscular layer of the uterus).

Option C: Treated preferably with hysterectomy: Hysterectomy (removal of the uterus) is not the first-line treatment for endometriosis. The initial approach involves medical management, including pain management and hormonal therapies. Hysterectomy may be considered in severe cases or when other treatments have failed, but it is not the preferred treatment option.

Option D: Seen in multiparous women: Endometriosis can occur in women regardless of their parity (number of pregnancies). It is not limited to multiparous women (women who have had multiple pregnancies).

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of infertility in a 29-year-old female who has a history of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • The most probable cause of infertility in a 29-year-old female with a history of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia is Endometriosis.

 

Incorrect Options:
 

Option A. Adenomyomatosis: The misplaced tissue in adenomyosis does not usually interfere significantly with fertility.

Option C. Myomas (Uterine Fibroids): The impact on fertility depends on the size, location, and number of fibroids. Small fibroids that do not distort the uterine cavity are unlikely to cause infertility issues.

Option D. Cervicitis: In most cases, cervicitis can be treated effectively with antibiotics and does not necessarily lead to infertility.

questions.text: A 32 year old pregnant woman presents with 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of pain abdomen and decreased fetal movements. On examination PR: 96/min, BP = 156/100 mm Hg, FHR = 128 bpm. On per-vagina examination there is altered blood seen and cervix is soft 1 cm dilated. What is the preferred management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C. Immediate LSCS

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may be experiencing placental abruption or another obstetric emergency, which requires immediate delivery to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus. Given her high blood pressure (which could indicate preeclampsia) and decreased fetal movements, immediate surgical intervention (LSCS - Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is the safest option.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Tocolytics

  • Explanation: Tocolytics are used to delay preterm labor, which is not appropriate here since the patient is already at 36 weeks and shows signs of potential placental abruption or another obstetric emergency.

Option B. Induce labour

  • Explanation: Inducing labor could be risky due to the altered blood seen on examination, indicating potential placental abruption. Immediate LSCS is safer to manage the condition.

Option D. Wait and watch

  • Explanation: Given the high blood pressure, abdominal pain, and decreased fetal movements, waiting could endanger both the mother and the fetus. Immediate action is required to prevent further complications.

questions.text: What is the most probable reason for a 30-year-old woman visiting a clinician due to abundant facial hair and hair growth on her upper back, arms, and thighs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-PCOS:

  • Excessive growth of facial hair in women, known as hirsutism, is commonly associated with hormonal imbalances. One of the most likely causes in this scenario is PCOS.
  • Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome is a common endocrine disorder characterized by hormonal imbalances, including elevated levels of androgens (male hormones). These elevated androgen levels can lead to hirsutism and other symptoms such as irregular periods, acne, and ovarian cysts.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Drug-induced: Certain medications can cause hirsutism as a side effect, but in the absence of medication history, PCOS is a more likely cause.

Option C: Endometriosis: Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus. While it can cause pelvic pain and other symptoms, it is not typically associated with hirsutism.

Option D: Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis is a condition where the endometrial tissue grows into the muscular wall of the uterus. It primarily causes heavy or painful periods but is not associated with excessive facial hair growth.

questions.text: What is the correct statement about the condition of a 52-year-old woman who visits a physician complaining of experiencing warm spells followed by excessive sweating, and has not had menstrual periods for the past 3 years?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D

  • The symptoms described by the patient, including hot flashes (warm spells) and profuse sweating, along with the cessation of periods for 3 years, are indicative of menopause. During menopause, there is a decline in ovarian function and hormone production.
  • The correct hormonal changes associated with menopause are increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and decreased estrogen levels. As the ovaries produce less estrogen, the negative feedback on the anterior pituitary is reduced, leading to increased FSH secretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 9 weeks of amenorrhea with a positive pregnancy test. She complains of nausea and vomiting which gets better by evening. The doctor advices her folic acid and dietary modifications to help with her vomiting. He explains that the cause of such presentation is a hormone. The source of this hormone is?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • The symptoms described by the patient, including nausea and vomiting that improve by evening, are characteristic of morning sickness (nausea and vomiting of pregnancy). The hormone responsible for causing morning sickness is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is primarily produced by the syncytiotrophoblast (a layer of the placenta).
  • During early pregnancy, hCG levels rise rapidly, peaking around 9-12 weeks of gestation. The exact mechanism by which hCG causes nausea and vomiting is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve interactions with the gastrointestinal system and hormonal pathways.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Yolk sac: The yolk sac plays a role in early embryonic development and nutrient transfer but is not the source of the hormone responsible for causing nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

Option B: Fetal liver: The fetal liver is involved in various metabolic functions but is not the source of the hormone responsible for morning sickness.

Option D: Umbilical cord: The umbilical cord connects the fetus to the placenta and facilitates nutrient and oxygen transfer but is not the source of the hormone causing nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

questions.text: True about pterygium:

choices.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea:

  • A pterygium is a fibrovascular sub-epithelial ingrowth of degenrative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • It appears as a triangular-shaped tissue with blood vessels and can cause discomfort, redness, and visual disturbances. It is characterized by the invasion of conjunctival tissue over the cornea, forming a flap-like structure.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Pterygium is a sub epithelial of conjunctiva on the cornea like a flap.

questions.text: For laser iridotomy which laser is used?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Laser iridotomy is a surgical procedure that involves creating a small hole in the iris to relieve intraocular pressure caused by conditions such as narrow-angle glaucoma. Nd YAG (neodymium-doped yttrium aluminum garnet) laser is commonly used for this procedure due to its ability to create precise and controlled openings in the iris.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Argon laser is primarily used for retinal photocoagulation and not for iridotomy.

Option C: Excimer laser is mainly used for refractive surgeries such as LASIK.

Option D: CO2 laser is not commonly used for iridotomy.

questions.text: In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the point of opening of the lacrimal sac is into:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Middle meatus:

  • Dacryocystorhinostomy is a surgical procedure used when there's an obstruction beyond the medial opening of the common canaliculus. This procedure involves connecting the lacrimal sac to the mucosa of the middle nasal meatus.
  • To perform this procedure, a vertical incision is made in the skin, 10 mm medial to the inner canthus. Then, the medial canthal tendon and lacrimal sac are exposed and reflected. The intervening bone is removed, and the sac is incised. Finally, the sac is attached to an opening created in the nasal mucosa.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A newborn is hypermetropic by
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Hypermetropia refers to a refractive error where the eye has difficulty focusing on near objects. In newborns, a certain degree of hypermetropia is considered normal. A refractive error of +2.5 D to 3.0 D is within the expected range for a hypermetropic newborn.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the origin of corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neural crest cells:

  • The corneal endothelium is derived from neural crest cells during embryonic development. It plays a crucial role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating the fluid balance in the cornea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neuroectoderm: Secondary vitreous, tertiary vitreous, optic nerve, retina, smooth muscles of the iris (iris sphincter and dilator pupillae), and epithelium lining of iris and ciliary body are derived from neuroectoderm.

Option C - Mesoderm: Primary vitreous, temporal part of sclera, extra ocular parts, and endothelial lining of the blood vessels are derived from mesoderm.

Option D - Surface ectoderm: The skin of eyelids and appendages, lens, lacrimal gland, epithelium of the cornea, and epithelium of conjunctiva are derived from surface ectoderm.

questions.text: What is true regarding retinoscopy using a plane mirror?

choices.text: In hypermetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction
In myopia the red glow moves in same direction
In emmetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction
Done at 1 meter away from patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Done at 1 meter away from patient:

  • Retinoscopy is a technique used to determine an individual's refractive error by analyzing the movement of light reflected from the retina. When performing retinoscopy with a plane mirror, the observer typically maintains a working distance of approximately 1 meter from the patient.
  • Procedure:
    • The examiner holds the retinoscope about 1 meter away from the patient.
    • The examiner shines the light beam into the patient's eye while moving the retinoscope back and forth, horizontally and vertically.
    • The reflected light forms a reflex that the examiner observes.
    • Depending on the movement of reflex with respect to the light it can be interpreted as:
      • With the movement: Patient is emmetropic/hypermetropic/myopia <1.
      • A movement against the light: Myopia <1.
      • No movement: Myopia -1

Incorrect options: 

Options: A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Rosette cataract is seen after?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Blunt trauma to eye:

  • Rosette-shaped cataract a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex, also known as traumatic cataract, is a type of cataract that occurs as a result of blunt trauma to the eye. The impact from the trauma can cause disruption and damage to the lens, leading to the formation of a characteristic rosette-like pattern in the lens fibers.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Copper foreign body in eye:  It can lead to Sunflower cataract.

Option C - Penetrating injury to the eye: A penetrating injury can result in sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Option D - Infection: Infections of the eye, such as endophthalmitis, can lead to severe inflammation and damage to various eye structures, including the lens.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding a patient who has a history of falling on a symmetrical surface and presents with enophthalmos, diplopia on upward gaze, and loss of sensitivity over the cheek?

choices.text: It is a blow out fracture
Zygomatic bone is most likely injured

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is a blow out fracture:

  • The patient's symptoms, including enophthalmos (sunken eye), diplopia on upward gaze, and loss of sensitivity over the cheek, are consistent with a blowout fracture.
  • A blowout fracture refers to a fracture of the orbital floor or medial wall caused by trauma. It can result in displacement of orbital contents and lead to various symptoms like periocular ecchymosis, enophthalmos, diplopia, and loss of sensation over the cheek because of the involvement of the infraorbital nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. described symptoms are not associated with these fractures.

questions.text: Blow out fracture can be due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tennis ball injury:

  • Blow-out orbital fractures occur due to trauma to the orbit, which is often caused by a large and rounded object like a tennis ball, cricket ball, human fist, or part of an automobile.
  • The force of the blow causes the eyeball to be displaced backwards and increases intraorbital pressure. This results in a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall, which is typically the orbital floor but can also be the medial wall.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which eye condition is commonly associated with sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the eyes. Anterior uveitis, characterized by inflammation of the anterior chamber of the eye, is a common ocular manifestation of sarcoidosis.
  • Other Ocular Features of Sarcoidosis.
    • Sarcoid nodules on the sclera or episclera
    • Interstitial keratitis
    • Band-shaped keratopathy because of hypercalcemia.
    • Candle wax dripping: Segmental or nodular periphlebitis.
    • Lander's sign: Pre-retinal nodules.
    • Heerfordt syndrome: Sarcoidosis with uveo-parotitis.
    • Lofgren syndrome: Sarcoidosis with anterior uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These ocular features are not associated with sarcoidosis.

questions.text: To confirm the diagnosis, what additional investigation should be conducted for a child exhibiting symptoms of night blindness and delayed dark adaptation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ERG:

  • Night blindness and delayed dark adaptation are characteristic features of a condition called congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB). To confirm the diagnosis of CSNB, further investigation with electroretinography (ERG) is necessary.
  • ERG measures the electrical responses generated by the retina in response to light stimuli and can help assess the functioning of retinal cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptometry is a test that measures the time it takes for the eyes to adapt to darkness and regain visual sensitivity.

Option C - EOG (Electrooculography): EOG is a test that measures the electrical responses generated by the muscles surrounding the eye. It is primarily used to assess the functioning of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Option D -: Retinoscopy: Retinoscopy is a technique used to assess refractive errors of the eye and does not directly evaluate night blindness or dark adaptation.

questions.text: Blount Disease results from the  involvement of
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Proximal Tibia:

  • Blount Disease, also known as tibia vara, is a growth disorder that primarily affects the proximal tibia
  • Main symptoms include noticeable leg bowing, leg pain, walking difficulty, and an abnormal gait.
  • Diagnosis involves physical examination and imaging tests like X-rays.
  • Treatment depends on age, severity, and complications, with options ranging from bracing and physical therapy to surgery for severe cases.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Distal Tibia: Blount Disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal tibia.

Option C - Proximal Femur: Blount Disease does not involve the proximal femur.

Option D - Distal Femur: Blount Disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal femur.

questions.text: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteoarthritis:

  • Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease that commonly affects the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints of the hands. It typically spares the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the wrist. The characteristic involvement of DIP and PIP joints with sparing of MCP and wrist joints is a typical feature of osteoarthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis typically involves multiple joints, including MCP and wrist joints, and may result in deformities.

Option C - Psoriasis: Psoriatic arthritis can involve DIP, PIP, and MCP joints, along with skin and nail changes.
