Option D - Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism does not specifically affect DIP, PIP, MCP, or wrist joints.

questions.text: What is the medical condition of a tennis player who is able to repeatedly and independently reduce a shoulder dislocation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B

  • Recurrent shoulder dislocation refers to the repeated episodes of shoulder dislocation, where the shoulder joint pops out of its normal position. Some individuals, particularly those involved in sports like tennis, may develop a condition known as voluntary or habitual dislocation. They can voluntarily and easily reduce the dislocated shoulder on their own. This ability to self-reduce the dislocation repeatedly is characteristic of recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Acute shoulder dislocation: Acute shoulder dislocation refers to the initial episode of shoulder dislocation, which requires manual reduction.

Option C: Inferior shoulder dislocation: Inferior shoulder dislocation (luxatio erecta) is a rare type of shoulder dislocation where the arm is stuck in an elevated position.

Option D. Fracture upper end humerus: Fracture of the upper end of the humerus is a different condition involving a break in the bone.

questions.text: A 35 year old man when presented with a gradual progressive swelling , was diagnosed with  Adamantinoma. Which of the following bone  is typically affected by this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tibia:

  • Adamantinoma is a rare primary bone tumor that typically affects the tibia (shinbone). It arises from the epithelial tissue within the bone. Adamantinoma is most commonly seen in the diaphysis (shaft) of the tibia, but it can also occur in other long bones.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Adamantinoma most commonly presents in young to middle-aged adults, typically between the ages of 20 and 40.
  • The most common site of involvement is the tibia, particularly the diaphysis (shaft) region.
  • Patients often present with localized pain, swelling, and a palpable mass in the affected bone.
  • Rarely, pathological fractures can occur.

Histopathology:

  • Adamantinoma is characterized by the presence of biphasic cellular components: epithelial-like cells and fibrous or osteofibrous stroma.
  • The epithelial-like cells form glandular or tubular structures resembling the enamel organ of developing teeth.
  • The stroma is composed of fibrous tissue with varying degrees of osteoid or bone formation.
  • Microscopic examination and immunohistochemistry are used to confirm the diagnosis.

Radiological Findings:

  • On X-ray, Adamantinoma typically presents as a lytic lesion within the affected bone, often with associated cortical thinning or expansion.
  • The lesion may exhibit a "soap-bubble" appearance due to areas of bone destruction and reactive bone formation.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can provide detailed information about the extent of the tumor and its relationship to surrounding structures.

Treatment:

  • Surgical resection is the mainstay of treatment for Adamantinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radius: Adamantinoma primarily affects the tibia, not the radius.

Option B - Humerus: Adamantinoma primarily affects the tibia, not the humerus.

Option C - Femur: Adamantinoma primarily affects the tibia, not the femur.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She was a non-restrained passenger in a car. She has pain in her neck and difficulty in neck movements. She has no associated neurological deficits. A neck collar is applied to protect the spinal cord. An X-ray of the neck is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hangman Fracture:

  • The X-ray image shows a fracture through the pedicles of C2 vertebra, which is known as a Hangman fracture. It is typically caused by severe hyperextension and distraction forces, commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents. Hangman fractures are unstable injuries that involve the C2 vertebra and can lead to significant spinal instability.

Treatment:

  • The treatment of Hangman fractures depends on the type and stability of the fracture, as well as the presence of associated injuries.
  • Stable fractures (Type I) are usually managed non-surgically with a rigid cervical collar or halo vest immobilization for a specific duration.
  • Unstable fractures (Type II and III) may require surgical intervention to achieve realignment and stabilization of the C2 vertebra. Surgical options include anterior cervical fusion, posterior fixation, or a combination of both.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Jefferson's Fracture: Jefferson's fracture is a fracture of the ring of C1 vertebra (atlas) caused by axial loading forces. It is characterized by fractures through the anterior and posterior arches of C1.

Option C - Clay Shoveler Fracture: Clay shoveler fracture is a fracture of the spinous process of a lower cervical vertebra, usually C6 or C7.

Option D - SCIWORA (Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality): SCIWORA refers to spinal cord injuries with no evident abnormalities on X-ray or imaging studies.

questions.text: Albers Schonberg disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Osteopetrosis:

  • Albers-Schonberg disease, also known as osteopetrosis, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density due to impaired bone resorption. It results in thickened, brittle bones that are prone to fractures. Osteogenesis imperfecta, often known as brittle bone disease, is a separate condition characterized by bone fragility and susceptibility to fractures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paget's Disease: Paget's disease of bone is a condition characterized by excessive and disorganized bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and weakened bones.

Option B - Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density and increased risk of fractures.

Option C - Osteogenesis Imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that easily fracture.

questions.text: A 25 year old Volleyball player presents to your OPD with injury to thumb ,along with pain, swelling, and tenderness at the base of thumb. On examination the thumb is in the position of abduction. Which of the following is the diagnosis of the presenting condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Game Keepers Thumb:

  • Gamekeeper's thumb, also known as skier's thumb, is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the thumb. It typically occurs due to a forceful abduction of the thumb, such as during a fall or sports-related injury. Gamekeeper's thumb can lead to instability and laxity of the thumb joint, affecting grip strength and causing pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bowler's Thumb: Bowler's thumb, also known as thumb pad swelling or bowler's thumb callus, is a localized thickening and callus formation on the thumb pad of professional bowlers.

Option C - Kaplan Injury: Kaplan injury is not a recognized medical condition or injury.

Option D - Mallet Finger: Mallet finger refers to the deformity caused by the disruption or avulsion of the extensor tendon insertion at the base of the distal phalanx, leading to the inability to extend the distal joint of the finger.

questions.text: Identify the following fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Monteggia Fracture:

  • The given image is of Monteggia Fracture.
  • It is Fracture of the ulna (usually the proximal or middle third). - Dislocation of the radial head.
  • Monteggia Fracture is a type of forearm fracture involving a fracture of the proximal or middle third of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Colles Fracture : This option is incorrect

Option C - Barton's Fracture: This option is incorrect

Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect

questions.text: A 79 yrs old lady had  a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis. Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemiarthroplasty:

  • The X-ray shows a fracture of the neck of the femur (hip fracture). In older patients, especially those over 65 years, surgical management with hemiarthroplasty (partial hip replacement) is often the preferred treatment for displaced femoral neck fractures.
  • Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the fractured head of the femur with a prosthetic implant while leaving the acetabulum intact. This procedure helps to restore hip function, relieve pain, and allow early mobilization.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hip Spica: Hip spica is a type of cast or brace used to immobilize the hip and surrounding areas. However, it is not the treatment of choice for a femoral neck fracture, especially in older patients. Immobilization alone does not provide adequate stability and may result in complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores.

Option C - Total Hip Replacement: Total hip replacement is not typically performed for femoral neck fractures, especially in older patients.

Option D - Nailing: Nailing may be a treatment option for certain types of femoral fractures but is not the preferred treatment for femoral neck fractures.

questions.text: A child presents to the orthopedic OPD with a limp and limb shortening. His X-ray is given below, What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - DDH:

  • The X-ray shows a dislocated hip joint with hip dysplasia and apparent limb shortening.
  • Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH), also known as congenital hip dysplasia or hip dislocation, refers to abnormal development of the hip joint, leading to instability, subluxation, or dislocation of the femoral head from the acetabulum. It commonly presents with a limp and limb length discrepancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Perthes: Perthes disease (Legg-Calve-Perthes disease) is a condition characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head, leading to deformity and hip joint dysfunction.

Option B - SCFE (Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis): SCFE is a condition where the femoral head slips off the femoral neck, causing hip pain and limping.

Option D - Fracture Neck of Femur: A fracture of the neck of the femur typically presents with localized pain, inability to bear weight, and external rotation of the affected limb.

questions.text: Ectopia lentis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -Homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis refers to the abnormal displacement or dislocation of the lens of the eye. It can occur as a result of various underlying conditions. Among the given options condition associated with ectopia lentis is homocystinuria.
  • Other diseases associated with ectopia lentis are:
    • Marfan syndrome.
    • Weill Marchesani syndrome.
    • Ehler’s Danlos syndrome.
    • Hyperlysinemia.
    • Sulphite oxidase deficiency.
    • Stickler syndrome.
       

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Refsum's disease: Refsum's disease, also known as heredopathia atactica polyneuritiformis, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of phytanic acid in the body. It primarily affects the nervous system and other organs but is not associated with ectopia lentis.

Option C - Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease is an inherited disorder that leads to abnormal copper metabolism in the body, resulting in copper accumulation in various organs, particularly the liver and brain. It manifest as Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea.

Option D - Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the eyes. Ocular manifestations inlude band-shaped keratopathy, and uveitis.

questions.text: The most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy, which is shown below, is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kimmelstiel Wilson Nodules:

  • The most characteristic feature of diabetic nephropathy shown in the histopathological image is Kimmelstiel Wilson nodules.
  • These are pathognomonic lesions seen in the kidneys of patients with diabetic nephropathy.
  • They are characterized by the presence of nodular mesangial expansion, thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, and hyaline deposits.
  • These changes are indicative of advanced diabetic nephropathy and are associated with the development of proteinuria and progressive renal dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is found in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: A

  • Stellate granuloma is a histopathological finding characterized by central necrosis surrounded by histiocytes, giant cells, and lymphocytes arranged in a stellate or star-shaped pattern. It is commonly associated with cat scratch disease, which is caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae. In cat scratch disease, stellate granulomas can be found in the affected lymph nodes, indicating the immune response to the infection.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Leprosy: Stellate granulomas are not a characteristic finding in leprosy. Leprosy is associated with granulomatous inflammation but presents with different histopathological features.

Option C: Coccidiomycosis: Coccidiomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides species and is not typically associated with stellate granulomas.

Option D: Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum and does not typically present with stellate granulomas.

questions.text: Xenograft is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Graft across species:

  • Xenograft refers to a type of graft or transplantation that involves transferring tissues or organs from one species to another.
Graft types Description Examples
Autograft Transfer of tissue from one site to another in the same individual Skin grafts from one site to another on the same individual
Allograft Transfer of tissue between genetically non-identical individuals of the same species Kidney transplant from a living or deceased donor
Isograft Transfer of tissue between genetically identical individuals (e.g., identical twins) Organ transplant between monozygotic twins
Xenograft Transfer of tissue between different species Pig heart valve transplant in a human

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most abundant glycoprotein in basement membranes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Laminin:

  • Laminin is the most abundant glycoprotein found in basement membranes.
  • It is a large protein complex composed of three different polypeptide chains (α, β, and γ) that form a cross-shaped structure.
  • Laminin plays a crucial role in the structure and function of basement membranes, including cell adhesion, migration, and signalling.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fibronectin:

  • Fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in the extracellular matrix and is not the most abundant glycoprotein in basement membranes.

Option C - Integrin:

  • Integrins are cell surface receptors that mediate cell adhesion to the extracellular matrix but are not glycoproteins themselves.

Option D - Syndecan:

  • Syndecan is a transmembrane heparan sulfate proteoglycan and is not the most abundant glycoprotein in basement membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Loss of differentiation:

  • Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation of cells.
  • It is a characteristic feature of malignant tumors and is associated with the loss of normal tissue organization and cellular features.
  • Anaplastic cells often exhibit pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and increased mitotic activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Loss of cohesion between cells: Loss of cohesion between cells is a characteristic feature of malignancy.

Option C - Change of epithelium type: Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation.

Option D - Benign and fully reversible: Anaplasia is typically seen in malignant tumors and is not fully reversible.

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is not seen 12 hours after an ischemic injury to the heart?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyper-eosinophilia of myocytes:

  • Hyper-eosinophilia invasion of myocytes is observed 1-3 days after injury.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are observed within 12 hours of ischemic injury.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the type of cell in the body that has the ability to give rise to the highest number of other cells?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A

  • Totipotent cells are capable of differentiating into all cell types, including the cells of the embryo and the extraembryonic tissues. They have the ability to form all cell lineages, both embryonic and extraembryonic. Totipotent cells are found in the early stages of embryonic development, up to the 4-cell stage. They have the highest developmental potential and can give rise to a complete organism.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Multipotent: Multipotent cells are capable of differentiating into multiple, but not all, cell types. They can give rise to cells of a closely related cell lineage or tissue type.

Option C: Pluripotent: Pluripotent cells can differentiate into cells of all three germ layers (endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm) but cannot form the extraembryonic tissues.

Option D: Lineage stem cells: This term is not commonly used in the context of cell potency. It may refer to stem cells that are capable of differentiating into specific lineages but not all cell types.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - G6PD Deficiency:

  • G6PD deficiency is characterized by impaired function of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase.
  • It follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hurler Syndrome:

  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase.

Option B - Thalassemia:

  • Thalassemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

Option C - Hereditary Spherocytosis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by abnormalities in red blood cell shape and function.

questions.text: With which pattern of disease inheritance is consanguinity associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autosomal Recessive:

  • Consanguinity refers to a close blood relationship between the parents.
  • Autosomal recessive diseases are more likely to occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples.
  • This is because the parents may both carry a single copy of a recessive gene mutation, and when they have children together, there is an increased chance of both parents passing on the mutated gene, resulting in the expression of the disease phenotype in the offspring.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Autosomal Dominant:

  • Autosomal dominant diseases can occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are not specifically associated with consanguinity.
  • Autosomal dominant diseases can also arise from de novo mutations or occur in non-consanguineous families.

Option C - X-Linked Recessive:

  • X-linked recessive diseases are inherited through the X chromosome.
  • Although consanguinity can increase the likelihood of inheriting X-linked recessive diseases, it is not the characteristic pattern associated with consanguinity.

Option D - X-Linked Dominant:

  • X-linked dominant diseases can also occur in the offspring of consanguineous couples, but they are less common and not specifically associated with consanguinity.

questions.text: In the context of Goodpasture syndrome, which organ is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of autoantibodies directed against the basement membrane of the kidneys and lungs. It primarily affects the kidneys and lungs, but renal involvement is more prominent. The autoantibodies target the type IV collagen in the glomerular basement membrane, leading to inflammation, damage, and ultimately, kidney dysfunction.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Liver: Goodpasture syndrome does not primarily involve the liver. The main organs affected are the kidneys and lungs.

Option B: Adrenals: Adrenal involvement is not a characteristic feature of Goodpasture syndrome. The adrenal glands are not typically targeted by the autoimmune response in this disorder.

Option D:. Brain: Goodpasture syndrome primarily affects the kidneys and lungs and does not involve the brain.

questions.text: What is the mechanism for healing in the case of a 57-year-old male with a gradually developing swelling over the scalp region, pus discharge, and pain?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • In this case, the mechanism for healing is granulation tissue formation. Granulation tissue is a type of connective tissue that forms during the healing process of a wound. It is composed of new blood vessels (angiogenesis), fibroblasts, and an extracellular matrix. Granulation tissue fills the wound defect and helps in the formation of new tissue. It appears as red, soft, and granular tissue on the wound surface.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Granuloma formation: Granuloma formation is a type of chronic inflammation characterized by the aggregation of immune cells, typically macrophages, in response to persistent or resistant antigens. It is not the primary mechanism involved in the healing of the described wound.

Option B: Scab formation: Scab formation occurs during the initial stages of wound healing when blood components, such as fibrin and platelets, dry and form a protective crust over the wound. It is not the primary mechanism involved in the healing process after incision and drainage of an infected scalp swelling.

Option D: Neovascularization: Neovascularization refers to the formation of new blood vessels. It is an important step in wound healing, but in the context of the described case, granulation tissue formation is a more relevant mechanism for healing.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male active smoker with a known case of bronchial asthma now presents with difficulty breathing, with the breath sounds being audible externally. Which of the following is not a feature you will expect to find in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in number of airway goblet cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fibroblastic foci:

  • Fibroblastic foci are not a characteristic feature of bronchial asthma.
  • Fibroblastic foci are commonly seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a distinct disease characterized by progressive lung scarring and fibrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thickening of bronchial wall:

  • In bronchial asthma, chronic inflammation of the airways leads to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of smooth muscle cells, along with edema and infiltration of inflammatory cells.
  • This contributes to the thickening of the bronchial wall.

Option B - Increase in the number of airway goblet cells:

  • Goblet cells produce and secrete mucus in the respiratory tract.
  • In asthma, there is an increase in goblet cell hyperplasia, leading to excessive mucus production and airway obstruction.

Option D - Sub-basement membrane fibrosis:

  • Chronic inflammation in asthma can lead to remodelling of the airway wall, including thickening of the sub-basement membrane due to the deposition of collagen and other extracellular matrix components.
  • This contributes to airway narrowing.

questions.text: Which of the following is a type-2 hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia:

  • Type-2 hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antibodies, particularly IgG or IgM, binding to antigens on the surface of target cells, leading to their destruction or dysfunction.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is an example of a type-2 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • In autoimmune hemolytic anemia, autoantibodies are produced against the antigens on the surface of red blood cells, resulting in their premature destruction by phagocytes in the spleen and liver.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chronic kidney rejection:

  • Chronic kidney rejection involves a complex immune response, including cellular and humoral components.

Option C - Arthus reaction:

  • Arthus reaction is a localized immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction that occurs when preformed antibodies react with antigens in the blood vessel walls, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • It is considered a type-3 hypersensitivity reaction.

Option D - Mantoux test:

  • Mantoux test is a type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Acute graft rejection occurs within?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:
Option C: Weeks to months: This option is correct because weeks to months is typically associated with acute graft rejection. 

Incorrect options:

Option A: Seconds to minutes: Rejection occurring within seconds to minutes after transplantation is extremely rare and not characteristic of acute graft rejection.

Option B: Days to weeks: This option is incorrect.

Option D: Months to years: This chronic graft rejection.

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia, all of the following are reduced, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Total iron binding capacity:

Iron Deficiency Anemia
Serum iron ↓
Total iron binding capacity ↑
Transferrin saturation ↓
Serum ferritin ↓
Soluble transferrin receptor ↑
Serum RBC protoporphyrin ↑

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male comes to the outdoor patient department with complaints of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating. On physical examination, his chest shows pectus excavatum and a high extremities-to-body ratio. Growth is seen on her tongue, and a mass on the left flank is also palpated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MEN 2B:

  • The patient's presentation episodic headaches, palpitations, sweating, pectus excavatum, high extremities-to-body ratio, tongue growth, and a flank mass are characteristic of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B).
  • MEN 2B is an autosomal dominant genetic syndrome caused by a mutation in the RET proto-oncogene.
  • It is associated with the development of multiple endocrine tumors, such as medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenomas.
  • MEN 2B is also characterized by distinctive physical features, including marfanoid habitus (high extremities-to-body ratio), mucosal neuromas (growth on the tongue), and gastrointestinal ganglioneuromas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - MEN 1:

  • MEN 1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1) is characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine glands, including the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland.
  • It does not typically present with the specific physical features described in the patient.

Option B - MEN 2A:

  • MEN 2A is another form of multiple endocrine neoplasia caused by RET gene mutations.
  • It is characterized by the development of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • The physical features associated with MEN 2B, such as marfanoid habitus and mucosal neuromas, are not typically seen in MEN 2A.

Option D - Neurofibromatosis type 2:

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) and other central nervous system tumors.
  • It does not typically present with the specific physical features described in the patient.

questions.text: Pheochromocytoma produces all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Secretin:

  • Pheochromocytomas are tumors that arise from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, resulting in excessive production of catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine.
  • These tumors can produce various hormones and vasoactive substances.
  • They do not produce secretin.
  • Secretin is a hormone produced by the S cells of the duodenum.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: Pheochromocytomas produce.

questions.text: Urea cycle occurs in which part of the cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Both

  • The urea cycle involves enzymatic reactions that occur in both the cytoplasm and the mitochondria. The synthesis of urea occurs in the cytoplasm, while the ornithine transcarbamylase reaction, which is an important step in the urea cycle, takes place in the mitochondria. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mitochondria: The urea cycle does involve some enzymatic reactions that occur in the mitochondria, specifically the ornithine transcarbamylase reaction. However, the majority of the urea cycle reactions occur in the cytoplasm. Therefore, option A is not the correct answer.

Option B - Cytoplasm: Many of the enzymatic reactions of the urea cycle take place in the cytoplasm of the cell. These reactions include the synthesis and breakdown of various intermediates involved in the urea cycle.

Option D - None: The urea cycle is a vital biochemical pathway that occurs in the body to remove excess nitrogen in the form of urea. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is a start codon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - AUG:

  • AUG is the start codon. It codes for the amino acid methionine and also serves as the initiation signal for protein synthesis. It is recognized by the ribosome as the site to begin translation.

Incorrect options:

Option A - UAA: UAA is not a start codon. It is a stop codon that signals the termination of protein synthesis.

Option B - UAG: UAG is also a stop codon and not a start codon. Like UAA, it signals the end of protein synthesis.

Option C - UGA: UGA is yet another stop codon and does not serve as a start codon. It indicates the termination of protein synthesis

questions.text: Melanin is synthesized from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tyrosine

  • Melanin is synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is converted into a compound called dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by the enzyme tyrosinase. Further enzymatic reactions and processes involving tyrosinase lead to the production of melanin. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Tryptophan: Tryptophan is primarily used in the synthesis of other compounds such as serotonin and niacin. Therefore, option B is not the correct answer.

Option C - Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is primarily used in the synthesis of other important compounds in the body, such as tyrosine and various neurotransmitters. Therefore, option C is not the correct answer.

Option D - Threonine: Threonine is an essential amino acid that plays various roles in protein synthesis and metabolism, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of melanin. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following aids in the process of wound healing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyaluronic acid

  • Hyaluronic acid is a glycosaminoglycan that is naturally present in the extracellular matrix of various tissues. It plays a crucial role in wound healing due to its ability to retain water, provide hydration to the wound bed, and create a favorable environment for cell migration and tissue repair. It also promotes angiogenesis and the production of growth factors involved in healing processes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Keratan sulfate: Keratan sulfate is a sulfated glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in various tissues, including the cornea and cartilage. While it plays important roles in tissue organization and function, it is not directly involved in wound healing.

Option B - Dermatan sulfate: Dermatan sulfate is another sulfated GAG present in the skin, blood vessels, and connective tissues. Like keratan sulfate, it contributes to tissue structure and function but is not directly involved in wound healing.

Option D - Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another sulfated GAG found in cartilage, tendons, and connective tissues. While it has important structural functions in these tissues, it is not directly involved in wound healing.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT inhibit oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • Thermogenin, also known as uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1), is a protein found in brown adipose tissue. Unlike the other options, thermogenin does not inhibit oxidative phosphorylation. Instead, it creates a channel that allows the flow of protons (H+) across the inner mitochondrial membrane, bypassing ATP synthase. This uncoupling of proton gradient and ATP synthesis generates heat instead of ATP production

Incorrect options:

Option A. CO (Carbon Monoxide): Carbon monoxide is a potent inhibitor of oxidative phosphorylation. It binds to cytochrome c oxidase, a component of the electron transport chain, and prevents the transfer of electrons, thus inhibiting ATP synthesis.

Option B. Antimycin A: Antimycin A is an antibiotic that specifically inhibits complex III of the electron transport chain. By blocking electron transfer from coenzyme Q to cytochrome c, it disrupts oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis.

Option C. Malonate: Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase, which is a key enzyme in the citric acid cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle). By inhibiting succinate dehydrogenase, malonate indirectly affects oxidative phosphorylation by reducing the availability of electron carriers in the electron transport chain.

questions.text: What is the role of zinc in the treatment of diarrhea?

choices.text: Reduces the risk, duration and severity of diarrheal episodes
Regulates intestinal transport & absorption of water and electrolytes

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All

  • Zinc supplementation addresses multiple aspects related to diarrhea. It reduces the risk, duration, and severity of diarrheal episodes, enhances immune response, and helps regulate intestinal transport and absorption of water and electrolytes. Therefore, option D is the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reduces the risk, duration, and severity of diarrheal episodes: Zinc supplementation has been shown to reduce the risk, duration, and severity of diarrheal episodes, particularly in children. It helps in restoring the integrity of the intestinal lining and reducing the loss of fluids and electrolytes during diarrhea.

Option B - Enhances immune response: Zinc plays a crucial role in supporting the immune system. It helps in the production and function of immune cells, such as T cells and natural killer cells, and contributes to the body's defense against pathogens. Zinc deficiency can impair immune function, making individuals more susceptible to infections, including those causing diarrhea.

Option C - Regulates intestinal transport & absorption of water and electrolytes: Zinc is involved in the regulation of intestinal transport and absorption of water and electrolytes. It helps maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelial cells, which are responsible for the absorption of nutrients and water. Zinc deficiency can disrupt these processes and contribute to diarrhea.

questions.text: What is the optimal approach for treating a patient who is hemodynamically stable, has a broad QRS complex on their ECG, and is experiencing antidromic tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • Intravenous procainamide: Procainamide is an antiarrhythmic medication that can be effective in treating antidromic tachycardia with a broad QRS complex. It works by blocking certain cardiac ion channels and restoring normal rhythm. Intravenous administration allows for rapid onset of action and is the preferred treatment option in this scenario.

Incorrect options:
Option A. Oral verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can be effective in treating certain types of supraventricular tachycardias. However, in the case of antidromic tachycardia with a broad QRS complex, verapamil is not recommended as it can potentially worsen the condition.
Option B. Oral beta-blocker: Beta-blockers are commonly used for rate control in supraventricular tachycardias. However, in the case of antidromic tachycardia with a broad QRS complex, oral beta-blockers may not be effective and are not the first-line treatment choice.
Option C. Cardioversion: Cardioversion involves the electrical conversion of an abnormal heart rhythm back to normal sinus rhythm. While cardioversion may be appropriate in certain situations, it is not the first-line treatment for antidromic tachycardia with a broad QRS complex.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect procedure when dealing with W.P.W?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Treadmill test

  • The treadmill test, also known as exercise stress testing, is not typically performed in individuals with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. WPW is a condition characterized by an abnormal electrical pathway (accessory pathway) in the heart that can cause rapid heart rates and potentially dangerous arrhythmias. Exercise stress testing may not be recommended in WPW because it can potentially induce tachycardias or ventricular fibrillation due to the presence of the accessory pathway.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Electrophysiological studies

  • Electrophysiological studies (EPS) are commonly performed in individuals with WPW syndrome. EPS involves the placement of catheters inside the heart to study the electrical conduction system and identify the location of the accessory pathway. It helps in determining the risk of arrhythmias and guiding further treatment options.

Option C. Oral beta blocker

  • Beta blockers are often used in the management of WPW syndrome. They work by blocking the effects of adrenaline on the heart, helping to slow down the heart rate and reduce the risk of arrhythmias. Oral beta blockers are frequently prescribed to control heart rate and prevent arrhythmias in individuals with WPW.

Option D. Procainamide

  • Procainamide is an antiarrhythmic medication that is sometimes used in the acute treatment of arrhythmias associated with WPW syndrome. It works by slowing down the electrical conduction through the accessory pathway. However, its use is generally reserved for acute situations and may not be the first-line treatment option.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is rescue percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) performed?

choices.text: Persistent chest pain with ST elevation > 60 min after thrombolysis
Persistent chest pain with ST elevation > 30 min after thrombolysis
Persistent chest persistent chest pain with ST elevation > 90 min after thrombolysis
Pain with ST elevation for > 120 min after thrombolysis

questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • Persistent chest pain with ST elevation > 90 min after thrombolysis: This option is correct. Rescue PCI is indicated when there is persistent chest pain accompanied by ST elevation more than 90 minutes after thrombolysis. In this case, the patient has ongoing ischemia despite thrombolysis, and urgent PCI is necessary to restore blood flow to the affected coronary artery. Therefore, option C is correct.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Persistent chest pain with ST elevation > 60 min after thrombolysis: This option is incorrect. Rescue PCI is not typically performed for chest pain persisting for 60 minutes after thrombolysis. In general, the window of opportunity for rescue PCI is shorter, and intervention is more effective when performed earlier.

Option B. Persistent chest pain with ST elevation > 30 min after thrombolysis: This option is incorrect. Similarly to option A, rescue PCI is not typically performed for chest pain persisting for 30 minutes after thrombolysis. Earlier intervention is generally preferred.

Option D. Pain with ST elevation for > 120 min after thrombolysis: This option is incorrect. Although the duration of chest pain and ST elevation is longer in this option, rescue PCI is typically performed when there is persistent chest pain and ST elevation more than 90 minutes after thrombolysis. Waiting for 120 minutes may delay necessary intervention

questions.text: Which of the following is cardio protective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HDL

 

Explanation:

HDL:

  • High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) is termed “good cholesterol.”

  • It plays a key role in reverse cholesterol transport, carrying cholesterol away from peripheral tissues and atherosclerotic plaques to the liver for excretion.

  • It also has anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, making it cardioprotective.

 

LDL (Option B):
LDL carries cholesterol to tissues but also deposits it in arterial walls, promoting atherosclerosis. Known as “bad cholesterol.”

IDL (Option C):
Intermediate-Density Lipoprotein is a transient form between VLDL and LDL and also contributes to plaque formation.

VLDL (Option D):
Very-Low-Density Lipoprotein primarily transports triglycerides and is considered atherogenic (promotes atherosclerosis).

questions.text: What are the effects on the fetus when Indomethacin is used in the uterus during the third trimester?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Early closure of ductus arteriosus: Indomethacin is a prostaglandin inhibitor, and its use in utero can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus before birth, which is the intended effect in certain cases.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Patent ductus arteriosus: Indomethacin is actually used to treat patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants. PDA is a condition where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. So, the use of Indomethacin would not lead to PDA.

Option C. Ventricular septal defect: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a congenital heart defect characterized by an abnormal opening between the ventricles. The use of Indomethacin is not associated with the development of VSD.

Option D. Atrial septal defect: Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital heart defect characterized by an abnormal opening between the atria. The use of Indomethacin is not associated with the development of ASD.

questions.text: Continuous murmur is heard in?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

  • Continuous murmurs are not confined to either phase of the cardiac cycle but instead begin in early systole and proceed through S2 into all or part of diastole.

  • Small PDAs are often silent to auscultation, and do not cause hemodynamic changes. The classic murmur is heard best just below the left clavicle and typically extends from systole past the second heart sound into diastole, reflecting flow turbulence and gradient between the aorta and the pulmonary arteries (resulting in left-to-right shunting).

Incorrect options:

Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD is a common congenital heart defect characterized by an abnormal opening between the right and left ventricles. The murmur associated with VSD is typically a holosystolic (pansystolic) murmur, heard best at the lower left sternal border. It is not a continuous murmur.

Option C. Atrial septal defect (ASD): ASD is a congenital heart defect characterized by an abnormal opening between the atria. The murmur associated with ASD is typically a systolic ejection murmur, heard best at the upper left sternal border. It is not a continuous murmur.

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF): TOF is a complex congenital heart defect characterized by a combination of four specific heart abnormalities. The murmur associated with TOF is typically a systolic ejection murmur, often accompanied by a harsh or crescendo-decrescendo quality. It is not a continuous murmur.

questions.text: What is the reason behind the stability of adenosine receptors, which is attributed to the formation of numerous disulfide bonds between?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cysteine:

  • Adenosine receptors, like many other proteins, can have disulfide bonds formed between cysteine residues. These disulfide bonds contribute to the stability and structure of the receptor.
  • Cysteine contains a thiol group (-SH) that can form a covalent bond with another cysteine residue, resulting in a disulfide bond. These disulfide bonds help maintain the structural integrity of the receptor and are important for its proper function. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Methionine: Methionine is an amino acid that does not participate directly in the formation of disulfide bonds. Therefore, option B is not the correct answer.

Option C - Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid that is positively charged and has a role in protein stability and structure, however, it does not directly participate in the formation of disulfide bonds. Therefore, option C is not the correct answer.

Option D - Alanine: Alanine is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid that does not contain a thiol group and is not involved in the formation of disulfide bonds. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the most common immediate complication following a splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemorrhage:

  • This is the correct option. Hemorrhage, or bleeding, is one of the most common immediate complications of splenectomy. The spleen is a highly vascular organ, and during surgery, there is a risk of bleeding from the splenic artery or its branches. Measures are taken to control bleeding during and after the procedure, but it remains a potential complication.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - Fistula: While it is possible for a fistula to develop after splenectomy, it is not the most common immediate complication. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C - Bleeding from gastric mucosa: The spleen is not directly involved in regulating gastric mucosal integrity or bleeding control. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D - Pancreatitis:While complications related to the pancreas can occur after splenectomy in some cases, pancreatitis itself is not the most common immediate complication. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Steps of PCR in sequence are?

choices.text: Extend DNA, anneal primers, Denture DNA
Anneal primers, extend DNA, Denature DNA
Denature DNA, anneal primers, Extends DNA
Denature DNA, Extend DNA, Anneal primers

questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • Denature DNA, anneal primers, extend DNA: This is the correct sequence of steps in PCR.
  • The first step is denaturation, which involves heating the DNA sample to separate the double-stranded DNA into single strands.
  • Next, the temperature is lowered to allow the primers to anneal or bind to the complementary regions of the single-stranded DNA templates.
  • Finally, the temperature is raised, and a DNA polymerase extends the primers by adding nucleotides to synthesize new DNA strands.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Extend DNA, anneal primers, denature DNA: This sequence is incorrect. In PCR, the denaturation step usually comes first to separate the DNA strands. Then, primers are annealed to the single-stranded DNA templates, and finally, DNA extension occurs.

Option B - Anneal primers, extend DNA, denature DNA: This sequence is also incorrect. The denaturation step typically precedes primer annealing.

Option D - Denature DNA, extend DNA, anneal primers: This sequence is incorrect. The annealing of primers typically occurs after the denaturation step but before DNA extension.

questions.text: In fever of unknown origin, blood sample should be drawn how many times?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - 3:

  • This option is correct. 3 sterile blood samples should be drawn and cultured. It is necessary to ensure ample growth time for any fastidious organisms, such as HACEK organisms and also to look for unusual organisms. But without potential diagnostic clues culturing of 3 blood samples will render no use.

questions.text: Which among the following has low glycemic index?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Has slower absorption

  • Has slower absorption: This option is correct. Low glycemic index foods are characterized by carbohydrates that are digested and absorbed more slowly by the body. This slow absorption leads to a slower and more controlled release of glucose into the bloodstream, resulting in a more stable and sustained blood glucose response.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Easily digestible: This option is incorrect. The digestibility of food is not directly related to its glycemic index. The glycemic index measures how quickly carbohydrates in food are broken down and absorbed, which is not solely determined by digestibility.

Option B - Increases plasma glucose: This option is incorrect. Foods with a high glycemic index tend to cause a rapid increase in blood glucose levels, while low glycemic index foods result in a slower and more gradual increase in blood glucose levels.

Option D - Increase glycogen deposits: This option is incorrect. Glycogen deposits refer to the storage form of glucose in the body, primarily found in the liver and muscles. The glycemic index of a food does not directly influence glycogen deposits. Instead, it reflects how quickly carbohydrates from the food are converted into glucose and affect blood glucose levels.

questions.text: In what situations is surgery contraindicated for patients with Ulcerative Colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Crohn’s disease:

  • Crohn’s disease: Presence of crohn’s disease is a contraindication of surgery in ulcerative colitis due to high rates of fistula formation, obstruction, and leakage.

Incorrect options:

Option B, C, D - These are indications for surgery in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: What is the mainstay of treatment of glue ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Myringotomy + aeration to middle ear:

  • Myringotomy + aeration to middle ear: Myringotomy is a surgical procedure in which a small incision is made in the tympanic membrane . This allows for the drainage of fluid from the middle ear and the insertion of a ventilation tube (grommet) to maintain aeration and equalize pressure in the middle ear. Myringotomy with aeration is a commonly performed procedure for the treatment of glue ear,.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Radical Mastoidectomy: Radical mastoidectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing the mastoid air cells and creating a cavity in the mastoid bone.

Option C - Temporal bone resection: Temporal bone resection involves the removal of a portion of the temporal bone, which houses the structures of the ear. It is a more extensive surgical procedure usually performed for advanced cases of ear cancer or severe complications of ear disease.

Option D - Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy: Tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy are surgical procedures that involve the removal of the tonsils and adenoids, respectively. While they can be performed to improve breathing and reduce recurrent ear infections in some cases

questions.text:
Please match the appropriate answers related to cardiac abnormalities and their corresponding syndromes.


	
		
			
			1) Noonan syndrome
			
			
			(A) PDA
			
		
		
			
			2) Downs syndrome

questions.text: Which of the options accurately describes the development of cancer in patients with ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Bad prognosis if it involved only rectum
Good prognosis if it involves only rectum and is low grade
2% chance of malignancy if present for 10 years
Young age onset has low chances as compared to old age onset

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2% chance of malignancy if present for 10 years:

  • 2% chance of malignancy if present for 10 years This statement is generally true.
  • Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of developing colorectal cancer compared to the general population. The risk is directly related to the duration of the disease. It is estimated that after 10 years of ulcerative colitis, the cumulative risk of developing colorectal cancer is around 2%.
  • However, it is important to note that individual risks can vary depending on other factors such as disease severity, extent, and presence of dysplasia.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Bad prognosis if it involved only rectum This statement is not entirely accurate. While rectal involvement can increase the risk of cancer development, the prognosis is determined by multiple factors and cannot be solely based on the involvement of the rectum.

Option B - Good prognosis if it involves only rectum and is low grade- This statement is partially correct. The prognosis of colorectal cancer in ulcerative colitis can vary based on multiple factors, including the extent and grade of the cancer. However, other factors such as the presence of dysplasia, depth of invasion, and lymph node involvement also play a role in determining prognosis.

Option D - Young age onset has low chances as compared to old age onset- This statement is not entirely accurate. Young age onset does not guarantee a low chance of developing cancer, and regular surveillance and monitoring are important regardless of age.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of a patient who has a two-day history of fever, with a neck swelling and displacement of one tonsil towards the midline upon examination?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Parapharyngeal abscess: This is the correct option. A parapharyngeal abscess is an infection that occurs in the space behind the tonsil and next to the pharynx. It can cause swelling in the neck and displacement of the tonsil towards the midline, which matches the patient's presentation.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Quinsy: Quinsy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, is a complication of tonsillitis. It involves the collection of pus between the tonsillar capsule and the surrounding tissues. While it can cause swelling in the neck, it typically presents with severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and a "hot potato" voice. The patient in the scenario does not exhibit these typical symptoms, making quinsy less likely.

Option C. Retropharyngeal abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection that occurs in the space behind the pharynx and in front of the cervical vertebrae. It typically presents with neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and a stiff neck. The patient in the scenario does not exhibit these typical symptoms, making retropharyngeal abscess less likely.

Option D. Tonsillitis: Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils and can present with symptoms such as sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and fever. While the patient in the scenario has a fever, the presence of a swelling in the neck and the displacement of the tonsil towards the midline suggests a more localized infection, making tonsillitis less likely.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with necrotizing fascitis was admitted to the ER. The patient was tachycardic and hypotensive. He was treated for septic shock. Which of the following is the characteristic feature of refractory septic shock?

choices.text: Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration
Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high dose vasopressors
Shock that is refractory to medical treatment
Shock that does not improve despite treatment for 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high-dose vasopressors:

  • Refractory septic shock is defined as septic shock that does not respond to initial fluid resuscitation and requires high doses of vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure.
  • The specific criteria often include persistence of shock despite adequate fluid resuscitation and high doses of vasopressors.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration: This option does not fully define refractory septic shock.

Option C - Shock that is refractory to medical treatment: This option is too broad and does not specifically address the criteria of IVF administration and high-dose vasopressors.

Option D - Shock that does not improve despite treatment for 24 hours: This option sets a specific time frame of 24 hours, which is not consistent with the definition of refractory septic shock.

questions.text: Continuous murmur is heard in:
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Patent ductus arteriosus:

  • A continuous murmur refers to a murmur that is heard throughout systole and diastole without interruption.
  • Continuous murmur is heard in patent ductus arteriosus
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect characterized by the persistence of a normal fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the aorta, known as the ductus arteriosus.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B: Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD produces a holosystolic murmur.

Option C: Atrial septal defect (ASD): ASD typically causes a systolic ejection murmur.

Option D: Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of Fallot is associated with a systolic ejection murmur, often described as a harsh or crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neck swelling:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma often presents with cervical lymphadenopathy (neck swelling) as an early sign. The most common lymph node involved is LN between the angle of the jaw and mastoid and LN along the spinal accessory and in the posterior triangle of the neck in HO's triangle.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Airway obstruction: This symptom can occur in advanced stages of nasopharyngeal carcinoma when the tumor grows and blocks the nasal passages or affects the surrounding structures.

Option B - Headache: Headaches are a non-specific symptom While headaches can occur in some cases of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, they are not a common or specific symptom.

Option D - Epistaxis: While nasopharyngeal carcinoma can sometimes cause epistaxis, it is not a prominent or common symptom.

questions.text: What is the waist to hip ratio that is associated with an increased risk of heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • > 0.85 in females: This option is correct. A waist-to-hip ratio greater than 0.85 in females is associated with an increased risk of heart disease. It indicates a higher proportion of abdominal fat and is considered a marker of central obesity, which is linked to cardiovascular health risks.

Incorrect options:

Option A. > 0.80 in males: While a waist-to-hip ratio greater than 0.80 in males may suggest central obesity, it is not specifically associated with an increased risk of heart disease. The threshold for increased risk is higher in males.

Option B. > 0.80 in females: This option is incorrect. A waist-to-hip ratio greater than 0.80 in females is not the commonly accepted threshold for increased risk of heart disease.

Option C. > 0.85 in males: This option is incorrect. While a waist-to-hip ratio greater than 0.80 in males may indicate central obesity, it is not specifically associated with an increased risk of heart disease. The threshold for increased risk is typically lower in males compared to females.

questions.text: Menke's disease is a metabolic defect in the process of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Copper:

  • Menke's disease is a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by impaired copper absorption and transport.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene that regulates the metabolism of copper in the body.
  • As a result, copper metabolism is disrupted, leading to copper deficiency and subsequent neurological and developmental abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Picket fence fever is a feature of which of the following in
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis:

  • Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis: Picket fence fever refers to a pattern of fever spikes seen in patients with lateral sinus thrombophlebitis, which is the inflammation and clotting of the veins draining the lateral sinus in the brain. It is called "picket fence fever" due to the characteristic pattern of high fevers followed by normal or low-grade temperatures.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Quincy: Quincy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, is a localized collection of pus behind the tonsils. It typically presents with symptoms such as severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and swollen tonsils.

Option C - Laryngitis sicca: Laryngitis sicca, also known as dry laryngitis, refers to inflammation of the larynx resulting in a dry and scratchy throat. It is characterized by hoarseness, throat irritation, and cough.

Option D - Croup: Croup is a viral infection that primarily affects young children, causing inflammation of the upper airways and resulting in a characteristic barking cough, hoarseness, and difficulty breathing. Picket fence fever is not associated with croup.

questions.text: Pellagra like rash is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct option C: Hartnup disease:

  • Hartnup disease is a metabolic disorder characterized by impaired transport of certain amino acids, including tryptophan.
  • Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3) synthesis.
  • A deficiency of niacin can lead to pellagra-like symptoms, including a rash, gastrointestinal disturbances, and neurological abnormalities.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D do not cause a pellagra-like rash.

Option A: Gaucher disease: Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various organs.

Option B: Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria is a disorder of phenylalanine and tyrosine metabolism, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

Option D: Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria is a genetic disorder characterized by the inability to metabolize phenylalanine properly.

questions.text: What is the treatment for neutropenia following chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Filgastrim:

  • Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that stimulates the production of neutrophils. It is commonly used to treat neutropenia caused by chemotherapy by promoting the production of new neutrophils in the bone marrow.
  • It is started one day after myelosuppressive chemotherapy and injected SC or IV, 5 µg/kg daily.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a medication that is used in combination with certain chemotherapy drugs to enhance their effectiveness. It is not specifically indicated for the treatment of neutropenia.

Option C - Ondansetron: Ondansetron is an antiemetic medication used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly associated with chemotherapy or radiation treatment. It does not directly address neutropenia.

Option D - Darbepoetin: Darbepoetin is a synthetic form of erythropoietin, a hormone that stimulates the production of red blood cells. It is used to treat anemia, but it does not have a direct effect on neutropenia.

questions.text: Why is cold water not used for syringing?

choices.text: Cold water leads to wax impaction
Cold water leads to foreign body impaction
It causes vertigo by caloric stimulation

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - It causes vertigo by caloric stimulation

  • It causes vertigo by caloric stimulation:. Cold water can cause vertigo by caloric stimulation of the inner ear. Caloric stimulation is a test used to assess the function of the vestibular system. Warm or cold water is typically used to irrigate the ear canal, which creates a temperature gradient that stimulates the vestibular apparatus. This stimulation can induce vertigo, a sensation of spinning or dizziness.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Cold water leads to wax impaction:. Cold water does not directly lead to wax impaction. Wax impaction occurs when there is an accumulation of earwax (cerumen) in the ear canal, usually due to inadequate cleaning or improper ear hygiene.

Option B - Cold water leads to foreign body impaction: Cold water does not cause foreign body impaction. Foreign body impaction occurs when a foreign object becomes lodged in the ear canal, typically due to improper insertion of objects into the ear.

Option C - Can cause tympanic membrane rupture:. Cold water, by itself, does not typically cause tympanic membrane rupture (a perforated eardrum). Tympanic membrane rupture can occur due to factors such as trauma, infection, or sudden changes in pressure.

questions.text: A pediatric patient arrives at the hospital complaining of several abnormal fractures, and the X-ray shows the image shown below. The blood tests indicate low levels of phosphorus and calcium, normal levels of Vitamin D, and increased levels of PTH. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Osteopetrosis:

  • The patient’s presentation with multiple pathological fractures, low phosphorus and calcium levels, normal Vitamin D levels, and elevated PTH along with the X-ray findings is suggestive of osteopetrosis.
  • Osteopetrosis is a genetic disorder characterized by defective osteoclast function, leading to increased bone density and susceptibility to fractures.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Osteomalacia:

  • Osteomalacia is characterized by softening of the bones due to vitamin D deficiency or impaired metabolism.
  • However, in this case, the vitamin D levels are normal.

Option C - Osteosclerosis: Osteosclerosis refers to abnormal hardening or increased density of the bones, but it does not present with multiple pathological fractures.

Option D - Histiocytosis X:

  • Histiocytosis X (also known as Langerhans cell histiocytosis) is a group of disorders characterized by abnormal proliferation of certain immune cells called Langerhans cells.
  • It does not present with findings described in the question.

questions.text: A 65-year-old, male with hypertension develops sudden onset weakness on the right side of the face & arm. His attender recalls history of headache, blurred vision in the patient which leads to the suspicion of increased ICP. Which is the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abducens nerve:

  • The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) is most commonly affected in cases of increased ICP.
  • When the ICP increases, it can lead to compression or stretching of the abducens nerve, resulting in weakness or paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle.
  • This causes a sign known as false localizing sign, as the problem is due to the stretching of the nerve.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Trochlear nerve: Increased ICP can potentially affect the trochlear nerve, it is not the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C - Trigeminal nerve: Increased ICP can cause headache and facial pain, the trigeminal nerve itself is not typically affected as the primary cranial nerve involved in raised ICP. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D - Facial nerve: Increased ICP can potentially affect the facial nerve, it is not the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a manifestation of congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gumma:

  • Congenital syphilis is a condition caused by transmission of the Treponema pallidum from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to various manifestations, including Hutchinson's teeth, Olympic brow (saddle nose), and interstitial keratitis.
  • However, gumma, which is a granulomatous lesion, is seen in the tertiary stage of syphilis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hutchinson's teeth: Hutchinson's teeth y refer to notched and peg-shaped permanent incisors.

Option C - Olympic brow (saddle nose): Olympic brow, also known as saddle nose, is a deformity seen in congenital syphilis where the bridge of the nose collapses.

Option D - Interstitial keratitis: Interstitial keratitis, which is inflammation of the cornea, can occur as a manifestation of congenital syphilis.

questions.text: From the first pharyngeal arch, which muscle originates among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Anterior belly of digastric muscle:

  • Anterior belly of digastric muscle: This option is correct. The anterior belly of the digastric muscle originates from the first pharyngeal arch. It plays a role in opening the mouth and depressing the mandible.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Stapedius muscle: The stapedius muscle is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It arises from the second pharyngeal arch and is involved in the movement and stabilization of the stapes bone within the middle ear.

Option C- Posterior belly of digastric muscle: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle does not originate from the first pharyngeal arch. It arises from the second pharyngeal arch and assists in the movement of the hyoid bone.

Option D- Stylopharyngeus: The stylopharyngeus muscle is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It originates from the third pharyngeal arch and helps elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speech.

  • In summary, the muscle that originates from the first pharyngeal arch is the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text: Rinku devi, a 26 years old female, labourer by occupation presented to you with complains of pain abdomen, nausea and restlessness since 4 hours. She gives h/o 2 episodes of hematuria. USG showed a 3×3 cm stone in Right renal pelvis. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis. Which of following is the best procedure for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PCNL:

  • PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy) is the best procedure for the management of kidney stones > 2 cm in size. 
  • Management of Kidney stones
    • Ketrolac/Tramadol
    • Euvolemia is achieved via IVF (prevents dehydration)
    • Alpha-1 blocker (Tamsulosin) can be given to relax ureter and expels the stone.
    • <2 cm kidney stone- Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (contraindicated in pregnancy bleeding diathesis)
    • > 2 cm kidney stone- PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy)
    • Ureteric stone (lower 1/3rd): Endourological appraoch- Dormian basket.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ESWL: ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy) is a non-invasive procedure done for kidney stones <2 cm. 

Option C - Antegrade Pyeloplasty: Antegrade Pyeloplasty is a surgical procedure used to treat ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction.

Option D - Retrograde pyeloplasty: Retrograde Pyeloplasty is also a surgical procedure used for the treatment of UPJ obstruction.

questions.text: Which chromosome is affected in Hunter disease, leading to an abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - X chromosome:

  • Hunter syndrome, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II, is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate sulfatase.
  • The defective gene responsible for the condition is located on the X chromosome.

Incorrect Options -B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What does a dip at 4000Hz indicate in pure tone audiometry?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Noise induced hearing loss:

  • Noise-induced hearing loss:. Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) is caused by prolonged exposure to loud noises, leading to damage to the sensory cells in the inner ear. NIHL typically affects the high-frequency range first, resulting in a characteristic dip at frequencies around 4000 Hz in pure tone audiometry. Therefore, a dip at 4000 Hz is indicative of noise-induced hearing loss.
  • Dip at 4000 Hz- Boilers notch Dip at 2000 Hz in Bone conduction- Carhart notch

Incorrect options:

Option A - Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis is a condition characterized by abnormal bone growth in the middle ear, specifically around the stapes bone. It typically leads to conductive hearing loss rather than sensorineural hearing loss. A dip at 4000 Hz in pure tone audiometry is not a typical finding in otosclerosis.

Option B - Meniere's disease: Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that involves episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), and a sensation of fullness or pressure in the affected ear. While Meniere's disease can cause low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, a dip specifically at 4000 Hz is not characteristic of Meniere's disease.

Option D - Age-related hearing loss: Age-related hearing loss, also known as presbycusis, is a common type of sensorineural hearing loss that occurs gradually as a person gets older. It typically affects the higher frequencies first, but a dip specifically at 4000 Hz is not a defining feature of age-related hearing loss.

questions.text: A new vaccine which was launched in 2018 in Thailand with the name CYD-TDV. In which of the following condition it is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dengue:

  • This is the correct option. CYD-TDV is a vaccine used for the prevention of dengue fever. It is designed to protect against all four serotypes of the dengue virus. The vaccine was launched in 2018 in Thailand under the trade name CYD-TDV (Dengvaxia). Therefore, option A is correct.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Intellectual disability is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phenylketonuria:

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body.
  • If left untreated, elevated phenylalanine levels can cause severe intellectual disability and developmental delays.

Incorrect options:

Options B, C, and D do not cause intellectual disability.

Option B -Alkaptonuria:

  • Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

Option C - Albinism:

  • Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of melanin production.

Option D - Von Gierke disease:

  • Von Gierke disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type I, is a metabolic disorder affecting glycogen metabolism.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the spasm causing trismus in parapharyngeal abscess?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Medial pterygoid: The spasm of the Medial pterygoid muscle can cause trismus in parapharyngeal abscess. This muscle is involved in closing the jaw.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Lateral pterygoid: The Lateral pterygoid muscle is responsible for protrusion and side-to-side movements of the jaw, but it is not directly associated with trismus in parapharyngeal abscess.

Option C. Masseter: The Masseter muscle is one of the main muscles involved in closing the jaw. However, in parapharyngeal abscess, the spasm of the Medial pterygoid muscle is primarily responsible for trismus.

Option D. Temporalis: The Temporalis muscle is another muscle involved in closing the jaw. However, it is not specifically associated with trismus in parapharyngeal abscess.

  • In summary, the correct muscle responsible for trismus in parapharyngeal abscess is the Medial pterygoid muscle (option A). It is important to note that proper diagnosis and treatment by a healthcare professional are essential for managing this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who had a history of domestic animal bite has come for a follow-up post 90 days after receiving rabies post-exposure prophylaxis. Now what will you use for rapid diagnosis of rabies in this case?

choices.text: Skin biopsy with fluorescent antibody testing

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Skin Biopsy with Fluorescent Antibody Testing:

  • Skin biopsy for rabies antigen detection via direct fluorescent antibody testing is a commonly used method for rapid diagnosis of rabies. A skin biopsy sample taken from the nape of the neck with at least 10 hair follicles is the best specimen, and it is stained with fluorescent antibodies specific to the rabies virus. If the virus is present, it will bind to the antibodies and produce a fluorescence, confirming the diagnosis of rabies.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rabies Virus Specific Antibodies: Testing for rabies virus-specific antibodies in the patient's blood is not a suitable method for diagnosis of rabies. The presence of antibodies in blood appears late and is present in both rabies-infected and immunized individuals. CSF antibodies appear early, and they are produced only in rabies-infected individuals but not in response to vaccination

Option C - Inoculation in Mice: Inoculation in mice helps in the isolation of the virus. It involves injecting the patient's tissue sample into a live mouse and observing for signs of rabies infection in the mouse. This method is time-consuming and may not provide rapid results.

Option D - Corneal Impression Smear: Corneal impression smear is another method used for diagnosing rabies via direct fluorescent antibody testing, but with a low sensitivity of 30%.

questions.text: In parotid gland surgery, which of the subsequent structures serves as a reference point for the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tragal pointer:

  • Tragal pointer: The tragal pointer is a small prominence located at the anterior margin of the tragus of the ear.
  • The tragal pointer is a landmark used to locate the main trunk of the facial nerve as it exits the stylomastoid foramen.
  • The facial nerve emerges from the stylomastoid foramen and runs forward through the parotid gland, and the tragal pointer helps in identifying the position of facial nerve during parotid gland surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Posterior border of mylohyoid: The posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle is not directly related to the facial nerve. It is a muscle that forms the floor of the oral cavity and is not typically used as a landmark in parotid gland surgery.

Option C - Tip of helix: The tip of the helix, which is the outer rim of the ear, is not specifically associated with the facial nerve. It is not commonly used as a landmark in parotid gland surgery.

Option D - Styloid process: The styloid process is a bony projection located in the neck region. While the facial nerve courses near the styloid process, it is not typically used as a direct landmark for identifying the facial nerve during parotid gland surgery.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old child who is brought to the clinic with developmental delay and extrapyramidal symptoms and is found to have a lens dislocation towards the inferonasal area during further examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Homocystinuria:
