  • Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired metabolism of the amino acid methionine.
  • It is caused by deficiencies in enzymes involved in the conversion of methionine to cysteine.
  • The dislocation of the lens (ectopia lentis) is a characteristic feature of homocystinuria.
  • Additionally, patients may present with developmental delays, intellectual disability, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Marfan syndrome:

  • Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene.
  • While it can also present with ectopia lentis, it is not associated with the developmental delays and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option C - Alkaptonuria:

  • Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • It does not typically present with dislocated lenses or extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option D - Wilson disease:

  • Wilson disease is a disorder of copper metabolism characterized by the accumulation of copper in various organs, particularly the liver and brain.
  • It does not typically present with ectopia lentis or developmental delays.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in case of continuous watery discharge from the nose following a trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CSF rhinorrhea:

  • CSF rhinorrhea occurs when there is a leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the nose. It can be a result of trauma to the head or skull fracture. Continuous watery discharge from the nose after trauma is a characteristic feature of CSF rhinorrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CSF otorrhea: CSF otorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the ear.

Option B - Common colds: Common colds typically present with symptoms such as nasal congestion, runny nose, sneezing, and a clear or slightly colored discharge.

Option D - Anterior epistaxis: Anterior epistaxis refers to nosebleeds that occur from the front part of the nose. It typically presents with bleeding from the nasal cavity and may cause a discharge of blood.

questions.text: Common neurological tumour in NF-2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vestibular Schwannoma:

  • Bilateral Vestibular Schwannomas are most common tumor seen in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Optic glioma: Optic gliomas are tumors that affect the optic nerve. While they can be seen in other conditions such as neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), they are not typically associated with NF-2.

Option C - Café-Au-Lait macules: Café-au-lait macules are pigmented skin lesions that can be seen in both NF-1 and NF-2. However, they are not tumors and do not specifically indicate the presence of a neurological tumor.

Option D - Neurofibrosarcoma: Neurofibrosarcoma is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 6-year-old child who exhibits hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, and develops a rash following the administration of ampicillin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Infectious mononucleosis:

  • The patient’s presentation with hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, and a rash following the administration of ampicillin is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.
  • Infectious mononucleosis is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The rash, known as an ampicillin rash, is a characteristic reaction seen in patients with EBV infection who are treated with ampicillin or other penicillin-based antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

  • Rash following the administration of ampicillin is characteristic of infectious mononucleosis and not seen in Options B, C, and D.

questions.text: What is the recommended method for preventing meningococcal meningitis during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ceftriaxone:

  • Ceftriaxone is commonly used for the prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis in pregnancy.
  • It is given as a single intramuscular or intravenous dose for prophylaxis in individuals who have had close contact with a person diagnosed with meningococcal disease. Therefore, option A is correct.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - Rifampicin: Rifampicin is also used for the prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis; however, it is not the preferred choice in pregnancy. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C - Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is avoided in pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on the developing fetus. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D - Penicillin G: Penicillin G is effective against many bacterial infections, but it is not the recommended prophylactic treatment for meningococcal meningitis. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which one of the subsequent options does not represent a premalignant lesion or condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis: Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species. It is not considered a premalignant lesion or condition.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Oral submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucosal fibrosis is a chronic, progressive condition characterized by the formation of fibrous bands in the oral cavity. It is associated with the habitual use of betel quid, tobacco, and certain spices. It is considered a premalignant condition because it carries an increased risk of developing oral squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an autoimmune condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral mucosa. While lichen planus itself is not considered premalignant, it has been associated with an increased risk of oral squamous cell carcinoma in some cases.

Option D. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia refers to white or gray patches that develop on the mucous membranes, including the oral mucosa. It is considered a premalignant lesion because it has the potential to transform into oral cancer.

questions.text: AFP is a tumour marker for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hepatocellular carcinoma:

  • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) is a tumor marker primarily associated with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common type of liver cancer. Elevated levels of AFP in the blood can indicate the presence of HCC. It is important to note that AFP is not specific to HCC and can also be elevated in other conditions such as certain germ cell tumors and liver cirrhosis. However, in the context of the given options, HCC is the most relevant association with AFP.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not innervated by the hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Palatoglossus: This is the correct option. The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) does not supply the palatoglossus muscle. The palatoglossus muscle is innervated by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). Therefore, option A is correct.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Styloglossus: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the styloglossus muscle. The styloglossus muscle is responsible for retracting and elevating the tongue. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C. Genioglossus: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the genioglossus muscle. The genioglossus muscle is the main muscle responsible for protruding and retracting the tongue. It plays a crucial role in swallowing and speech. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D. Hyoglossus: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the hyoglossus muscle. The hyoglossus muscle helps depress and retract the tongue. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: In an eye camp, doctors try to make people aware of the causes of blindness. Vitamin A is the leading cause of preventable childhood blindness. A parent brings her 18-month-old child to the doctor for a routine eye check-up. The doctor notices a thinned-out cornea, and from old records, it was seen that the child also has iron-deficiency anemia. If the weight of the child is 10kg, what should be the dose of vitamin A to be given in this case if the doctor marks it as keratomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: 2,00,000 IU:

  • Keratomalacia is a severe condition of the cornea caused by vitamin A deficiency.
  • In cases of keratomalacia, a high dose of vitamin A is required to correct the deficiency and prevent further damage.
  • The recommended dose of vitamin A for the treatment of keratomalacia in children is 2,00,000 IU.
  • According to WHO guidelines, children aged 12-59 months should receive 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately, with additional doses on subsequent days as necessary.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a post-hepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Budd Chiari syndrome:

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome: Budd-Chiari syndrome is a post-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. It is characterized by the obstruction or narrowing of the hepatic veins, which impairs the blood flow out of the liver.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Banti disease: Banti disease, also known as non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis, is a condition characterized by fibrosis and obstruction of the intrahepatic portal veins. It is considered a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension.

Option C - Portal vein thrombosis: Portal vein thrombosis refers to the formation of a blood clot within the portal vein, which can lead to impaired blood flow and increased pressure in the portal system. It is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension.

Option D - Schistosomiasis: Schistosomiasis is considered a presinusoidal hepatic cause of portal hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a patient who is unable to smell coffee but can smell ammonia after experiencing head trauma?

choices.text: Ammonia is used for testing olfactory nerve
The olfaction system is not damaged

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ammonia irritates the trigeminal nerve:

  • When ammonia vapor comes into contact with the mucous membranes lining the nasal passages, it can trigger a sensation of irritation or burning, which is detected by nerve endings associated with the trigeminal nerve, which is responsible for sensations such as pain, temperature, and chemical irritants. When a person smells ammonia, the trigeminal nerve can be activated, leading to a sensation or perception of smell.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ammonia is used for testing olfactory nerve: Ammonia is not typically used for testing the olfactory nerve as it can also stimulate the trigeminal nerve. Instead, specific odorants or substances with distinct smells, such as coffee or essential oils, are commonly used in olfactory testing to assess the function of the olfactory nerve.

Option B - The olfaction system is not damaged: If the patient is unable to smell coffee after head trauma but can smell ammonia, it suggests a specific impairment in detecting certain odors, indicating damage or dysfunction in the olfaction system.

Option D - All of the above: This statement is incorrect because only option C is correct. Option A and B are incorrect as explained above.

questions.text: What is the recommended preventive dosage of Oseltamivir for infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3 mg/kg/day:

  • Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication commonly used for the prevention and treatment of influenza.
  • The prophylactic dose of Oseltamivir for infants is 3 mg/kg/day.
  • This dose is used to prevent influenza infection in infants at risk.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Pheochromocytoma is associated in production of all of the below except.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cortisol:

  • Cortisol: Pheochromocytomas are not associated with cortisol production. Cortisol is primarily produced by the adrenal cortex in response to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation, whereas pheochromocytomas originate from the adrenal medulla and are more focused on the production of catecholamines

Incorrect options

Options A, B, and D:

  • Pheochromocytomas are associated with production of these hormones.

questions.text: Which muscle among the options provided functions as an accessory muscle in the process of mastication?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • This is the correct option. The buccinator muscle is an accessory masticatory muscle. It is a flat, thin muscle located in the cheek region. The buccinator muscle plays a role in actions such as compressing the cheeks against the teeth, assisting in chewing and swallowing, and maintaining oral competence. Therefore, option A is correct.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Masseter: The masseter muscle is not an accessory masticatory muscle but one of the primary muscles involved in mastication (chewing). It is a powerful muscle located at the side of the face, covering the jawbone. The masseter muscle is responsible for the elevation and protrusion of the mandible during chewing. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is not an accessory masticatory muscle but another primary muscle involved in mastication. It is located on the inner side of the mandible and functions in elevating and protruding the mandible during chewing. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D. Lateral pterygoid: The lateral pterygoid muscle is not an accessory masticatory muscle but one of the primary muscles involved in mastication. It is located in the region of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and is responsible for the forward movement (protrusion) and lateral movement (side-to-side) of the mandible during chewing. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Cut off for diagnosis of Priapism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 4 hours:

  • Priapism refers to a persistent and painful erection and may be associated with sickle cell anemia, hypercoagulable states, spinal cord injury, or injection of vasodilator agents into the penis.

  • Priapism is diagnosed when an erection persists for 4 hours or longer. This duration indicates a pathological condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C - 1 hour, 2 hours & 3 hours:

  • Priapism is diagnosed when an erection persists for 4 hours or longer

questions.text: A term neonate was born to a G2P1 mother, and initial measures were done by your senior resident, and he asked you a question: A newborn loses maximum heat from?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Head:

  • A newborn loses the maximum amount of heat from the head.
  • The head has a large surface area relative to the rest of the body, and the scalp is often uncovered.
  • Heat loss from the head can be minimized by providing appropriate head coverings and keeping the baby's head warm.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Glucose is reabsorbed in which part?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Proximal convoluted tubule:

  • 100% glucose is absorbed in the proximal tubules. Proximal tubules are divided into two parts as follows.

Tubular Segment

Glucose Reabsorption (%)

Luminal Transporter (Lumen to cytoplasm)

Basolateral Transporter (Cytoplasm to blood)

Proximal Convoluted Tubules (PCT)

90%

SGLT type II (Secondary active Transporter)

  • 1 molecule of sodium and 1 molecule of glucose from the lumen to the cell.

GLUT-2 (Facilitated diffusion transporter)

Proximal Straight Tubules (PST)

10%

SGLT type I (Secondary active Transporter)

  • 2 molecules of sodium and 1 molecule of glucose from the lumen to the cell.

GLUT-1 (Facilitated diffusion transporter)

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of a 6-year-old patient who has been experiencing fever for the past 3 days and complains of pain in the right upper abdomen, and upon examination, tenderness is observed in the right upper quadrant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - USG (Ultrasonography):

  • Ultrasonography is a non-invasive imaging modality that can help visualize the liver, gallbladder, and other abdominal structures.
  • It can provide valuable information about the presence of any abnormalities such as hepatomegaly, gallstones, or signs of inflammation in the right upper quadrant.
  • The ultrasound pulses echo off tissues with different reflection properties and are returned to the probe, which records and displays them as an image.
  • Several modes of ultrasound are used in medical imaging:
    • A-mode
    • B-mode
    • M-mode

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Serology: Serological tests are blood tests used to detect specific antibodies or antigens in the blood. While serology can be helpful in certain situations, such as identifying specific infections or autoimmune conditions, it may not be the initial investigation of choice in this scenario.

Option C - LFT (Liver Function Tests): Liver function tests, including SGOT and SGPT, assess liver enzymes to evaluate liver function. While these tests can provide information about liver health, they may not be the most appropriate initial investigation to assess the cause of pain in the right hypochondrium.

Option D - CT abdomen (Computed Tomography): CT abdomen is a cross-sectional imaging technique that provides detailed images of abdominal structures. While it can be useful in certain cases, such as when a more detailed evaluation is required, it may not be the initial investigation of choice in a 6-year-old patient due to concerns about radiation exposure and it being a more expensive diagnostic test.

questions.text: What is the recommended daily dose of iodine for a child?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: 90-120 μg:

  • The recommended daily dose of iodine in a child is 90-120 μg.
  • Iodine is an essential nutrient required for the synthesis of thyroid hormones.
  • Adequate iodine intake is important for normal thyroid function and proper growth and development.

Incorrect options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is absent in Horner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mydriasis:

  • Mydriasis (dilated pupil): This is incorrect. Horner syndrome is characterized by meiosis (constricted pupil) rather than mydriasis.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B, C, D:

  • These symptoms are associated with horner syndrome

questions.text: A 35-year-old female comes to the OPD for well-care visits. The patient is completely well and eats a balanced diet. She never smokes or drinks alcohol and has no significant past medical history. On examination, her vitals are normal. The patient tells the physician that next week she will go on a trip to an island and is worried about motion sickness. Which of the following drugs may be considered first-line therapy for this patient's prophylaxis of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Promethazine:

  • Promethazine is commonly used as a first-line therapy for prophylaxis of motion sickness. It belongs to a class of medications called antihistamines, which can help alleviate symptoms of motion sickness, such as nausea, vomiting, and dizziness.

  • Motion sickness arises from a mismatch between sensory inputs from the visual, vestibular, and proprioceptive systems, resulting in a mismatch in the brain's perception of motion and spatial orientation.

  • Histamine receptors play a pivotal role in modulating the body's response to motion stimuli. By antagonizing these receptors, antihistamines mitigate the neural signals responsible for triggering nausea and vomiting, thereby ameliorating symptoms of motion sickness.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a medication primarily used for the prevention and treatment of nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy or surgery. While it can be effective in managing nausea and vomiting, it is not typically considered a first-line therapy for motion sickness. Antihistamines like promethazine are generally preferred in this context.

Option C - Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a medication that helps to relieve symptoms of nausea and vomiting by increasing the movements or contractions of the stomach and intestines. While it can be effective in certain situations, it is not commonly used as a first-line therapy for motion sickness. Antihistamines, such as promethazine, are typically preferred due to their specific mechanism of action.

Option D - Domperidone: Domperidone is another medication used for the management of nausea and vomiting. It works by blocking dopamine receptors in the gut, which can help reduce the symptoms. However, similar to metoclopramide, it is not commonly used as a first-line therapy for motion sickness. Antihistamines are generally the preferred choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Defibrillation?

choices.text: Only be used by a trained person
Decrease in success rate with delay in initiation

questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • This option is incorrect. There is typically no fixed time interval between two defibrillation shocks. The decision to deliver subsequent shocks is based on the specific circumstances and the response of the patient. In some cases, it may be necessary to deliver multiple shocks in rapid succession, while in other cases, a pause may be required to assess the patient's response or to provide additional interventions.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Only be used by a trained person: This option is correct. Defibrillation is a medical procedure that involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to restore its normal rhythm. It is a complex procedure that typically requires training and certification. Using a defibrillator without proper training can be dangerous and potentially harmful.

Option B. Decrease in success rate with delay in initiation: This option is correct. Defibrillation is most effective when it is performed promptly after identifying a cardiac arrest. The longer the delay in initiating defibrillation, the lower the success rate becomes. Early defibrillation is crucial for improving the chances of survival in cardiac arrest cases.

Option C. Improve prognosis: This option is correct. Defibrillation is a critical intervention in cases of cardiac arrest caused by ventricular fibrillation (VF) or ventricular tachycardia (VT). Delivering an electric shock through defibrillation can restore a normal heart rhythm, which significantly improves the prognosis or outcome for the individual experiencing the cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Exenatide, a recently introduced medication, is employed for the treatment of diabetes mellitus. The drug's mode of action is characterized by:

choices.text: Release of insulin via acting as agonist of GLP-1 receptors

questions.solution:
Correct Option B

  • Exenatide is a medication used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It belongs to a class of drugs called incretin mimetics or glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists. The mechanism of action of exenatide involves acting as an agonist of GLP-1 receptors.
  • GLP-1 is a naturally occurring hormone that is released from the intestine in response to food intake. It plays a crucial role in regulating glucose metabolism. By acting as a GLP-1 receptor agonist, exenatide mimics the effects of GLP-1 and enhances its activity.
  • When exenatide binds to GLP-1 receptors, it stimulates the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells. Insulin helps to lower blood sugar levels by promoting the uptake of glucose into cells and reducing the production of glucose by the liver.
  • Additionally, exenatide suppresses the release of glucagon, which is a hormone that raises blood sugar levels. By inhibiting glucagon release, exenatide helps to further control blood glucose levels.

Incorrect Option:

Option A) Inhibition of DPP-4: Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors are another class of medications used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. These drugs work by inhibiting the enzyme DPP-4, which breaks down GLP-1 and other incretin hormones. However, exenatide is not a DPP-4 inhibitor.

Option C) Inhibiting intestinal absorption of carbohydrates: This mechanism of action is associated with medications called alpha-glucosidase inhibitors, such as acarbose and miglitol. These drugs work by inhibiting enzymes in the intestines that break down carbohydrates, thereby reducing the absorption of glucose. Exenatide does not act through this mechanism.

Option D) Stimulation of PPAR-gamma: Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-gamma) agonists, such as pioglitazone and rosiglitazone, are a class of medications used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. They work by activating PPAR-gamma receptors, which helps improve insulin sensitivity and reduce insulin resistance. Exenatide does not stimulate PPAR-gamma receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is the compound that prostaglandin, indicated for multiple conditions, is derived from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Prostaglandins are a class of lipid compounds that play diverse roles in the body, including regulating inflammation, blood flow, and various physiological processes. They are derived from a fatty acid called arachidonic acid, which is an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid.
  • Arachidonic acid is obtained from the diet and is also synthesized in the body from essential fatty acids. When the body needs prostaglandins, arachidonic acid is metabolized by enzymes called cyclooxygenases (COX) to produce prostaglandins.
  • These prostaglandins then act as local hormones, exerting their effects in the immediate vicinity of their synthesis. They are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including inflammation, pain signaling, blood vessel constriction and dilation, regulation of blood clotting, and control of gastrointestinal secretions.

Incorrect Option:

Option A) Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid found in various foods, including animal fats and chocolate. It is not directly involved in the synthesis of prostaglandins.

Option C) Linoleic acid: Linoleic acid is an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid that is also involved in the synthesis of various lipid compounds in the body. However, it is not the direct precursor of prostaglandins.

Option D) Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is an omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid, and while it is involved in the synthesis of other important lipid compounds in the body, it is not the precursor for prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: Which drug should not be administered to a pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D

  • Streptomycin is contraindicated in pregnant females due to its potential to cause harm to the developing fetus. Streptomycin is an antibiotic from the aminoglycoside class and has been associated with adverse effects on the fetal auditory and vestibular systems. It can cross the placenta and reach the developing fetus, potentially leading to hearing loss, balance problems, and other developmental abnormalities. Therefore, it is generally avoided during pregnancy unless the potential benefits outweigh the risks and no alternative treatment options are available.

Incorrect Option:

Option A) Erythromycin: Erythromycin is an antibiotic that is generally considered safe for use during pregnancy. It belongs to the macrolide class of antibiotics and has been widely used for the treatment of various infections in pregnant women without significant evidence of harm to the fetus.

Option B) Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a commonly used antibiotic from the penicillin class and is generally considered safe for use during pregnancy. It has a long history of use in pregnant women with bacterial infections and has not been associated with significant risks to the fetus.

Option C) Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic from the cephalosporin class. It is generally considered safe for use during pregnancy and is often prescribed for the treatment of various infections in pregnant women.

questions.text:
Mediastinal surface of the right lung is related to? 

A. The Azygos vein

B. The Right Lymphatic Duct

C. The Aorta

D. The Trachea
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A only:

  • The Azygos vein: The azygos vein is a major vein that drains blood from the posterior part of the thoracic wall into the superior vena cava. It does run along the mediastinal surface of the right lung, making option A correct.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lymphatic vessel that drains lymph from the upper right quadrant of the body.

Option C - While the aortais located in the mediastinum, it is positioned more towards the left side rather than the mediastinal surface of the right lung.

Option D - The trachea travels down the center of the thoracic cavity, behind the mediastinal surface of both lungs. Although it's close to the mediastinal surface of the right lung, it's not directly connected to it.

questions.text: Sternum is attached to scapula via?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Clavicle

  • Clavicle: The clavicle is a bone that connects the sternum (specifically the manubrium) to the scapula. It forms the acromioclavicular joint with the scapula, providing a direct attachment between the sternum and the scapula. This makes option B correct.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Manubrium: The manubrium is the top portion of the sternum and forms the sternoclavicular joint with the clavicle. However, it doesn't directly connect to the scapula.

Option C - First rib: The first rib, attaching to the sternum at the sternocostal joint, isn't directly involved in connecting the sternum to the scapula.

Option D - Second rib: The second rib, like the first rib, attaches to the sternum at the sternocostal joint, but it isn't directly linked to the scapula.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methyl dopa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

  • Methyldopa is an antihypertensive medication commonly used in the management of hypertension during pregnancy. Its mechanism of action involves agonism of alpha 2 adrenergic receptors. Methyldopa is converted in the body into methylnorepinephrine, which acts as a false neurotransmitter. Methylnorepinephrine stimulates alpha 2 receptors in the central nervous system (CNS), leading to a decrease in sympathetic outflow from the CNS. This ultimately results in reduced peripheral vascular resistance and lowered blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Blockade of beta adrenergic receptors: Methyldopa does not block beta adrenergic receptors. Beta blockers, on the other hand, are a separate class of antihypertensive medications that block beta adrenergic receptors to reduce blood pressure.

Option B) Agonism of beta 2 receptors: Methyldopa does not directly agonize beta 2 receptors. Agonists of beta 2 receptors, such as albuterol, are commonly used in the treatment of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Option D) Blockade of alpha 2 receptors: Methyldopa does not block alpha 2 receptors. Blocking alpha 2 receptors would result in increased sympathetic outflow and potentially raise blood pressure. Medications that block alpha receptors, like alpha blockers, are used for different therapeutic purposes, such as the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or alpha-adrenergic antagonist poisoning.

questions.text: Retraction of the scapula is primarily done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trapezius

  • Trapezius: The trapezius muscle is a large muscle that covers the upper back and neck. It plays a key role in the movement and stabilization of the scapula. The middle and lower fibers of the trapezius muscle primarily perform scapular retraction, which involves pulling the scapula backward toward the spine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serratus anterior: The serratus anterior muscle protracts and rotates the scapula, stabilizing it against the rib cage. However, it doesn't directly retract the scapula at the sternoclavicular joint.

Option C - Subscapularis: The subscapularis muscle, part of the rotator cuff, sits on the front of the scapula. It internally rotates the humerus and stabilizes the shoulder joint but doesn't aid in scapular retraction.

Option D - Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus muscle, part of the rotator cuff, is located on the back of the scapula. It helps initiate shoulder abduction but isn't mainly responsible for scapular retraction.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his mother with complaints of blurring of vision for one week. The patient further explains that he only has blurring of the far vision and has no problem in his near vision. The patient gives a history of no other abnormalities. For a detailed examination of the eye, the doctor uses a short-acting topical medication which also has a cycloplegic effect. Which of the following drug was used by the doctor in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tropicamide eye drops:

  • In this case, the doctor used a short-acting topical medication with cycloplegic effect for a detailed examination of the child's eyes. Tropicamide is a commonly used cycloplegic and mydriatic agent that is often employed in ophthalmology clinics for diagnostic purposes. Tropicamide eye drops cause temporary paralysis of the ciliary muscle of the eye, resulting in cycloplegia (loss of accommodation) and mydriasis (pupil dilation). These effects allow for a more accurate examination of the patient's refractive error and the posterior segment of the eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atropine oral: Atropine is a potent anticholinergic medication with cycloplegic and mydriatic effects. However, in this case, the doctor used a topical medication for examination, not an oral formulation.

Option B - Atropine eye ointment: Atropine eye ointment can be used as a topical cycloplegic agent, but it has a slower onset of action compared to eye drops. It is typically used for prolonged dilation and cycloplegia, such as in cases of uveitis or amblyopia treatment. In this case, where a detailed examination is needed, a short-acting eye drop would be more appropriate.

Option D - Phenylephrine eye drops: Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic medication that acts as a mydriatic (pupil dilation agent) by stimulating alpha-adrenergic receptors in the iris dilator muscle. While it can be used for pupillary dilation, it does not have cycloplegic effects. In this case, where cycloplegia is desired for a detailed examination, tropicamide eye drops would be a more suitable choice.

questions.text: What is the cause of scapular winging?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Serratus anterior:

  • Serratus anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is primarily responsible for stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall. When the serratus anterior muscle is paralyzed or weakened, it can lead to winging of the scapula. This muscle is especially important for maintaining proper scapular position during movements such as pushing, pulling, and reaching. Hence, option B is correct.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trapezius: The trapezius muscle stabilizes and moves the scapula, but its paralysis typically doesn't cause scapular winging.

Option C - Latissimus dorsi: The latissimus dorsi muscle assists in various shoulder movements but is typically not associated with scapular winging, even when weakened or paralyzed.

Option D - Pectoralis major: The pectoralis major muscle aids shoulder movements but usually doesn't cause scapular winging if paralyzed.

questions.text: Identify the marked bony process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Radial head:

  • Radial head: The radial head is a rounded bony structure located at the proximal end of the radius bone. It articulates with the capitulum of the humerus to form the radiocapitular joint, allowing rotational movements of the forearm. 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Capitulum: The capitulum is a bony prominence located on the distal end of the humerus. It articulates with the head of the radius to form the radio capitular joint.

Option B - Olecranon: The olecranon is a bony process located at the proximal end of the ulna, forming the prominent bony tip of the elbow. It serves as the insertion point for the triceps brachii muscle.

Option C - Trochlea: The trochlea is a structure located on the distal end of the humerus and plays a crucial role in the formation of the elbow joint. It articulates with the trochlear notch of the ulna, allowing flexion and extension movements of the forearm.

questions.text: During embryological development, the midgut undergoes rotation. In a 6-month-old infant presenting with bilious emesis, it is discovered that the cecum is fixed in the right upper quadrant due to peritoneal bands, leading to a diagnosis of intestinal malrotation. Which of the following statements accurately describes the midgut rotation during embryological development?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • During normal embryological development, the midgut rotates 270 degrees anticlockwise (counterclockwise) around the axis of the superior mesenteric artery.
  • This rotation occurs in three stages: 90 degrees during herniation into the umbilical cord, an additional 180 degrees during retraction back into the abdominal cavity.
  • This process positions the cecum in the lower right quadrant of the abdomen and the small intestines in a way that avoids complications such as malrotation.

Incorrect options:

Option A: 270-degree clockwise: This option suggests a clockwise rotation of 270 degrees. However, the midgut rotation occurs in a counterclockwise direction rather than clockwise. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option C: 360-degree clockwise: This option suggests a clockwise rotation of 360 degrees. However, the midgut rotation does not involve a full 360-degree rotation in either direction. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D: 360-degree anticlockwise: This option implies a counterclockwise rotation of 360 degrees. While the counterclockwise rotation is correct, the midgut rotation does not involve a full 360-degree rotation. Hence, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: In relation to the anatomy of vasa brevia, a senior surgeon asks a first-year surgery resident a question that suggests vasa brevia is another term for which artery runs through the gastrosplenic ligament. This scenario is based on a research article published about the branches and course of vasa brevia.
questions.solution:
Correct option: B

  • Short gastric arteries: The short gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus and upper part of the greater curvature of the stomach. They pass through the gastrosplenic ligament, which is a fold of the peritoneum connecting the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Long gastric arteries: The long gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus and upper part of the greater curvature of the stomach. However, they do not pass through the gastrosplenic ligament.

Option C: Ileal vasa recta: The ileal vasa recta are small arteries that arise from the superior mesenteric artery and supply the terminal part of the ileum in the small intestine. They are not associated with the gastrosplenic ligament.

Option D: Jejunal vasa recta: The jejunal vasa recta are small arteries that arise from the superior mesenteric artery and supply the jejunum in the small intestine. Similar to the ileal vasa recta, they are not related to the gastrosplenic ligament.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery originating from celiac trunk territory?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Gastroepiploic artery: The gastroepiploic artery, also known as the gastro-omental artery, is a branch of the celiac trunk territory. It arises from the splenic artery, which is one of the main branches of the celiac trunk. The gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach and supplies blood to the stomach and the greater omentum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Splenic artery: The splenic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk, but it does not originate from the celiac trunk territory. Instead, it arises directly from the celiac trunk itself.

Option C: Gastroduodenal artery: The gastroduodenal artery is another branch of the celiac trunk, but it does not originate from the celiac trunk territory. It arises directly from the common hepatic artery, which is a separate branch of the celiac trunk.

Option D: Left gastric artery: The left gastric artery is also a branch of the celiac trunk, but it does not originate from the celiac trunk territory. It arises directly from the common hepatic artery, just before it gives rise to the proper hepatic artery.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments is another name for the lienorenal ligament derived from the peritoneum, where the tail of the pancreas is located in a healthy adult female?
questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • Spleno-renal: The lienorenal ligament, also known as the splenorenal ligament, is a double-layered fold of peritoneum that connects the spleen to the posterior abdominal wall and the left kidney. It plays a crucial role in supporting and positioning the spleen within the abdominal cavity.

  • Functions:

    • Splenorenal Support: The primary function of the lienorenal ligament is to support the spleen in its anatomical position. The spleen is a relatively mobile organ, and the lienorenal ligament helps anchor it to the posterior abdominal wall and the left kidney, preventing excessive movement and rotation. This support ensures that the spleen remains in its usual location in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.

    • Vascular and Neural Contents: Within the lienorenal ligament, you can find several important structures:

      • Splenic Artery and Vein: The lienorenal ligament contains the splenic artery and vein, which are the main blood vessels supplying and draining the spleen.
      • Lymphatics: Lymphatic vessels from the spleen also pass through the lienorenal ligament.
      • Autonomic Nerves: Nerve fibers related to the autonomic nervous system may also pass through this ligament.

    • Potential Pathway for Disease Spread: Due to its connections with the spleen, stomach, and surrounding structures, the lienorenal ligament can serve as a pathway for the spread of disease or infections between these organs.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Hapato-gastric: The hepatogastric ligament, also known as the lesser omentum, connects the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach

Option B: Hepato-duodenal: The hepatoduodenal ligament, also known as the lesser omentum, connects the liver to the duodenum. Like the hepatogastric ligament, it does not include the tail of the pancreas.

Option C: Gastro-splenic: The gastro-splenic ligament, also known as the lienorenal ligament, is the correct ligament in question. It is derived from the peritoneum and connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The tail of the pancreas lies within this ligament

questions.text: Bleeding vessel in hemorrhoids is?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Superior rectal vein: Hemorrhoids are swollen and inflamed blood vessels in the rectum and anus. The bleeding associated with hemorrhoids usually occurs from the engorged veins. The superior rectal vein, which drains blood from the rectum, is often involved in hemorrhoidal bleeding. Thus, the superior rectal vein (option B) is the correct answer.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is responsible for supplying arterial blood to the rectum. However, in the context of hemorrhoids, the bleeding vessel is typically a vein rather than an artery. Therefore, the superior rectal artery (option A) is not the correct answer.

Option C: Middle rectal artery: The middle rectal artery is responsible for supplying blood to the middle portion of the rectum. While it plays a role in rectal blood supply, it is not typically associated with bleeding in hemorrhoids. Therefore, the middle rectal artery (option C) is not the correct choice.

Option D; Middle rectal vein: The middle rectal vein drains blood from the middle portion of the rectum. Similar to the middle rectal artery, it is not directly associated with hemorrhoidal bleeding. Hence, the middle rectal vein (option D) is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Foot eversion is caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct option: B 

  • Peroneus longus: The peroneus longus muscle, also known as the fibularis longus muscle, is located on the lateral side of the leg. It plays a significant role in foot eversion. When the peroneus longus contracts, it pulls the foot outward, causing eversion.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Extensor digitorum: The extensor digitorum muscle is located on the anterior aspect of the leg and primarily functions to extend the digits (toes) and dorsiflex the foot. It is not directly involved in foot eversion.

Option C: Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior muscle is located on the anterior aspect of the leg. Its primary action is dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. It is not directly involved in foot eversion.

Option D: Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior muscle is located on the posterior aspect of the leg. Its primary action is plantarflexion and inversion of the foot. It works in the opposite direction of foot eversion.

questions.text: Which muscle is supplied by the both tibial and common peroneal nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Biceps femoris: The biceps femoris muscle is innervated by the tibial and common peroneal nerves. The tibial nerve supplies the long head of the biceps femoris, while the common peroneal nerve supplies the short head. Therefore, the tibial and common peroneal nerves do supply the biceps femoris muscle

Incorrect options:

Option A: Gracilis: The gracilis muscle is primarily innervated by the obturator nerve, not the tibial or common peroneal nerve. Therefore, the tibial and common peroneal nerves do not supply the gracilis muscle

Option C: Adductor longus: The adductor longus muscle is primarily innervated by the obturator nerve, not the tibial or common peroneal nerve. Thus, the tibial and common peroneal nerves do not supply the adductor longus muscle.

Option D: Adductor magnus: The adductor magnus muscle is primarily innervated by the obturator and sciatic nerves. The sciatic nerve, which is composed of the tibial and common peroneal nerves, supplies the posterior part of the adductor magnus. However, the tibial and common peroneal nerves alone do not supply the adductor magnus muscle.

questions.text: Pilocarpine produces:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Active miosis:

  • Pilocarpine is a cholinergic agonist that acts on the muscarinic receptors in the eye. When applied topically to the eye, pilocarpine causes the contraction of the iris sphincter muscle, leading to active miosis, which is the constriction of the pupil.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Active mydriasis: Mydriasis refers to the dilation of the pupil. Pilocarpine actually has the opposite effect of mydriasis. It causes miosis, not mydriasis.

Option C - Passive miosis: The term "passive miosis" is not commonly used in medical terminology. Miosis itself refers to the constriction of the pupil, which can be actively induced by pilocarpine.

Option D - Passive mydriasis: Similar to option B, "passive mydriasis" is not a recognized term in medical practice. Mydriasis refers to the dilation of the pupil, which is not produced by pilocarpine.

questions.text: Which drug directly inhibits clotting factor Xa among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Apixaban:

  • Apixaban is a direct inhibitor of clotting factor Xa. It belongs to a class of medications known as direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) or non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs). Apixaban specifically inhibits factor Xa, which is a crucial enzyme involved in the coagulation cascade. By inhibiting factor Xa, apixaban prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent blood clot formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Argatroban: Argatroban is a direct thrombin inhibitor, not a direct inhibitor of clotting factor Xa. It acts by directly inhibiting thrombin, another key enzyme involved in the coagulation pathway.

Option C - Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is an indirect inhibitor of clotting factor Xa. It selectively binds to antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits factor Xa. Although it indirectly inhibits factor Xa, it does not directly inhibit the enzyme itself.

Option D - Aspirin: Aspirin is not a direct inhibitor of clotting factor Xa. It belongs to the class of medications known as antiplatelet drugs. Aspirin exerts its antiplatelet effects by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes, leading to decreased synthesis of thromboxane A2, a potent platelet aggregator.

questions.text: Which drug from the options provided is known as a protein synthesis inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Linezolide:

  • Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor. It belongs to a class of antibiotics known as oxazolidinones. Linezolid works by binding to the bacterial 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit, which prevents the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex. This ultimately inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nevirapine: Nevirapine is an antiretroviral medication used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It belongs to the class of drugs called non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs). Nevirapine inhibits the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is necessary for the replication of the HIV virus, but it does not directly inhibit protein synthesis.

Option C - Indinavir: Indinavir is an antiretroviral medication used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It belongs to the class of drugs called protease inhibitors. Indinavir works by inhibiting the protease enzyme, which is required for the replication of the HIV virus, but it does not directly inhibit protein synthesis.

Option D - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic belonging to the class of drugs called cephalosporins. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, leading to bacterial cell lysis. Ceftriaxone does not directly inhibit protein synthesis.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for preventing meningococcal meningitis in a pregnant woman following exposure to a confirmed case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  •  Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis in a pregnant female after contact with a case. Meningococcal meningitis is a severe bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis. It can be transmitted through respiratory droplets and close contact with an infected individual.
  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that has excellent activity against Neisseria meningitidis. It is highly effective in eradicating the bacteria from the nasopharynx, thus preventing the development of meningitis in individuals who have been exposed to the bacterium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that has activity against Neisseria meningitidis. However, it is generally not recommended for prophylaxis in pregnant females due to potential adverse effects on the fetus, such as cartilage development issues.

Option C) Cephalexin: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that has limited activity against Neisseria meningitidis. It is not the drug of choice for prophylaxis in this situation.

Option D) Rifabutin: Rifabutin is an antibiotic primarily used in the treatment of tuberculosis and certain Mycobacterium avium complex infections. It does not provide adequate coverage against Neisseria meningitidis and is not indicated for prophylaxis in this case.

questions.text: Purpose of adding zinc to insulin in commercial preparations for treatment of diabetes mellitus is:

choices.text: Addition of zinc make the insulin effective orally

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - To make it long acting: 

  • The purpose of adding zinc to insulin in commercial preparations for the treatment of diabetes mellitus is to make it long acting. Insulin is a hormone that regulates blood sugar levels, and its action can be modified by adding certain substances. Zinc is one such substance that can be added to insulin to prolong its duration of action.

  • When zinc is added to insulin, it forms crystals that delay the absorption of insulin from the injection site into the bloodstream. This delayed absorption results in a slower and more prolonged release of insulin, leading to a long-acting effect. Long-acting insulin formulations are used to provide a steady basal level of insulin throughout the day, mimicking the body's natural insulin secretion patterns.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - To make it short acting: Adding zinc to insulin does not make it short acting. Instead, it has the opposite effect of prolonging its duration of action.

Option C - To make it fast acting: Adding zinc to insulin does not make it fast acting. Fast-acting insulins, such as rapid-acting or short-acting insulins, are formulated differently to provide a rapid onset of action and shorter duration.

Option D - Addition of zinc makes the insulin effective orally: Adding zinc to insulin does not make it effective when taken orally. Insulin cannot be taken orally as it is broken down by digestive enzymes in the gastrointestinal tract. Insulin must be administered via subcutaneous injection or other suitable routes to be effective.

questions.text: During the surgery of a 40-year-old patient, anesthesia is administered along with other agents to enhance the effects of anesthesia and minimize any negative consequences. Which of the options below refers to the muscle relaxant with the shortest duration of action and is commonly used for rapid sequence induction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Succinylcholine is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant and is commonly used for rapid sequence induction during anesthesia. It is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent that acts by binding to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the motor endplate of the neuromuscular junction, resulting in temporary paralysis of skeletal muscles.
  • The rapid onset and short duration of action of succinylcholine make it suitable for rapid sequence induction. Rapid sequence induction is a technique used to quickly and efficiently induce anesthesia while minimizing the risk of aspiration of stomach contents. It involves administering a rapid-acting muscle relaxant like succinylcholine to achieve muscle relaxation and facilitate endotracheal intubation.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A) Tubocurarine: Tubocurarine is a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent with a relatively long duration of action. It is not suitable for rapid sequence induction due to its slow onset and prolonged effects.

Option C) Pancuronium: Pancuronium is a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent with an intermediate duration of action. It is not as short-acting as succinylcholine and is not typically used for rapid sequence induction.

Option D) Atracurium: Atracurium is another nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent, but it has an intermediate duration of action. It is not as short-acting as succinylcholine and is not typically used for rapid sequence induction.

questions.text: Which medication is known to induce orthostatic (postural) hypotension and may lead to potentially severe blood pressure drops when patients transition from sitting or lying down to a standing position, potentially causing dizziness, lightheadedness, or even fainting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Prazosin:

  •  Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker that is commonly used to treat hypertension. However, it can also cause postural hypotension, which is a drop in blood pressure upon standing up from a sitting or lying position. This can lead to dizziness, lightheadedness, and an increased risk of falls, particularly in elderly patients who may already have compromised balance and coordination.

  • Prazosin works by blocking the alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, which results in vasodilation and relaxation of smooth muscles in blood vessels, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. However, this vasodilatory effect can cause a sudden drop in blood pressure when changing positions, especially from lying down to standing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Metformin: Metformin is an antidiabetic medication that does not typically cause postural hypotension. Its primary action is to decrease glucose production in the liver and increase insulin sensitivity, making it a commonly used medication for the management of type 2 diabetes.

Option C - Acarbose: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. It does not have a direct effect on blood pressure and is not associated with postural hypotension.

Option D - Nor-adrenaline: Nor-adrenaline (norepinephrine) is a naturally occurring neurotransmitter and hormone that acts as a vasoconstrictor. It is not typically associated with postural hypotension. In fact, it can increase blood pressure by constricting blood vessels.

questions.text: What is the recommended medication for treating a 23-year-old female who is experiencing burning pain while urinating and has been diagnosed with a co-infection of chlamydia and gonococcus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A. 

  • In the case of co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the drug of choice for treatment is Azithromycin. Azithromycin is an antibiotic that is effective against both Chlamydia and Gonococcus. It is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis, leading to the eradication of the bacteria causing the infection.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is primarily used for the treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. While it is effective against Gonococcus, it is not sufficient to treat Chlamydia. Therefore, it is important to use a combination therapy with Azithromycin to cover both organisms in cases of co-infection.

Option C. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections. It is not effective against bacterial infections like Chlamydia and Gonococcus.

Option D. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an antibiotic primarily used for treating anaerobic bacterial infections. It is not the drug of choice for treating Chlamydia and Gonococcus.

questions.text: Which drug can be administered in the next cycle of chemotherapy to prevent neutropenia in a patient who has received anti-cancer therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that can be used to prevent neutropenia in patients undergoing chemotherapy. Neutropenia is a condition characterized by a low level of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in fighting off infections. Chemotherapy drugs can suppress the production of neutrophils, leading to an increased risk of infections.
  • Filgrastim works by stimulating the production of neutrophils in the bone marrow, helping to prevent or reduce the severity and duration of neutropenia. By increasing the neutrophil count, it enhances the patient's ability to fight off infections.

Incorrect Options :

Option B. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that has anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. While it may be used in certain cases to manage inflammation or immune-related complications, it is not specifically indicated for the prevention of neutropenia.

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that plays a role in the production of red blood cells and the maintenance of nerve cells. While it is essential for overall health, it does not have a direct effect on preventing neutropenia.

Option D. Folic acid: Folic acid is a B-vitamin that is important for the synthesis and repair of DNA and red blood cell production. Similar to vitamin B12, it does not have a direct effect on preventing neutropenia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old presents with complaints of chest and difficulty in swallowing. Based on the findings in the below image, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diffuse oesophageal spasm:

  • Diffuse oesophageal spasm is a motility disorder characterized by uncoordinated contractions of the muscles in the esophagus. This condition leads to difficulties in swallowing, chest pain, and sometimes regurgitation.
  • The X-ray image provided shows the characteristic findings associated with Diffuse Oesophageal Spasm, which include multiple contractions along the length of the esophagus, often referred to as "corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Achalasia cardia: The X-ray image does not display the typical findings associated with Achalasia cardia, such as a dilated esophagus or absent peristalsis. Therefore, the image does not support the diagnosis of Achalasia cardia.

Option C - Carcinoma Oesophagus spasm: The X-ray image does not provide any evidence of a tumor or cancerous growth, which is a characteristic feature of Carcinoma Oesophagus spasm. Therefore, the image does not support the diagnosis of Carcinoma Oesophagus spasm.

Option D - Schatzki's Ring: The X-ray image does not show any evidence of a narrowing or ring-like structure in the esophagus, which is characteristic of Schatzki's Ring. Thus, the image does not support the diagnosis of Schatzki's Ring.

questions.text: Which of the following actions is not typically performed in cases of Carcinoma of the Oesophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • pH-metry: pH-metry is not typically performed for the evaluation of Carcinoma Oesophagus. pH-metry is a test used to measure the pH levels in the esophagus to evaluate for conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or esophageal motility disorders. It is not specific to Carcinoma Oesophagus.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Biopsy: A biopsy is typically performed to obtain a tissue sample from the suspected area of carcinoma in the esophagus. The tissue sample is then examined under a microscope to confirm the diagnosis and determine the histological type and grade of the cancer.

Option C. CT chest: A CT (computed tomography) scan of the chest is commonly performed to evaluate the extent and stage of Carcinoma Oesophagus. It helps visualize the size and location of the tumor, as well as any spread to nearby lymph nodes or distant organs.

Option D. PET scan: A PET (positron emission tomography) scan is often used to detect the spread of Carcinoma Oesophagus beyond the primary tumor site. It can help identify metastases to distant organs or lymph nodes by detecting areas of increased metabolic activity.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are true about Allergic Broncho Pulmonary Aspergillosis?


	Distal bronchiectasis
	Serum precipitins to Aspergillus
	Increased lgE Levels
	Seen in asthmatics
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2,3,4 only:

  • Distal bronchiectasis: This feature is not typically associated with Allergic Broncho Pulmonary Aspergilloma (ABPA). Distal bronchiectasis is more commonly seen in other conditions such as cystic fibrosis. In ABPA, Central Bronchiectasis is seen.
  • Serum precipitins to Aspergillus: This is a characteristic feature of ABPA. Individuals with ABPA often have detectable serum precipitins (specific antibodies) against Aspergillus.
  • Increased IgE levels: ABPA is characterized by an elevated level of IgE (immunoglobulin E) in the blood. This is a result of the allergic response to Aspergillus antigens.
  • Seen in asthmatics: ABPA is frequently associated with asthma. It is estimated that about 10% of individuals with asthma may develop ABPA.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the accurate description of marble Schonberg disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteopetrosis:

  • Osteopetrosis (Marble Bone/Albers Schonberg disease): In osteopetrosis there is a defect in the normal process of bone resorption, resulting in excessive accumulation of dense, brittle bone tissue. This leads to increased bone density and reduced bone marrow space. The term "marble bone" refers to the appearance of the bones on imaging studies, which appear dense and resemble marble. Osteopetrosis can be inherited as an autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant condition and can manifest with various symptoms such as fractures, anemia, and impaired vision or hearing.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Why is COVID-19 a major global concern despite influenza spreading faster than COVID-19?

choices.text: Median incubation period is more in influenza
Serial interval is 5-6 days in influenza
Reproductive number for Influenza is higher

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Reproductive number for COVID-19 is 2-2.5:

  • The reproductive number (R0) represents the average number of people that an infected individual will infect. The estimated R0 for COVID-19 is around 2-2.5, which means that each infected person, on average, can transmit the virus to 2-2.5 others. This indicates the potential for sustained transmission and makes COVID-19 highly contagious.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Median incubation period is more in influenza: The median incubation period of COVID-19 is generally longer compared to influenza. Influenza typically has a shorter incubation period, ranging from 1-4 days, while COVID-19 has a median incubation period of around 5-6 days.

Option C - Serial interval is 5-6 days in influenza: The serial interval refers to the time between the onset of symptoms in one infected individual and the onset of symptoms in the secondary infected individual. Influenza typically has a shorter serial interval, usually around 2-3 days, indicating a relatively rapid spread of the virus from person to person.

Option D - Reproductive number for Influenza is more: The reproductive number for influenza is generally lower compared to COVID-19. While the exact R0 for different influenza strains can vary, it is typically lower than the estimated R0 for COVID-19. This means that COVID-19 has a higher potential for transmission within a susceptible population compared to influenza.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with complains of Mental retardation, mousy odur and hypopigmentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phenylketonuria:

  • Phenylketonuria is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in phenylalanine metabolism leading to accumulation of phenyl ketones.
  • Clinical features
    • Mental retardation- Due to phenyl ketones crossing BBB.
    • Mousy odor- Due to accumulation of phenylacetate
    • Hypopigmentation- Due to decreased synthesis of melanin

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which can cause dark urine, darkening of connective tissues, and joint problems.

Options C - Albinism: Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Options D - MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine Disease): MSUD is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the inability to break down certain amino acids, including leucine, isoleucine, and valine. If left untreated, it can lead to severe neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient comes to the OPD with complains tingling sensation in the hands and feet. Reversible dementia is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - SACD:

  • Subacute Combined Degeneration (SACD) is a neurological condition characterized by the degeneration of the spinal cord, peripheral nerves, and sometimes the brain primarily due to Vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Clinical features include reversible dementia, paresthesias in hand and feet, loss of vibration and position sensation.
  • Treatment includes 1000 microgram of Vitamin B12 IM.

Incorrect options:

Option B - AD (Alzheimer's Disease): Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by irreversible memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes.

Option C - CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease): Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease leads to rapid neurological decline, including dementia, and unfortunately, it is a fatal condition. CJD is not reversible.

Option D - Pick's Disease: Pick's disease, also known as frontotemporal dementia, leads to progressive cognitive decline, personality changes, and behavioral disturbances.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is NOT accurate regarding Parkinson's disease?

choices.text: Usage of Carbidopa leads to on and off phenomenon
Slight tremor in the hand or foot followed by jaw
Cog wheel rigidity or lead pipe rigidity is seen

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Usage of Carbidopa leads to on and off phenomenon:

  • The "on and off phenomenon" refers to fluctuations in motor response, where individuals with Parkinson's disease experience periods of improved motor function (on) followed by periods of reduced or absent response to medication (off).
  • This phenomenon is more commonly associated with fluctuations in the effectiveness of levodopa itself, rather than carbidopa.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Manganese can cause secondary Parkinsonism: Exposure to high levels of manganese, such as through occupational or environmental sources, can lead to a form of parkinsonism known as manganism.

Option C - Slight tremor in the hand or foot followed by jaw: One of the cardinal symptoms of Parkinson's disease is a resting tremor, typically starting in the hand or foot. The tremor can progress to involve other body parts, including the jaw.

Option D - Cogwheel rigidity or lead pipe rigidity is seen: Rigidity is a characteristic feature of Parkinson's disease. Cogwheel rigidity refers to a jerky resistance to passive movement characterized by a series of brief interruptions, while lead pipe rigidity refers to a continuous resistance throughout the range of movement.

questions.text: The patient being discussed has come in for medical evaluation following an injury to the chest. During the examination, the presence of crepitus is detected. Based on these findings, what is the likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subcutaneous emphysema:

  • Chest Trauma: The patient has presented after chest trauma, indicating that there has been an injury to the chest area. Chest trauma can cause various injuries, including damage to the respiratory structures.
  • Crepitus refers to the sensation of crackling or crunching felt under the skin. It occurs when air or gas escapes from the damaged respiratory or gastrointestinal tract and dissects through the subcutaneous tissues. The presence of crepitus is a characteristic finding in subcutaneous emphysema.
  • The description of the image-based question mentioning the face of the man showing edema is not directly related to the diagnosis of subcutaneous emphysema. Edema refers to the swelling caused by an accumulation of fluid in the tissues, and it can have various causes. However, it is not a specific feature of subcutaneous emphysema.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gas gangrene: Gas gangrene is a severe and potentially life-threatening infection caused by certain bacteria, such as Clostridium species. It is characterized by the rapid spread of infection, tissue destruction, and gas production within the affected tissues. Gas gangrene is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus, so it is an incorrect option in this case.

Option C - Acute tubular necrosis: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is a type of kidney injury that can occur due to various causes, such as ischemia, toxins, or infections. It involves damage to the renal tubules, leading to impaired kidney function. ATN is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus, so it is an incorrect option in this scenario.

Option D - Hyperbaric decompression sickness: Hyperbaric decompression sickness, commonly known as "the bends," is a condition that can occur in scuba divers when they ascend too quickly, leading to the formation of gas bubbles in the bloodstream. It primarily affects divers and is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus. Therefore, it is an incorrect option in this context.

questions.text: A 40-year-old was brought to the emergency with complians of severe abdominal pain with tenderness, fever with chills, and tachycardia. What is the most likely diagnosis for the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumoperitoneum:

  • The correct diagnosis based on the given description and the X-ray image showing air under the diaphragm is pneumoperitoneum.
  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, which is the space between the abdominal organs and the abdominal wall. It is commonly caused by perforation or rupture of a hollow organ in the abdomen, such as the stomach, intestine, or appendix. The presence of air under the diaphragm on an X-ray image is a classic finding seen in pneumoperitoneum.
  •  

Incorrect options:

Option A - Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air or gas in the pleural cavity, which is the space between the lung and the chest wall. It typically appears as air surrounding the lung tissue on an X-ray image.

Option C - Eventration of diaphragm: Eventration of the diaphragm is a condition in which the diaphragm muscle is abnormally thin or weak, leading to an elevated and dome-shaped appearance. It does not involve the presence of air under the diaphragm.

Option D - Pneumomediastinum: Pneumomediastinum refers to the presence of air or gas in the mediastinum, which is the central region of the chest between the lungs. It can be caused by various factors, including trauma or medical conditions.

questions.text:
Mark the true statements?

1. MEN 2B is also known as Sipple syndrome

2. MEN 1 is also known as Wermer syndrome

3. MEN 2B is characterized by the presence of Marfanoid Habitus.

4. MEN 4 is a/w CDKN1B
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3 and 4 are true:

  • MEN 1 is also known as Wermer syndrome: This statement is TRUE. MEN-1 or Wermer syndrome is caused by defect in chromosome 11q13. premature aging.
  • Marfanoid Habitus is a feature of MEN 2B: This statement is true. Marfanoid habitus, which refers to the skeletal features similar to Marfan syndrome, is commonly seen in individuals with MEN 2B.
  • MEN 4 is associated with CDKN1B: This statement is true. MEN 4 is a rare form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is associated with mutations in the CDKN1B gene.

Incorrect options

Option A, C, and D

  1. MEN 2B is also known as Sipple syndrome: This statement is false. MEN 2B is not known as Sipple syndrome. Sipple syndrome is associated with multiple endocrine adenomatosis type 2A (MEN 2A).

questions.text: Which of the following options has the lowest concentration in intracellular fluid (ICF)compared to extracellular fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Calcium:

  • Calcium is present in the least concentration in intracellular fluid (ICF). Inside the cell, calcium ions are tightly regulated to maintain proper cellular function.
  • The intracellular concentration of calcium is relatively low (0.0001 mEq/L) compared to the concentration in extracellular fluid..

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Their concentration is relatively higher in intracellular fluid compared to extracellular fluid.

questions.text: In good pasture syndrome, which organ is involved apart from lung?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kidney:

  • Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that target the basement membrane in the lungs and kidneys. These autoantibodies primarily bind to the type IV collagen present in the alveolar basement membrane of the lungs and the glomerular basement membrane of the kidneys.
  • The binding of autoantibodies to the glomerular basement membrane in the kidneys leads to the activation of an immune response and subsequent inflammation. This inflammatory response can cause damage to the kidney tissue and impair its function.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the opposition to passive stretching?
questions.solution:
Correct option:  B. Spasticity

  • Explanation: Spasticity is characterized by increased muscle tone that is velocity-dependent, meaning the resistance to passive movement increases with higher speed or sudden stretching. This directly describes the opposition to passive stretching, as spastic muscles resist being stretched quickly.

Incorrect option: 

Option A. Tone

  • Explanation: Tone refers to the general tension or resistance in a muscle at rest. It can be increased (hypertonic) or decreased (hypotonic) depending on the condition. Tone itself does not specifically describe the opposition to passive stretching but rather the overall state of muscle tension.

Option C. Rigidity:

  • Rigidity involves increased resistance to passive movement that is independent of velocity. It is a constant, uniform resistance and is not specifically related to the speed or force of stretching, thus not accurately describing opposition to passive stretching.

Option D. Paratonia:

  • Paratonia is characterized by variable resistance to passive movement, which fluctuates between increased and decreased muscle tone. It involves an impaired ability to modulate muscle tone but does not specifically refer to opposition to passive stretching in a consistent manner.

questions.text: Enterokinase is an activator of?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A

  • Enterokinase, also known as enteropeptidase, is an enzyme produced in the duodenum of the small intestine. Its primary role is to activate trypsinogen, which is an inactive precursor of trypsin. Trypsinogen is synthesized and released by the pancreas.
  • Enterokinase acts on trypsinogen, cleaving it at a specific site to generate active trypsin. Once trypsin is formed, it can then further activate other pancreatic zymogens, such as chymotrypsinogen and procarboxypeptidase, initiating the digestive process.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Trypsin: Trypsin is not activated by enterokinase. Instead, enterokinase is responsible for the activation of trypsinogen to form trypsin. Once trypsin is formed, it can activate other pancreatic zymogens and participate in the digestion of proteins.

Option C. Chymotrypsin: Enterokinase does not directly activate chymotrypsin. Chymotrypsinogen, the inactive precursor of chymotrypsin, is activated by trypsin.
