Trypsin cleaves chymotrypsinogen to generate active chymotrypsin. Therefore, the activation of chymotrypsinogen is dependent on the presence of trypsin, not enterokinase.

Option D. Antitrypsin: Antitrypsin, also known as alpha-1 antitrypsin, is a protein that functions as an inhibitor of proteases, including trypsin. It is not activated by enterokinase. Instead, antitrypsin acts to regulate and inhibit the activity of trypsin and other proteases to prevent excessive tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of child pugh classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - SGOT:

  • Child-Pugh classification is a scoring system used to assess the severity of liver disease and to predict the prognosis in patients with chronic liver disease, particularly cirrhosis.
  • SGOT (serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase) or AST (aspartate aminotransferase) is not included in the Child-Pugh classification. 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are components of Child Pugh classification.

questions.text: What is the connecting structure between Broca's area and Wernicke's area?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A

  • The arcuate fasciculus is a white matter tract that connects two important language areas of the brain: Broca's area and Wernicke's area. Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals), is involved in the production of speech and language expression. Wernicke's area, located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus, is involved in language comprehension.
  • The arcuate fasciculus serves as a major pathway for communication between these two language areas. It allows for the coordination of language production and comprehension. Damage or disruption to the arcuate fasciculus can result in language deficits, such as conduction aphasia, where there is difficulty repeating words or phrases.

questions.text: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Fulminant diabetes mellitus refers to a rapid and severe onset of diabetes symptoms and complications. Coxsackie B virus, a type of enterovirus, has been associated with the development of fulminant diabetes mellitus. The virus can cause damage to the pancreatic beta cells, leading to a sudden and complete loss of insulin production.

Incorrect options:

Options A: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): While DKA is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by high blood sugar, ketone production, and metabolic acidosis, it is not specifically associated with a rapid and severe onset like fulminant diabetes.

Options C: Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma: Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma is a life-threatening complication of diabetes characterized by extremely high blood sugar and severe dehydration. It is not typically associated with a rapid and sudden onset like fulminant diabetes.

Options D: Autoimmune pancreatitis: Autoimmune pancreatitis is a rare form of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction. It is not typically associated with a rapid and severe onset of diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a calcium-binding protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Clathrin:

  • Clathrin is not a calcium-binding protein. It is a structural protein that plays a crucial role in the formation of coated vesicles during endocytosis, a process by which cells internalize molecules from the extracellular environment. Clathrin helps shape the vesicles by assembling them into a lattice-like structure around the invaginated membrane.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Calbindin: Calbindin is a calcium-binding protein that regulates calcium homeostasis in cells. It is found in various tissues, including the brain, kidney, and intestines, and helps buffer and transport calcium ions.

Option B - Calmodulin: Calmodulin is a highly conserved calcium-binding protein found in The smooth muscle cell.

Option C - Troponin: Troponin is a complex of three subunits (troponin C, troponin I, and troponin T) found in skeletal muscle cells and is a calcium binding protein.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 6-year-old patient who presents with a mild fever persisting for 7 days, enlarged cervical lymph nodes, and a palpable spleen tip, and subsequently develops a widespread rash after administration of ampicillin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Infectious mononucleosis:

  • The clinical presentation described is consistent with infectious mononucleosis, also known as glandular fever. It is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The symptoms include fever, lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes), hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), and a characteristic rash that can occur after the administration of certain antibiotics like ampicillin.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Histamine is secreted by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Enterochromaffin cell:

  • Histamine is primarily secreted by enterochromaffin cells, which are a type of neuroendocrine cells found in the gastrointestinal tract. These cells release histamine in response to gastrin and acetylcholine.
  • Histamine has diverse physiological functions and plays a significant role in various processes in the body. In the gastrointestinal tract, histamine acts as a paracrine and neurotransmitter molecule. It can stimulate gastric acid secretion, increase blood flow to the gastric mucosa, and regulate smooth muscle contraction in the gut.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Parietal cell: Parietal cells are responsible for producing and secreting gastric acid (hydrochloric acid) in the stomach.

Option C - Oxyntic cell: Oxyntic cells, or parietal cells, are another name for the cells that produce gastric acid.

Option D - Chief cell: Chief cells are responsible for secreting pepsinogen, the inactive precursor of the enzyme pepsin, which is involved in protein digestion.

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding rheumatoid nodules?

choices.text: Tender, located on extensor surface and seen with arthritis
Non tender, located on extensor surface and seen with arthritis
Non tender, located on flexor surface and seen with arthritis
Tender, located on flexor surface and seen with arthritis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Non tender, located on extensor surface and seen with arthritis:

  • Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous nodules characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis. They are usually painless (non-tender) and are typically found over bony prominences, especially on the extensor surfaces of joints, such as the elbows. Rheumatoid nodules result from the accumulation of inflammatory cells and fibrous tissue and are a specific clinical manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Reward centre in the brain is?
questions.solution:
Correct option. D

  • The reward center in the brain is primarily associated with the ventral tegmental area (VTA). The VTA is a region located in the midbrain, specifically in the mesolimbic pathway. It is known for its role in the brain's reward system, which is involved in the experience of pleasure, motivation, and reinforcement of certain behaviors.
  • The VTA contains dopamine-producing neurons that project to various regions of the brain, including the nucleus accumbens, prefrontal cortex, and amygdala. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter closely associated with reward and pleasure. When the VTA neurons release dopamine in response to rewarding stimuli, it can reinforce behaviors and create a sense of pleasure and motivation.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a key structure in the brain involved in emotional processing, particularly in the formation and regulation of fear responses. While it plays a role in processing reward-related stimuli, it is not considered the primary reward center in the brain. The amygdala is interconnected with the reward system and can influence emotional responses to rewarding stimuli, but it does not serve as the central hub for reward processing.

Option B. Thalamus: The thalamus is a critical relay station in the brain that processes and relays sensory information to different areas of the cerebral cortex. It serves as a gateway for sensory inputs but is not specifically associated with the reward system or the primary reward center in the brain.

Option C. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is primarily involved in memory formation, spatial navigation, and learning. While it is interconnected with other brain regions involved in reward processing, such as the VTA and nucleus accumbens, it is not considered the primary reward center itself. The hippocampus is crucial for memory and contextual associations but is not primarily responsible for the experience of pleasure or motivation related to rewards.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the Modified Duke Criteria in diagnosing?
questions.solution:
Correct option D

  • The Modified Duke criteria are widely used criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, which is an infection of the endocardium (inner lining) of the heart, including heart valves. The criteria help in establishing a diagnosis based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings. They take into account major and minor criteria, as well as the presence of predisposing factors, to classify the likelihood of infective endocarditis.
  • Major Criteria Description
    Positive Blood Culture - Typical organisms isolated from 2 separate blood cultures.  - Persistently positive blood cultures, with typical organisms isolated from cultures done > 12 hours apart.  - Coxiella infection (Q fever) demonstrated by a single positive blood culture with Phase I IgG titre > 1:800.
    Echocardiographic Evidence - Evidence of vegetation or oscillating intracardiac mass on echocardiography. - Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred over transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).  - New valvular regurgitation or partial dehiscence of prosthetic valve.
    New Onset Murmur in Patient with Pre-existing Heart Lesion - Development of a new heart murmur in a patient with pre-existing heart disease.
    Minor Modified Criteria Description
    Predisposition - Presence of pre-existing heart disease or history of intravenous drug usage.
    Fever > 38°C - Fever with temperature exceeding 38°C.
    Vascular Phenomenon - Major embolic phenomenon.  - Septic pulmonary infarction. - Mycotic aneurysm.  - Intracranial hemorrhage.  - Janeway lesions (palm, soles).
    Immunological Phenomenon (Mnemonic – ROG) - Roth spots.  - Rheumatoid factor positivity.  - Osler nodes (tip of fingers).  - Glomerulonephritis.
    Microbiological Evidence - Positive blood culture not meeting major criteria. - Moderate-high clinical suspicion warrants transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), while low suspicion warrants transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).  - Additional diagnostic modalities include SHOT metagenomics, FDG PET-CT, and multi-slice CT angiography.

     

Incorrect options:

Option A (Infective endarteritis) is incorrect because infective endarteritis is not a recognized term or condition. It may be a confusion with infective endocarditis.

Option B (Infectious mononucleosis) is incorrect because the Modified Duke criteria are not used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.

Option C (Inflammatory myopathy) is incorrect because the Modified Duke criteria are not used for the diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy, which refers to a group of muscle disorders characterized by muscle inflammation.

questions.text: Glucose is absorbed by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Upper part of proximal tubule:

  • 100% glucose is absorbed in the proximal tubules. Proximal tubules are divided into two parts as follows.

Tubular Segment

Glucose Reabsorption (%)

Luminal Transporter(Lumen to cytoplasm)

Basolateral Transporter (Cytoplasm to blood)

Proximal Convoluted Tubules (PCT)

90%

SGLT type II (Secondary active Transporter)

  • 1 molecule of sodium and 1 molecule of glucose from the lumen to the cell.

GLUT-2 (Facilitated diffusion transporter)

Proximal Straight Tubules (PST)

10%

SGLT type I (Secondary active Transporter)

  • 2 molecules of sodium and 1 molecule of glucose from the lumen to the cell.

GLUT-1 (Facilitated diffusion transporter)

 

Incorrect options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators may be observed when using a small-sized blood pressure cuff?

choices.text: Cancels the effects of calcified arteries

questions.solution:
Correct option A: False elevation of BP

  • Using a small-size blood pressure (BP) cuff can lead to inaccurate measurements and false elevation of blood pressure. When the cuff size is too small for the patient's arm, it can result in increased resistance and inadequate compression of the underlying artery, leading to an overestimation of the blood pressure reading.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Falsely low value of BP: It is incorrect because using a small-size BP cuff would typically result in a false elevation of blood pressure, not a falsely low value.

Option C: Cancels the effects of calcified arteries: It is incorrect because using a small-size BP cuff does not cancel the effects of calcified arteries. Calcified arteries may affect the accuracy of the blood pressure measurement, but using an appropriate cuff size is important for accurate readings.

Option D: Increases trans arm impedance: It is incorrect because using a small-size BP cuff does not specifically increase trans arm impedance. Trans arm impedance refers to the resistance encountered when measuring blood pressure across the arm.

questions.text: Which medication could be the cause of recurrent falls in an elderly male patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker medication used primarily for the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, one of the common side effects of prazosin is orthostatic hypotension, which can increase the risk of falls, especially in the elderly. Orthostatic hypotension refers to a sudden drop in blood pressure upon standing, leading to dizziness or lightheadedness, and can result in falls.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Metformin is a medication used for the management of diabetes mellitus, and it is not typically associated with an increased risk of falls.

Option C: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus. It does not commonly cause orthostatic hypotension or an increased risk of falls.

Option D: Thiazide refers to a class of diuretic medications commonly used for blood pressure control. While they can sometimes cause orthostatic hypotension, it is not a common side effect compared to prazosin.

questions.text: What is the duration for which sperm stays in the epididymis?
questions.solution:
Correct option. c

  • During puberty, cells are transformed into sperms with a head, midsection, and tail. The sperms use their long tails to push themselves out of the tubes into the epididymis. For the next 2 to 4 weeks the sperm swims through the epididymis as it develops further.

Other options are incorrect.

questions.text: What mediates Inverse stretch reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • The inverse stretch reflex, also known as the inverse myotatic reflex, is mediated by the Golgi tendon organs (GTOs). Golgi tendon organs are specialized sensory receptors located in the tendons near the junction of muscles and tendons.
  • When the muscle contracts and applies tension to the tendon, the GTOs are activated. They sense changes in tension and send inhibitory signals to the spinal cord, which in turn inhibits the motor neurons innervating the muscle. This reflex helps prevent excessive tension and potential damage to the muscle and tendon by inhibiting further contraction.

Incorrect option: 

Option B Muscle spindle is incorrect in this context. The muscle spindle is responsible for the stretch reflex, also known as the myotatic reflex, which detects changes in muscle length and initiates a reflex contraction of the muscle.

Option C Unmyelinated C fibers are associated with pain perception and are not specifically involved in the inverse stretch reflex.

Option D Dorsal Column refers to a pathway in the spinal cord involved in transmitting sensory information related to touch, proprioception, and vibration. It is not directly involved in mediating the inverse stretch reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following organelle has DNA?
questions.solution:
Correct option A-Mitochondria :

  • Mitochondria are organelles found in eukaryotic cells that have their own DNA. They are often referred to as the "powerhouses" of the cell because they are responsible for generating most of the cell's energy through a process called cellular respiration. Mitochondria have a double membrane structure, and within their inner membrane, they house their own DNA, known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).
  • Mitochondrial DNA is separate from the nuclear DNA found in the cell's nucleus. It contains genes that encode for some of the proteins, RNA molecules, and other components needed for mitochondrial function and energy production.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. The Golgi complex, or Golgi apparatus, is involved in processing, modifying, and packaging proteins and lipids for transport to their specific destinations within the cell or for secretion. It does not have its own DNA.

Option C. The SER is involved in various functions, including lipid metabolism, detoxification of drugs and toxins, and calcium storage. It does not contain DNA.

Option D. The RER is responsible for the synthesis and processing of proteins. It is called "rough" because it is studded with ribosomes involved in protein synthesis. However, it does not contain its own DNA.

questions.text: All are Glucogenic hormones except?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Glucogenic hormones are hormones that promote the production or release of glucose in the body. They stimulate processes such as glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen), gluconeogenesis (synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), and the release of glucose into the bloodstream.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon is a hormone produced by the alpha cells of the pancreas. It acts in opposition to insulin and promotes the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, increases gluconeogenesis, and enhances the release of glucose into the bloodstream.

Option C. Thyroxine (thyroid hormone): Thyroxine is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland. While it primarily affects metabolism and energy utilization, it can indirectly influence gluconeogenesis and the production of glucose.

Option D. Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are a class of hormones, including cortisol, produced by the adrenal glands. They are involved in various metabolic processes, including the regulation of glucose metabolism. Glucocorticoids can stimulate gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, leading to an increase in blood glucose levels.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the consistent amplitude of action potential when the stimulus is delivered at an intensity above the threshold?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - All or none law:

  • The all-or-none law states that once a nerve or muscle cell is stimulated beyond a certain threshold, it will generate an action potential of consistent magnitude.
  • If the stimulus is strong enough, the resulting action potential will have a fixed amplitude and will propagate without loss of intensity. Below the threshold, no action potential occurs; above it, the response is maximal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Local potential: Local potential refers to the passive changes in membrane potential that occur during the propagation of electrical signals along a neuron.

Option C - Absolute refractory period: Absolute refractory period refers to a brief period after an action potential when the neuron is unresponsive to further stimulation. During this period, another action potential cannot be generated, regardless of the strength of the stimulus.

Option D - Relative refractory period: Relative refractory period refers to a period following the absolute refractory period during which a neuron can be stimulated to generate another action potential, but only with a stronger stimulus than the previous stimulus.

questions.text: What specific region of the thalamus is associated with the regulation of motor control?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • The ventrolateral thalamus (VL) is a region of the thalamus that is closely associated with motor control. It is involved in the transmission of motor signals from the basal ganglia and cerebellum to the motor cortex.
  • The ventrolateral thalamus receives input from the basal ganglia, which is responsible for motor planning and coordination, as well as the cerebellum, which plays a crucial role in motor learning and fine-tuning of movements. The information processed in the VL thalamus is then relayed to the motor cortex, where it contributes to the execution of voluntary movements.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Ventral posteromedial (VPM) and option (c) Ventral posterolateral (VPL) are regions of the thalamus that are primarily involved in somatosensory processing. They receive sensory information from the body, including touch, temperature, and pain, and relay it to the somatosensory cortex for further processing.

Option D. Superior and inferior colliculi are structures located in the midbrain and are involved in visual and auditory processing, respectively. They play important roles in orienting responses to visual and auditory stimuli but are not directly related to motor control.

questions.text: Which test is utilized for the diagnosis of DIC among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dimer assay:

  • D-dimer assay is a blood test used to detect the presence of D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product that is elevated in conditions associated with fibrin formation and breakdown, such as DIC.
  • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate the activation of the clotting system and can support the diagnosis of DIC.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Fibrin degradation products is incorrect because while the presence of fibrin degradation products is a characteristic feature of DIC, the specific test used for their detection is the D-dimer assay.

Option B - Activated partial thromboplastin time is incorrect because activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a coagulation test that measures the intrinsic pathway of coagulation and is not specific to the diagnosis of DIC.

Option C - Prothrombin time is incorrect because prothrombin time (PT) is a coagulation test that measures the extrinsic pathway of coagulation and is not specific to the diagnosis of DIC.

questions.text: Active form of Vitamin D3 is?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Calcitriol, also known as 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, is the active form of Vitamin D3. It is formed in the kidneys from Calcidiol (the intermediate form) through hydroxylation reactions. Calcitriol plays a crucial role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels in the body, promoting their absorption from the intestine and reabsorption from the kidneys.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Calciferol: Calciferol is a term that can refer to various forms of Vitamin D, including both Vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol) and Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol). However, specifically referring to Calciferol as the active form of Vitamin D3 is not accurate.

Option C. Calcidiol: Calcidiol, also known as 25-hydroxyvitamin D, is an intermediate form of Vitamin D that is produced in the liver from Vitamin D2 or Vitamin D3. It is not the active form of Vitamin D3 itself.

Option D. Ergocalciferol: Ergocalciferol is a form of Vitamin D2 that is derived from plant sources. It undergoes conversion in the body to form the active form of Vitamin D, but specifically referring to Ergocalciferol as the active form of Vitamin D3 is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the clinical diagnosis for a patient who experiences sudden and severe respiratory distress after undergoing internal jugular vein catheterization?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumothorax:

  • The sudden-onset severe respiratory distress following the placement of an internal jugular vein catheter is highly suggestive of pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. When air accumulates in the pleural space, it can cause the lung to collapse partially or completely, leading to respiratory distress, chest pain, and other symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which hormone binds to tyrosine kinase receptors and has 4 subunits and 2 units for receptor binding?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • The hormone that has 4 subunits and 2 units for tyrosine kinase receptor binding is Insulin.
  • Insulin is a peptide hormone that regulates glucose metabolism in the body. It is composed of two peptide chains, namely the A chain and B chain, which are held together by disulfide bonds. Insulin receptors are tyrosine kinase receptors located on the surface of target cells.
  • The insulin receptor is a tetramer, consisting of two α-subunits and two β-subunits. The α-subunits are located extracellularly and contain the insulin-binding sites, while the β-subunits span the cell membrane and possess the tyrosine kinase catalytic activity. When insulin binds to the α-subunits of the receptor, it triggers a series of signaling events leading to the activation of the tyrosine kinase domain in the β-subunits. This activation initiates downstream signaling pathways involved in glucose uptake, glycogen synthesis, and other cellular responses to insulin.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon is a peptide hormone that has its own receptor, but it does not bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. Glucagon receptors belong to the G protein-coupled receptor family and activate different signaling pathways compared to tyrosine kinase receptors.

Option C. T3: T3 (triiodothyronine) is a thyroid hormone that acts primarily through nuclear receptors rather than tyrosine kinase receptors. The binding of T3 to its receptors in the nucleus regulates gene expression and metabolic processes.

Option D. ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone, also known as vasopressin): ADH acts through G protein-coupled receptors, specifically V1 and V2 receptors, and does not involve tyrosine kinase receptor signaling.

questions.text: As an intern in the neurology ward of the Department of Internal Medicine, you encounter a 48-year-old female patient who has been admitted due to muscle weakness. After conducting investigations and examinations, it is found that her nerve conduction shows a decremental response , but she displays signs of flaccidity. Based on these findings, what possible diagnosis would you consider?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Myasthenia gravis:

  • Myasthenia gravis can present with normal nerve conduction studies and a flaccid weakness pattern. In myasthenia gravis, weakness often worsens with exertion and improves with rest.
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test may show decremental response if the muscle is affected (>10% decrease at the frequency of 3 Hz stimulation)

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - (GBS - Guillain-Barré syndrome) is incorrect because GBS is characterized by reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and can show abnormalities in nerve conduction studies.

Option C - (Transverse myelitis) is incorrect because transverse myelitis is typically associated with abnormalities in nerve conduction studies and may present with spastic weakness rather than flaccid weakness.

Option D - (Traumatic neuritis) is incorrect because traumatic neuritis would not typically present with flaccid weakness and normal nerve conduction studies.

questions.text: What happens to urine after passing the thin descending loop of Henle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hypertonic:

  • The descending thin segment of the loop of henle is permeable to water and impermeable to the solutes.
  • The tubular fluid will be hypertonic after passing through the descending thin segment of the Loop of Henle.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: What conditions are associated with Type 2 hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Type 2 hypersensitivity reactions involve the destruction of target cells or tissues by antibodies.Blood transfusion reaction is an example of a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

Incorrect options:

Option A (Hyperacute kidney rejection) is incorrect because hyperacute kidney rejection is a type of organ transplant rejection mediated by preformed antibodies. It is not a classic example of a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.

Option C (Arthus reaction) is incorrect because Arthus reaction is a localized immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction that typically occurs at the site of antigen exposure, resulting in tissue damage and inflammation.

Option D (Pathergy phenomenon) is incorrect because pathergy phenomenon refers to a hyperreactivity of the skin to minor trauma, commonly seen in conditions like Behcet's disease. It is not specific to type 2 hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe increased pain in response to a minor stimulus?
questions.solution:
Correct option. C

  • In case a small stimulus causes more pain, it is called "Hyperalgesia."
  • Hyperalgesia is a condition where there is an increased sensitivity to painful stimuli, resulting in an exaggerated pain response. It can occur in response to various factors, including tissue injury, inflammation, nerve damage, or certain medical conditions.
  • Hyperalgesia can be categorized into two types:
    • Primary Hyperalgesia: This occurs in the area surrounding the site of tissue injury or inflammation. The affected area becomes more sensitive to painful stimuli, even in response to mild or non-painful stimuli.
    • Secondary Hyperalgesia: This occurs in areas surrounding the primary hyperalgesic zone. It is characterized by an expanded area of increased pain sensitivity beyond the immediate injury site.
  • Hyperalgesia can manifest as an increased intensity or prolonged duration of pain in response to stimuli that would normally be perceived as mildly painful or non-painful. It is believed to involve changes in the peripheral and central nervous systems, including altered neuronal excitability and enhanced pain transmission.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Hypersensitivity refers to an exaggerated or abnormal response of the immune system to a normally harmless substance, resulting in an allergic or autoimmune reaction.

Option C: Causalgia is a type of chronic pain syndrome characterized by severe burning pain, typically following a peripheral nerve injury.

Option D: Allodynia refers to the perception of pain in response to a stimulus that is not normally painful, such as light touch or a gentle stroke.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a management approach used for a violent patient in psychiatry?
questions.solution:
Correct option. B

  • CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a psychotherapeutic approach that focuses on identifying and modifying negative thoughts, beliefs, and behaviors. While CBT is effective in treating a wide range of psychiatric conditions, it is not typically the primary intervention for managing an acutely violent patient. In the immediate management of violent behavior, other interventions such as medications and ensuring the safety of the patient and others are usually prioritized.

Incorrect Option: 

Option A. BZD (Benzodiazepines): Benzodiazepines are a class of medications that have sedative properties and are commonly used to treat anxiety, agitation, and acute aggression. While they are not typically the first-line choice for managing violent behavior in psychiatric patients due to their potential to cause sedation and impair judgment, they can still be used in specific situations. Benzodiazepines can help calm agitated patients, reducing their aggressive tendencies and facilitating a safer environment

Option C. ECT (Electroconvulsive Therapy): ECT is a medical procedure that involves the induction of controlled seizures through the administration of electric currents to the brain. It is primarily used in the treatment of severe psychiatric conditions such as severe depression, catatonia, or some forms of psychosis. While ECT is not a first-line intervention for immediate management of violent behavior, it can be considered in certain cases. For example, if a patient presents with severe agitation, aggression, or a risk of harm to themselves or others, and their symptoms are not responding to other treatments, including medication.

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication commonly used in psychiatry. It belongs to the class of typical antipsychotics and is known for its sedative and antipsychotic properties. Haloperidol can be used to manage acute agitation and aggression in psychiatric patients. It is often administered in emergency settings to rapidly control violent behavior.

questions.text: Which test is the most sensitive for diagnosing Organophosphate poisoning among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Plasma acetylcholinesterase: 

  • Organophosphate poisoning occurs inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine and excessive cholinergic activity.
  • The most sensitive test for the diagnosis of organophosphate poisoning is the measurement of plasma acetylcholinesterase levels. Reduced levels of plasma acetylcholinesterase activity indicate organophosphate poisoning.

Incorrect options:

Option B - (Organophosphate level in blood) is incorrect because the measurement of organophosphate levels in the blood is not the primary diagnostic test for organophosphate poisoning. The clinical effects and acetylcholinesterase activity are more indicative of the poisoning.

Option C - (Organophosphate level in plasma) is incorrect because the measurement of organophosphate levels in the plasma is not the primary diagnostic test for organophosphate poisoning. The clinical effects and acetylcholinesterase activity are more indicative of the poisoning.

Option D - (RBC transaminase levels) is incorrect because RBC transaminase levels are not relevant to the diagnosis of organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least chance of developing malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oral lichen planus:

  • Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the mucous membranes in the mouth.
  • Conditions associated with low risk malignant transformation
    • Oral lichen planus
    • Discoid lupus erythematosus
    • Discoid kerratosis congenita

Incorrect Options:

Option A - (Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis) is incorrect because chronic hyperplastic candidiasis, caused by the fungus Candida, is considered a premalignant condition due to its association with an increased risk of oral cancer.

Option B - (Oral submucosal fibrosis) is incorrect because oral submucosal fibrosis, typically caused by the chewing of betel nuts or other irritants, is considered a premalignant condition associated with an increased risk of oral cancer.

Option D - (Leukoplakia) is incorrect because leukoplakia, characterized by white patches in the oral mucosa, is considered a premalignant condition as it has a higher risk of progressing to oral cancer.

questions.text: Double depression is:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Depression with dysthymia:

  • Double depression refers to the coexistence of major depressive disorder and dysthymia

  • Dysthymia is a chronic depressive disorder, and when an individual with dysthymia experiences a major depressive episode, it is considered double depression. In this case, the individual would have ongoing depressive symptoms for at least two years (dysthymia) and then experience a distinct period of more severe depressive symptoms meeting the criteria for major depressive disorder.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Major depressive disorder from 2 years: While it is possible to have a chronic course of major depressive disorder, the specific term "double depression" is not used to describe this condition. Major depressive disorder itself can be a recurrent and chronic condition, but double depression specifically refers to the co-occurrence of MDD and dysthymia.

Option B - Major depression with OCD: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a separate psychiatric disorder characterized by intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors or mental acts (compulsions). While individuals with OCD may also experience depressive symptoms, the term "double depression" is not used to describe this combination. Double depression specifically involves the coexistence of major depressive disorder and dysthymia.

Option D - Depression with anxiety attack: While anxiety symptoms can often co-occur with depressive symptoms, the term "double depression" is not used to describe this combination. Double depression specifically refers to the combination of major depressive disorder and dysthymia.

questions.text: Extensor Reflex on pinching gastrocnemius muscle is called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Gordon Sign:

  • The extensor reflex on pinching the gastrocnemius muscle is known as the Gordon sign.
  • It is an abnormal reflex response where pinching the gastrocnemius muscle leads to extension of the big toe instead of the normal flexion response. The Gordon sign can be seen in upper motor neuron lesions, such as in pyramidal tract dysfunction.

Incorrect options:

Option A - (Gower Sign) is incorrect because the Gower sign is associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy and refers to the characteristic way that individuals with muscle weakness in the lower extremities rise from a squatting or sitting position. They use their hands to "walk" up their legs and push themselves into a standing position.

Option B - (Homan Sign) is incorrect because the Homan sign is a clinical finding associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the lower extremities. It is characterized by pain in the calf upon passive dorsiflexion of the foot.

Option C - (Oppenheim Sign) is incorrect because the Oppenheim sign is a test used to assess upper motor neuron dysfunction. It involves applying firm pressure along the anterior tibial surface from the knee to the ankle, and a positive sign is indicated by a downward movement of the big toe.

questions.text: What is the psychiatric disorder most frequently observed in patients with medical or surgical conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Delirium:

  • Delirium is a common psychiatric condition seen in medico-surgical patients. It is an acute and fluctuating disturbance of consciousness and cognitive function that often occurs in the context of a medical illness, surgery, or medication use. Delirium is characterized by a rapid onset and can cause impairments in attention, memory, perception, and other cognitive domains. It is commonly associated with underlying medical conditions, such as infections, metabolic imbalances, drug intoxication, or withdrawal. Delirium is considered a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation and treatment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Depression: While depression can occur in medico-surgical patients, it is not the most commonly seen psychiatric illness in this population. Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest or pleasure, changes in appetite or sleep patterns, and other symptoms. While depression can be prevalent in various clinical settings, including medical and surgical patients, delirium is more frequently observed in this context.

Option B - Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by disturbances in perception, thinking, emotions, and behavior. It is typically diagnosed during early adulthood and often requires ongoing treatment and support. While schizophrenia can coexist with medical or surgical conditions, it is not the most commonly observed psychiatric illness in medico-surgical patients.

Option D - Dementia: Dementia is a chronic and progressive neurocognitive disorder characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, behavior, and the ability to perform daily activities. While dementia can be seen in medico-surgical patients, it is not the most commonly encountered psychiatric illness in this population. Delirium, with its acute onset and fluctuating course, is more frequently observed in the hospital setting compared to chronic conditions like dementia.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the shown CT:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Massive epidural hemorrhage, also known as epidural hematoma, is a serious medical condition characterized by bleeding between the outer lining of the brain (dura mater) and the skull. It is typically caused by a traumatic injury to the head, such as a skull fracture or severe impact
  • On a CT scan, a massive epidural hemorrhage appears as a convex, lens-shaped collection of blood that is located between the skull and the dura mater. The blood appears hyperdense (bright) compared to the surrounding brain tissue. The hemorrhage can exert pressure on the brain, leading to potentially life-threatening complications if not promptly addressed.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Intraventricular bleed: Intraventricular bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs within the brain's ventricles. It is characterized by blood accumulation within the ventricular system. On a CT scan, intraventricular bleeding appears as hyperdense areas within the ventricles. It is often associated with other types of bleeding, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage or intracerebral hemorrhage. However, in the given scenario, the CT scan does not show blood accumulation within the ventricles, making intraventricular bleed an incorrect choice.

Option C: Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage refers to bleeding that occurs between the dura mater (outermost layer of the brain) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer). It is typically caused by trauma and can lead to the collection of blood in the subdural space. On a CT scan, subdural hemorrhage appears as a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the brain and the dura mater. In the given scenario, there is no evidence of blood accumulation in the subdural space, making subdural hemorrhage an incorrect choice.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage refers to bleeding that occurs in the subarachnoid space, which is the space between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater (innermost layer of the brain). It is commonly caused by the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm or head trauma. On a CT scan, subarachnoid hemorrhage appears as diffuse or localized areas of high-density blood within the subarachnoid space. In the given scenario, there is no evidence of blood within the subarachnoid space, making subarachnoid hemorrhage an incorrect choice

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a negative symptom of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Negative symptoms of schizophrenia are characterized by deficits or reductions in normal emotional, cognitive, or behavioral functioning. They reflect a loss or diminishment of typical functioning rather than an excess or overactivity. Therefore, "Over activity" is the correct answer as it is not considered a negative symptom of schizophrenia.

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Anhedonia: Anhedonia is a negative symptom of schizophrenia. It refers to the loss of interest or pleasure in previously enjoyable activities. Individuals with schizophrenia may have difficulty experiencing joy or finding satisfaction in things they used to find pleasurable.

Option C. Alogia: Alogia is a negative symptom of schizophrenia. It is characterized by reduced speech output or impoverished speech content. Individuals with alogia may have difficulty expressing themselves or providing detailed responses in conversations.

Option D. Apathy: Apathy is a negative symptom of schizophrenia. It refers to a lack of interest, motivation, or enthusiasm in activities or goals. Individuals with apathy may have reduced drive or find it difficult to initiate and sustain activities.

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered acute organic mental disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Delirium is the most common acute organic mental disorder. It is an acute confusional state characterized by a disturbance in attention and awareness. Delirium often has a rapid onset and fluctuating course, and it is commonly caused by underlying medical conditions, such as infections, metabolic imbalances, drug intoxication, or withdrawal. Delirium is a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation and treatment to address the underlying cause and manage the symptoms.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Dementia: Dementia is a chronic and progressive neurocognitive disorder characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, behavior, and the ability to perform daily activities. Unlike delirium, dementia develops slowly and gradually over time, and it is not considered an acute disorder. While dementia can cause cognitive impairment, it is not the most common acute organic mental disorder.

Option C. Amnesia: Amnesia refers to the loss of memory, either partial or complete, due to various causes such as brain injury, trauma, or psychological factors. While amnesia can occur acutely, it is not as common as delirium as an acute organic mental disorder. Delirium involves not only memory impairment but also disturbances in attention, awareness, and other cognitive functions.

Option D. Anxiety disorder: Anxiety disorder is a broad term that encompasses various mental health conditions characterized by excessive worry, fear, and anxiety. While anxiety disorders can occur acutely, they are not classified as acute organic mental disorders. Acute organic mental disorders typically refer to conditions with an acute onset and organic (physiological) etiology, such as delirium caused by medical factors.

questions.text: Identify the sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Target sign

  • Abdominal ultrasound. Target sign of an ileocecal intussusception in the right lower quadrant (arrows). The classic ultrasound image of intussusception is a ‘bull's eye', ‘coiled spring' or ‘target sign' lesion (intraluminal mass or intussusceptum) representing layers of the intestine within the intestine.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Claw sign : Also seen in intussusception

Option C: Coffee bean sign : The presence of the coffee bean sign is pathognomonic of sigmoid volvulus. 

Option D: Lead pipe sign : Seen in ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Which of the subsequent investigations operate based on the same principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • CT and X-ray both work on the principle of ionizing radiation. X-ray imaging involves the use of a focused beam of X-rays that pass through the body, creating an image on a detector. The resulting image provides information about the internal structures and can help diagnose various conditions.
  • CT, on the other hand, also utilizes X-rays but in a more advanced manner. It employs a rotating X-ray tube and detectors to capture multiple images from different angles. These images are then processed by a computer to create cross-sectional images of the body. CT scans provide more detailed and three-dimensional information compared to conventional X-rays.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: CT and MRI: CT and MRI work on different principles. CT uses X-rays, while MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to generate detailed images of the body's structures. MRI does not involve ionizing radiation.

Option C: USG and HIDA Scan: USG (Ultrasound) and HIDA (Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid) scan do not work on the same principle. USG uses high-frequency sound waves to produce images of internal organs, while HIDA scan is a nuclear medicine scan that involves the injection of a radioactive tracer to evaluate the hepatobiliary system.

Option D: MRI and PET Scan: MRI and PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scan also work on different principles. MRI uses magnetic fields and radio waves, while PET scan involves the injection of a radioactive tracer to detect the metabolic activity of cells in the body.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for GERD:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • GERD is a chronic condition characterized by the reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and chest discomfort. The goal of investigations for GERD is to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of acid reflux.
  • 24-hour pH monitoring is considered the gold standard investigation for GERD. It involves placing a pH probe into the esophagus to measure and record the pH levels for a 24-hour period. This allows for the detection of abnormal acid exposure in the esophagus, helping to establish the diagnosis of GERD and assess its severity.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: USG (Ultrasound): USG is not typically used as an investigation for GERD. It is more commonly employed for evaluating abdominal organs, such as the liver, gallbladder, or kidneys, and may be useful in assessing other conditions that can mimic GERD, such as gallbladder disease or pancreatitis.

Option B : HIDA (Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid) scan: HIDA scan is not indicated as an investigation for GERD. It is primarily used for evaluating the biliary system, such as in cases of suspected gallbladder dysfunction or biliary obstruction.

Option C: Manometry: Esophageal manometry measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus and is used to assess esophageal function. While manometry may be helpful in evaluating other esophageal conditions, such as achalasia or esophageal motility disorders, it is not the investigation of choice for GERD.

questions.text: Adhesion of platelets is the main function of von-willebrand factor. Which of the following is true for von-willebrand disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Normal prothrombin time:

  • Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a protein involved in platelet adhesion and the stabilization of factor VIII in the blood clotting cascade.
  • Prothrombin time is not affected in von-willebrand disease as von-willebrand factor affects only the intrinsic factor.

Incorrect options:

Option A - "Normal partial thromboplastin time (PTT)": PTT is prolonged in von-willebrand disease as it does not bind to factor 8.

Option B - "Decreased platelets": Von Willebrand disease does not directly affect platelet production or cause a decrease in platelet count. Platelet count is generally normal in VWD. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option D - "Normal bleeding time": Since von Willebrand factor plays a crucial role in platelet adhesion, patients with VWD may have an increased bleeding time due to impaired platelet function. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Please identify the pathology present in the provided X-ray image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

Pneumoperitoneum on a chest X-ray:

  • Presence of Free Air Under the Diaphragm: Air rises in the abdomen, and when it accumulates within the peritoneal cavity, it appears as a radiolucent area below the diaphragm. This creates a clear demarcation between the air-filled abdomen and the denser structures of the thoracic cavity.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air in the pleural space, which is the space between the lungs and the chest wall. On a chest X-ray, pneumothorax typically appears as a dark area with absent lung markings at the lung periphery, indicating lung collapse. This is different from pneumoperitoneum, which involves the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity.

Option C: Hydrothorax: Hydrothorax refers to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. On a chest X-ray, hydrothorax appears as an opacity with blunted or obscured costophrenic angles, indicating fluid-filled lung spaces. It does not involve the presence of air as seen in pneumoperitoneum.

Option D: Normal X-ray: A normal chest X-ray would not show any significant abnormalities. It would exhibit clear lung fields with normal heart size and mediastinal structures. In the case of pneumoperitoneum, the presence of free air under the diaphragm would be absent in a normal X-ray.

questions.text: Mosquito having spotted wings is?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Anopheles mosquitoes are known to have spotted wings. They are the primary vectors for transmitting malaria.

 

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Culex: Culex mosquitoes have uniformly colored wings.

Option C. Aedes: Aedes mosquitoes have dark-colored wings with prominent markings but not necessarily spots.

Option D. Mansonia: Mansonia mosquitoes have unspotted wings.

questions.text: Yaws is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - T. Pertunae:

  • Yaws is a tropical disease caused by the bacterium Treponema pertenue. It is a subspecies of Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis. Yaws primarily affects the skin, bones, and joints.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - T. endemicum: Treponema endemicum causes endemic syphilis, not yaws.

Option C - T. Carateum: Treponema carateum causes pinta.

Option D - Hemophilus: Hemophilus is associated with pneumonia, meningitis, croup, and suppurative lesions.

questions.text: A 40 yr old man comes with a history of retrosternal chest pain and dysphagia, Barium meal was done given below. What is the classical pattern of dysphagia found in this condition?

choices.text: Progressive dysphagia more for solids >> liquids

questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

Option A: More for liquids >> solids: This pattern is consistent with achalasia. In achalasia, dysphagia is more associated with liquids.

Incorrect Option:

Option B: Progressive Dysphagia for liquids = solids : This is incorrect

Option C: Progressive dysphagia more for solids >> liquids: This pattern does not align with the classical presentation of achalasia.

Option D: Intermittent dysphagia for solids = liquids: This pattern is not characteristic of achalasia.

questions.text: Which subtype of human papilloma virus has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HPV 16 & 18:

  • High-risk subtypes of human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV 16 and HPV 18, are known to have the highest association with the development of cervical carcinoma.
  • Other high-risk human papillomaviruses associated with cervical carcinoma are HPV 31, 33, and 35.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HPV 6 & 11: HPV 6 and HPV 11 are classified as low-risk subtypes and are commonly associated with condyloma acuminatum and laryngeal papillomatosis.

Option C - HPV 31 & 32: HPV 31 is a high-risk subtype associated with cervical cancer, but HPV 32 is not associated with cervical carcinoma.

Option D - HPV 1 & 2: HPV 1 and HPV 2 are low-risk subtypes associated with plantar warts/verruca and filiform warts.

questions.text: Size of uterus (in inch):
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The correct option represents the size of the uterus as 3x2x1 inches. The other options provide different measurements that do not match the given size.

Incorrect options:

Option A: This option provides a different measurement than the given size of the uterus.

Option C: This option provides a different measurement than the given size of the uterus.

Option D: This option provides a different measurement than the given size of the uterus.

questions.text: Most common immediate complication of splenectomy:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemorrhage:

  • The most common immediate complication of splenectomy is hemorrhage, which refers to excessive bleeding. The spleen is a highly vascular organ, and its removal can lead to significant bleeding. Surgeons take precautions to control bleeding during the procedure, but it remains a potential complication.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fistula: While a fistula can occur after splenectomy, it is not the most common immediate complication.

Option C - Bleeding from gastric mucosa: Bleeding from the gastric mucosa can occur in some cases, but it is not the most common immediate complication after splenectomy.

Option D - Pancreatitis: Pancreatitis, inflammation of the pancreas, is not a common immediate complication of splenectomy.

questions.text: Pearl index is used to calculate which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • The Pearl index is a measure used to calculate the number of accidental pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure to a contraceptive method. It helps assess the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods in preventing unintended pregnancies. The other options are unrelated to the Pearl index.

Incorrect options:

Option B: The Pearl index is not used to calculate population statistics.

Option C: The Pearl index is not used to calculate the overall fertility rate.

Option D: The Pearl index is not used to calculate the number of abortions.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought with a high fever with rigors for 5 days with pain in the right hypochondrium. On examination, the patient is anicteric, and tenderness is noted in the right upper quadrant. What is the best investigation for this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Serology:

  • Serological tests can be used to detect specific pathogens, such as viral or bacterial infections, that may be causing the symptoms. These tests can include antibody tests, antigen tests, or tests for specific biomarkers associated with certain infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - USG: Ultrasonography, may be helpful in evaluating the abdominal organs and detecting any abnormalities, but it may not provide specific information about the underlying cause of the symptoms.

Option C - SGOT/LFT: Serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase/liver function tests may be part of a comprehensive evaluation, but they do not specifically target the cause of the symptoms described.

Option D - CECT: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography is a useful imaging modality for assessing abdominal structures in detail, but it may not be the initial investigation of choice in this case.

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis of this 60 years of man:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - SCC of lip:

  • The diagnosis for this 60-year-old man is SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) of the lip, as shown in the image.

  • Based on the image showing SCC of the lip, it is evident that the patient has a malignant tumor involving the lip. Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly occurs in sun-exposed areas, including the lips. It typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, crusted lesion with irregular borders.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Basal cell carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma is another common type of skin cancer, but it typically presents with different clinical features and is less likely to be associated with lip involvement.

Option B - Plunging Ranula: Plunging ranula refers to a cystic lesion that occurs in the floor of the mouth and is not related to lip carcinoma.

Option C - Epulis: Epulis refers to a benign tumor or overgrowth of tissue, which is different from the malignant nature of the lesion seen in the image.

questions.text: What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

choices.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Options C -Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa:

  • Greenish discoloration of the right iliac fossa, known as the Greenish Line of Hochenegg, is one of the early signs of decomposition and is observed before  any other changes such as maggot formation, putrefaction, or mummification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maggot formation: Maggot formation occurs during the later stages of decomposition, after the initial discoloration of the right iliac fossa.

Option B - Putrefaction: Putrefaction, the breakdown of body tissues, occurs after the initial discoloration.

Option D - Mummification: Mummification is a specific form of postmortem preservation and does not occur as the first change in a dead body.

questions.text: ​​​​​​​What is the most effective treatment approach for anal canal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chemoradiation:

  • Carcinoma of the anal canal is typically treated with a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy, known as chemoradiation. The chemotherapy drugs commonly used in this regimen include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and mitomycin C.
  • The rationale behind using chemoradiation is that the anal canal is a highly radiosensitive area, and the addition of chemotherapy enhances the radio sensitivity of the tumor cells, leading to improved treatment outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Surgery: Depending on the extent and location of the tumor, surgical options may include local excision, wide local excision, or abdominoperineal resection (APR).

Option C - Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy alone may be considered in select cases, such as in patients who are not candidates for chemotherapy or in cases of localized tumors in patients with significant comorbidities.

Option D - Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the preferred treatment modality for this type of cancer.

questions.text: What is the population served by a single Primary Health Center (PHC) in the plains?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 30000: 

  • In the plains, the population covered by one Primary Health Center (PHC) is generally around 30,000. PHCs are the basic units of healthcare delivery in rural areas.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have multiple strictures of small bowel with interspersed areas of normal mucosa in between. Which of the following is false regarding the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - No recurrence after surgery:

  • Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, but it most commonly involves the terminal ileum and colon.
  • Crohn's disease is characterized by the presence of multiple strictures of the affected bowel segments. These strictures can lead to symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. The strictures are often interspersed with areas of normal mucosa, which is a characteristic feature of the disease and can reoccur after surgery.

Incorrect Options:

 Option B - Aphthous ulcers: Crohn's disease can cause aphthous ulcers, which are small, shallow, painful sores that can develop in the mouth, esophagus, or gastrointestinal tract.

Option C - Skip lesions: Crohn's disease is known for its patchy distribution, with areas of inflammation (affected by the disease) and areas of normal tissue (unaffected by the disease) interspersed. This pattern of skip lesions is a distinguishing feature of Crohn's disease.

Option D - Fistula formation: Crohn's disease can lead to the formation of abnormal connections (fistulas) between different parts of the gastrointestinal tract or between the gastrointestinal tract and other organs. Fistulas can cause additional complications and symptoms.

questions.text: What is the CD4 cut off for initiating Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) in the treatment of AIDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - No cut-off:

  • The treatment of AIDS, or HIV infection, with Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) is not solely based on a specific CD4 cell count cut-off. The decision to start ART depends on various factors, including clinical symptoms, CD4 count, viral load, and the individual's overall health.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 200: This CD4 cut-off was previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count.

Option B - 350: This CD4 cut-off was also previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count.

Option C - 500: This CD4 cut-off was previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count.

questions.text: Normal Waist to hip-ratio in male is:
questions.solution:
Correct option D: <0.90 males

  • The normal waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) in males is typically less than 0.90. It is a measure of central obesity and is used as an indicator of increased health risks associated with excess abdominal fat.
  • This ratio is calculated by dividing the circumference of the waist by the circumference of the hips.

Incorrect options

Option A: >0.8 in males

  • This value is not within the normal range for waist-to-hip ratio.

Option B: >0.85 in females

  • This value refers to the normal waist-to-hip ratio in females, not males.

Option C: >0.90 males

  • This value is outside the normal range and indicates an increased risk of health problems.

questions.text: Most common subtype of Rodent ulcer is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nodular:

  • The most common subtype of Rodent ulcer is Nodular.

  • Rodent ulcer, also known as basal cell carcinoma (BCC), is a common type of skin cancer that typically occurs on areas of the skin exposed to the sun, such as the face, neck, and hands. BCC is the most common form of skin cancer and is characterized by slow-growing, locally invasive tumors.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Superficial BCC: This subtype is characterized by a red, scaly patch or plaque on the skin. It tends to grow slowly and can be mistaken for eczema or a patch of psoriasis.

Option B - Cystic BCC: This subtype appears as a translucent or pearly nodule with central cystic areas. It may have a smooth, shiny surface and can resemble a benign cyst.

Option D - Pigmented BCC: Is rare variant

questions.text: Which of these is the best for management of a 3 cm stone in renal pelvis without evidence of hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PCNL:

  • The best management option for a 3 cm stone in the renal pelvis without evidence of hydronephrosis is PCNL

  • Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. It involves making a small incision in the back and creating a tract into the kidney to access and remove the stone. PCNL is particularly effective for larger stones, typically those larger than 2 cm.

  • In the case of a 3 cm stone in the renal pelvis, PCNL is the preferred treatment option because it allows for direct access to the stone and provides effective clearance. The procedure involves using specialized instruments, such as a nephroscope and laser or ultrasound energy, to break up the stone into smaller fragments and remove them. The surgeon can visualize the stone and surrounding structures to ensure complete stone clearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ESWL: ESWL Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy uses shock waves to break up kidney stones from outside the body. However, it is generally more suitable for smaller stones (less than 2 cm) and may be less effective for larger stones like the 3 cm stone in the renal pelvis mentioned.

Option C - Antegrade Pyeloplasty: Antegrade pyeloplasty is a surgical procedure used to treat ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, which is a blockage at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter. It is not the primary treatment for kidney stones and is not specifically indicated for stone removal.

Option D - Retrograde Pyeloplasty: Retrograde pyeloplasty is another surgical procedure used to treat UPJ obstruction. Similar to antegrade pyeloplasty, it is not the primary treatment for kidney stones and is not specifically indicated for stone removal.

questions.text: How can the diagnosis of Rabies be quickly made in a living dog that is displaying symptoms of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fluorescent antibody test:

  • The rapid diagnosis of Rabies in a living dog can be done using the Fluorescent Antibody Test (FAT). This test helps identify the presence of the Rabies virus in the dog's tissues.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Corneal impression: Corneal impressions are not used for the rapid diagnosis of Rabies.

Option C - Inoculation in mouse: Inoculation in mice is used for laboratory confirmation of Rabies but not for rapid diagnosis in living dogs.

Option D - None of the above: The correct answer is the Fluorescent Antibody Test.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is AFP a tumor marker?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HCC:

  • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) is a Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) tumor marker.
  • Hepatocellular Carcinoma is the most common type of primary liver cancer, and AFP is one of the key tumor markers associated with this disease. AFP is a protein the liver produces during fetal development, and its levels decrease after birth. However, in certain conditions, such as HCC, the production of AFP can be reactivated, leading to elevated levels in the blood.
  • Measuring AFP levels in the blood can be helpful in screening, diagnosing, and monitoring the progression of HCC. High levels of AFP are often seen in patients with HCC, although it is important to note that not all individuals with HCC will have elevated AFP levels. Elevated AFP levels can also be seen in other conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and certain germ cell tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - RCC: ESR, CEA, haptoglobin, fibrinogen, and C3 to estimate the staging of RCC and ESR, CEA, haptoglobin, and C3 to estimate the prognosis.

Option C - Oncocytoma: Oncocytomas are benign tumors commonly found in the kidneys but can also occur in other organs, such as the salivary glands, thyroid, and parathyroid glands. Unlike malignant tumors, oncocytomas do not typically produce specific tumor markers commonly associated with cancer.

Option D - Chordoma: Chordomas are rare, slow-growing malignant tumors that arise from remnants of the notochord, a structure present during early embryonic development. They usually occur in the skull base, spine, or sacrum bones. Unlike many other cancers, chordomas do not typically produce specific tumor markers widely used for diagnostic or monitoring purposes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a germ cell tumor not typically observed in males?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sertoli cell tumor:

  • Sertoli cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors that arise from the Sertoli cells of the testes.

  • They are not classified as germ cell tumors but rather as interstitial tumors.

  • Sertoli cell tumors are extremely rare and are typically benign.

  • They are not typically observed in males as part of the germ cell tumor spectrum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Choriocarcinoma:

  • Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant tumor that arises from trophoblastic cells.

  • It is a type of germ cell tumor and is observed in males, although it is more commonly associated with testicular cancer in females.

  • Choriocarcinoma is one of the subtypes of germ cell tumors.

Option B - Seminoma:

  • Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor in males, accounting for approximately 40-50% of cases.

  • It arises from the germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules.

  • Seminomas are typically observed in males and are a classic example of a germ cell tumor.

Option D - Teratoma:

  • Teratoma is another type of germ cell tumor that can occur in the testes.

  • It is characterized by the presence of tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm.

  • Teratomas can occur in both males and females and are commonly found in the testes as well as other locations such as the ovaries and sacrococcygeal region.

  • They are part of the spectrum of germ cell tumors typically observed in males.

questions.text: In which of the following locations is the dye injected for Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Areola:

  • In sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB), a dye is injected near the site of the primary tumor to identify the sentinel lymph node(s) draining that area. The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node in the lymphatic system that receives drainage from the tumor site, and it is the most likely node to contain metastatic cancer cells if they have spread.
  • In breast cancer, the dye for SLNB is commonly injected in or around the areola. The areola is the pigmented area surrounding the nipple. By injecting the dye in this location, it can flow through the lymphatic channels and reach the sentinel lymph node(s) in the axilla (armpit).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Axilla: Injecting the dye directly into the axilla is not the common practice for sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast cancer. While the axillary lymph nodes are the primary drainage site for the breast, the dye is typically injected near the areola to allow it to flow through the lymphatic channels and reach the sentinel lymph node(s) in the axilla.

Option B - Tail of Spence: The tail of Spence is an extension of breast tissue into the axilla. However, the dye is not typically injected specifically into the tail of Spence. It is more common to inject the dye near the areola to ensure proper drainage to the sentinel lymph node(s).

Option C - Nipple: Injecting the dye directly into the nipple is not the standard practice for sentinel lymph node biopsy. While the nipple is part of the breast tissue, it is not the typical injection site for the dye. The areola, which surrounds the nipple, is a more common site for the injection.

questions.text: What is the accurate portrayal of Paget's disease of the breast?

choices.text: The most common presentation is bilateral..

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Eczema of skin of nipple: 

  • Paget's disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer that primarily affects the skin of the nipple and areola. It is characterized by eczema-like changes in the appearance and texture of the skin, such as redness, itching, flaking, and crusting. The affected skin may also become thickened, scaly, or ulcerated.
  • The disease usually starts in the nipple and then spreads to the areola. It is often associated with an underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), which is a non-invasive form of breast cancer. In some cases, invasive breast cancer may also be present.
  • Paget's disease of the breast is typically diagnosed through a combination of clinical examination, imaging studies, such as mammography or breast ultrasound, and biopsy of the affected skin and underlying breast tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - The most common presentation is bilateral: The most common presentation of Paget's disease of the breast is unilateral, but bilateral cases have been reported and are rare.

Options C - Mastitis carcinomatosis: Mastitis carcinomatosis refers to a condition where breast cancer cells invade the breast tissue, causing inflammation and infection-like symptoms. Paget's disease of the breast is a distinct entity and is not synonymous with mastitis carcinomatosis. While Paget's disease can be associated with underlying breast cancer, it does not represent a direct inflammation of the breast tissue.

Options D - Atrophic scirrhous carcinoma: Atrophic scirrhous carcinoma is a subtype of invasive breast carcinoma characterized by dense fibrous tissue and marked stromal reaction. It is not specific to Paget's disease of the breast, which primarily involves the skin of the nipple. Atrophic scirrhous carcinoma does not manifest as eczema-like changes on the nipple.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of a painful erection without sexual drive. The patient also gives a history of taking antipsychotic medication. The cut-off duration for diagnosis of Priapism is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 4 hours:

  • Priapism is defined as a persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours. It's considered a surgical emergency.

  • Ischaemic priapism, the more common type, involves venous congestion leading to thrombosis and ischemia. It's often associated with medications like antipsychotics or conditions like sickle cell disease.

  • Delay in treatment beyond 6 hours can cause irreversible damage to the penile tissue, leading to fibrosis and erectile dysfunction.

  • Treatment includes aspiration of blood from the corpora cavernosa, intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine, or creation of a shunt if conservative measures fail.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C - 1 hour, 2 hour & 3 hour:

  • Priapism is not diagnosed until an erection persists for longer than 4 hours.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of recurrent right upper quadrant pain complaint. They exacerbate, especially after eating. An ultrasound of the abdomen is performed, which comes out to be non-conclusive. Which of the following procedures is indicated in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):

  • The image provided suggests the procedure of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  • ERCP is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to evaluate and treat disorders of the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts. It involves the use of an endoscope, a flexible tube with a light and camera, which is inserted through the mouth and guided down to the duodenum. Contrast dye is then injected into the bile ducts or pancreatic ducts, and X-ray images are taken to visualize the anatomy and detect any abnormalities.
  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing recurrent right upper quadrant pain, which can be indicative of biliary system pathology. The non-conclusive ultrasound abdomen suggests the need for further evaluation of the bile ducts. ERCP allows direct visualization of the bile ducts and can help identify any obstructions, strictures, or other abnormalities that may be causing the patient's symptoms. It can also be used for therapeutic interventions, such as removing gallstones or placing stents to relieve obstructions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram: This involves the injection of contrast dye directly into the bile ducts through a needle inserted into the liver. It is typically used when ERCP is not possible or unsuccessful.

Option B - T-tube cholangiogram: This is a radiographic study performed after the placement of a T-tube in the common bile duct following surgery. It allows visualization of the bile ducts and assessment of bile flow.
