Option D - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan: This nuclear medicine scan is used to evaluate the function of the gallbladder and bile ducts. It involves the injection of a radioactive tracer that is taken up by the liver and excreted into the bile ducts.

questions.text: What is the urgent indication for performing laparotomy in a 30-year-old man who presents with right iliac fossa pain lasting for four days, as depicted in the provided USG image?

choices.text: Increase in the size of mass

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All of the above:

  • In a patient with a four-day history of right iliac fossa pain, the presence of the following signs and symptoms would warrant urgent surgical intervention.

 

Option A - Rising pulse rate: An increasing or persistently elevated pulse rate can be indicative of ongoing inflammation, infection, or compromised blood flow to the affected area. It may suggest a worsening condition that requires immediate surgical evaluation and intervention.

Option B - Increasing abdominal pain: If the abdominal pain is progressively worsening, it may indicate a worsening or evolving pathology, such as an inflamed appendix or an abscess. Increasing pain can be a sign of a worsening condition that may require surgical exploration.

Option C - Increase in the size of the mass: If a palpable mass in the right iliac fossa is increasing in size, it could suggest an enlarging abscess or a rapidly progressing inflammatory process. This may necessitate urgent surgical drainage or intervention.

questions.text: Bell clapper testis predisposes to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Torsion testis:

  • The Bell clapper deformity refers to a condition in which the testis lacks proper fixation within the scrotum, allowing it to rotate freely on the spermatic cord. This anatomical abnormality predisposes the individual to testicular torsion, which is the twisting of the testicle and its associated structures. Testicular torsion can lead to ischemia (lack of blood flow) and if not promptly treated, it can result in testicular damage or loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Varicocele: Varicocele is a condition characterized by the enlargement of veins within the scrotum. It is not directly related to the Bell clapper deformity. Varicocele is more commonly associated with the impairment of venous drainage in the testicles.

Option C - Cancer of testis: The Bell clapper deformity itself does not predispose to testicular cancer. Testicular cancer typically arises from abnormal growth of cells within the testicles and is influenced by various factors such as genetic predisposition, previous testicular abnormalities, and environmental factors.

Option D - Hydrocele: Hydrocele is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid around the testicle, leading to scrotal swelling. It is not directly related to the Bell clapper deformity. Hydrocele can occur due to various reasons, including trauma, infection, or underlying testicular abnormalities.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed complication in a 29-year-old man who visits the outpatient department due to pain, heaviness, and swelling in his right leg? The patient has been dealing with varicose veins since he was 12 years old. After undergoing below-knee stripping of the long saphenous vein, both the symptoms and visible varicose veins disappeared.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neuralgia:

  • Neuralgia refers to the condition characterized by sharp, shooting, or burning pain along the course of a nerve. In the context of the patient's history of varicose veins and subsequent surgical intervention (below-knee stripping of the long saphenous vein), neuralgia can occur as a common complication. This can happen due to nerve damage during the surgical procedure or as a result of ongoing irritation or inflammation of the nerves in the affected area.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Hemorrhage: Hemorrhage, or excessive bleeding, is a potential complication of any surgical procedure. However, in the given scenario, where the patient's symptoms resolved completely after the surgery, hemorrhage is less likely to be the most common complication.

Options B - Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism refers to the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) that travels through the bloodstream and blocks a blood vessel. While varicose veins can increase the risk of blood clots, the patient's symptoms improved after the surgery, suggesting that thromboembolism is not the most common complication in this case.

Options D - Infection: Infection is a possible complication of any surgical procedure. However, the patient's symptoms resolved after the surgery, making infection less likely to be the most common complication.

questions.text: Most common benign breast tumour:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fibroadenoma:

  • Fibroadenoma is the most common benign breast tumor.
  • It is a non-cancerous growth that typically occurs in young women.
  • Fibroadenomas are composed of glandular and fibrous tissue and usually feel like a firm, rubbery mass that is smooth and movable.
  • They are usually painless and do not increase the risk of developing breast cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Fibroadenosis: Fibroadenosis, also known as fibrocystic changes or benign breast changes, refers to the presence of lumps, pain, and breast swelling. It is not a tumor.

Options C - DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ):  DCIS is not a benign tumor but rather a non-invasive form of breast cancer. It is characterized by abnormal cells confined to the milk ducts of the breast.

Options D - Phyllodes tumor:  Phyllodes tumors are rare fibroepithelial tumors of the breast. While they are benign in most cases, they have the potential to be malignant. However, fibroadenomas are more commonly encountered in clinical practice compared to phyllodes tumors.

questions.text: Sebaceous cyst is not seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Soles:

  • Sebaceous cysts can occur in various parts of the body, including the back, scalp, and scrotum. However, they are not commonly seen on the soles of the feet.
  • Sebaceous cysts are typically found in areas where there are hair follicles and sebaceous (oil) glands.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Back: Sebaceous cysts can occur on the back. The back is a common location for these cysts, along with other areas such as the face, neck, and trunk.

Options C - Scalp: Sebaceous cysts are frequently seen on the scalp. They can develop when the hair follicles or oil glands on the scalp become blocked or damaged.

Options D - Scrotum: Sebaceous cysts can also occur on the scrotum. The scrotum has hair follicles and sebaceous glands, making it a potential site for the development of these cysts.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options does not constitute a Hospital-Acquired infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - STD:

  • Hospital-Acquired Infections (HAIs) are infections that are acquired during a hospital stay or healthcare facility visit. They are also known as nosocomial infections. These infections are typically associated with medical procedures, invasive devices, or exposure to healthcare personnel.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases are not included in HAIs.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Surgical site infection: Surgical site infections are a common type of Hospital-Acquired Infection. They occur after surgery and can affect the incision site or deeper tissues.

Options C - UTI (Urinary Tract Infection): UTIs can be both community-acquired and hospital-acquired.

Options D - Pneumonia: Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP) is a type of pneumonia that develops during a hospital stay. It is typically associated with mechanical ventilation, aspiration, or exposure to multidrug-resistant organisms in the hospital environment.

questions.text: Amount of blood loss in class III circulatory failure/Haemorrhagic shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 30-40%: 

  • In the classification of hemorrhagic shock, class III refers to moderate hypovolemia or circulatory failure. It is characterized by a blood loss of approximately 30-40% of the total blood volume. This level of blood loss can lead to significant cardiovascular compromise and compromised tissue perfusion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - < 15%: This level of blood loss would typically correspond to class I or mild hypovolemia.

Option B - 15-30%: This range of blood loss would correspond to class II or moderate hypovolemia.

Option D - > 40%: Blood loss exceeding 40% of the total blood volume would be classified as class IV or severe hypovolemia

questions.text: Provide your opinion on the diagnosis based on a radiographic image displayed of a 65-year-old male experiencing acute abdominal pain.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colocolic intussusception:

  • The X-ray image shows colocolonic intussusception, it means that a part of the colon has telescoped into an adjacent part of the colon. Colocolonic intussusception is a relatively rare condition and can occur in any age group.
  • The diagnosis of colocolonic intussusception on an X-ray image would typically show signs of bowel obstruction, such as a dilated loop of the colon or evidence of air-fluid levels. The telescoping of the colon may appear as a target or "bull's eye" appearance on the X-ray.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ileocolic intussusception: Ileocolic intussusception refers to the telescoping of the small intestine (ileum) into the large intestine (colon). It is a distinct condition from colocolonic intussusception.

Option B - Sigmoid volvulus: Sigmoid volvulus is a condition where the sigmoid colon twists upon itself, leading to bowel obstruction. It is characterized by a "coffee bean" or "omega" sign on imaging.

Option C - Toxic megacolon: Toxic megacolon refers to a severe complication of inflammatory bowel disease, usually ulcerative colitis, where the colon becomes dilated and at risk of perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the breast triple assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Axillary sampling:

  • Axillary sampling, is not part of the breast triple assessment. Axillary sampling refers to the removal of lymph nodes from the armpit (axilla) for evaluation, particularly in cases of known or suspected breast cancer to determine if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes. While axillary sampling is an important procedure in breast cancer staging, it is not considered part of the initial diagnostic assessment known as the breast triple assessment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clinical examination: This involves a thorough examination of the breasts and surrounding areas by a healthcare professional to assess any palpable masses, changes in breast shape or texture, or other clinical findings.

Option C - USG: This may include a mammogram and/or ultrasound (USG) of the breasts. These imaging tests help visualize the internal structures of the breast and can detect abnormalities such as masses or calcifications.

Option D - FNAC and biopsy: Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or biopsy involves obtaining a tissue sample from a breast abnormality for pathological examination. FNAC uses a fine needle to extract cells for analysis, while biopsy involves the removal of a small piece of tissue. These samples are then examined under a microscope to determine if they are benign or malignant

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Wet gangrene: 

  • Wet gangrene is a type of gangrene characterized by tissue necrosis (death) that occurs in a moist or wet environment. It is usually caused by a severe bacterial infection and impaired blood supply to the affected area. The affected tissue appears swollen, discolored (often dark or black), and may have a foul odor. It is commonly seen in the extremities, such as the feet.

  • In the given image, the appearance of the foot with discoloration, swelling, and signs of tissue decay suggests the presence of wet gangrene. The presence of a severe infection and impaired blood supply are consistent with this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dry gangrene: Dry gangrene is characterized by tissue death in a dry environment without the presence of infection. It usually occurs due to reduced blood supply to the affected area, leading to tissue necrosis. Dry gangrene often appears black, dry, and shriveled.

Option C - Frostbite: Frostbite refers to tissue injury caused by extreme cold exposure. It occurs when prolonged exposure to freezing temperatures leads to damage to the skin and underlying tissues. Frostbite can cause discoloration, numbness, and blistering of the affected area.

Option D - Ainhum: Ainhum is a rare condition characterized by the progressive constriction and autoamputation of the digits, usually the fifth toe. It typically affects individuals in certain geographical regions and is associated with the formation of a fibrous band around the affected digit.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man visits the outpatient department with concerns of pain in the lower abdomen and rectal bleeding. After conducting additional tests, it is found that the patient has several shallow ulcers in the rectum that extend upwards to involve the entire colon. Upon examination of the tissue samples, it is discovered that only the mucosa and submucosa are affected. Which of the following complications associated with the aforementioned conditions is not harmful?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Colonic polyp: 

  • Colonic polyps are abnormal growths that develop on the inner lining of the colon or rectum. They can vary in size and shape and may be noncancerous (benign) or have the potential to develop into colon cancer (premalignant). In the given scenario, the presence of multiple superficial ulcers in the rectum and colon suggests an inflammatory bowel disease (such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease) as the underlying condition.
  • However, it is important to monitor and manage colonic polyps appropriately due to their potential to progress to colon cancer over time.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Toxic megacolon: Toxic megacolon is a severe complication of inflammatory bowel disease characterized by massive inflammation and dilation of the colon.

Options C - Colonic obstruction: Colonic obstruction refers to a blockage in the colon that prevents the normal passage of stool. It can occur due to various causes, such as tumors, strictures, or adhesions.

Options D - Massive colonic bleeding: Massive colonic bleeding refers to significant and potentially life-threatening bleeding from the colon. It can occur due to various causes, including ulcers, tumors, diverticulosis, or vascular abnormalities.

questions.text: Patient complains of painless swelling over the face with difficulty in swallowing. The appearance of face is shown. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cancer of parotid gland:

  • Cancer of the parotid gland refers to the development of malignant tumors in the parotid gland, the largest salivary gland in the face. The symptoms described by the patient, including painless swelling over the face and difficulty swallowing, are characteristic features of parotid gland tumors. The image shown indicates an enlarged parotid gland.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute parotitis: Acute parotitis refers to inflammation of the parotid gland, usually caused by a bacterial infection. It typically presents with symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness over the affected gland.

Option C - Angioedema of face: Angioedema involves sudden swelling of deeper skin layers, commonly triggered by allergies, typically accompanied by itching, hives, and a history of allergic reactions, whereas painless swelling and swallowing difficulty are atypical.

Option D - Acute sialadenitis: Acute sialadenitis refers to inflammation of the salivary glands. It can result in pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presented with a 6-month painless fluctuant, non-transilluminant swelling with a thin watery discharge. Clinical diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - TB:

  • Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It can affect various organs, including the lymph nodes. Tuberculous lymphadenitis is characterized by painless, fluctuant swelling with a thin watery discharge.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Brachial cyst: A branchial cyst is a congenital abnormality that arises from remnants of the branchial arches. It typically presents as a painless, cystic swelling in the neck, usually in the lateral aspect. It is not associated with watery discharge.

Option B - Secondaries: The term "secondaries" refers to metastatic cancer, which occurs when cancer cells from the primary tumor spread to other parts of the body. The given clinical presentation with a painless fluctuant swelling and watery discharge is not indicative of metastatic cancer.

Option D - Lymphoma: Lymphoma can affect lymph nodes and other lymphoid tissues. However, lymphoma typically presents with painless, firm lymph node enlargement, and watery discharge is not a characteristic feature.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 1-year-old patient diagnosed with Keratomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct option. B

  • Keratomalacia is a condition characterized by vitamin A deficiency leading to corneal damage. The standard treatment for Keratomalacia is vitamin A supplementation. In this case, the correct treatment option is administering 1 Lac IU (International Units) of vitamin A three times.

Incorrect option:

Option A. 1 Lac IU once: Vitamin A supplementation in Keratomalacia requires multiple doses to replenish the deficient levels adequately.

Option C. 2 Lac IU once: A single high dose is not the recommended treatment approach for Keratomalacia.

Option D. 2 Lac IU three times: This dosage is higher than the recommended treatment regimen for Keratomalacia.

questions.text: Beri-Beri seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct option. C

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional disease caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is commonly associated with diets predominantly consisting of polished rice. Polished rice lacks the outer bran layer, which is rich in thiamine.

Incorrect options

Option A. Sorghum eaters: Sorghum is not typically associated with causing Beri-Beri.

Option B. Wheat eaters: Wheat is not a common cause of Beri-Beri.

Option D. Maize eaters: Maize (corn) is not a common cause of Beri-Beri.

questions.text: Most common cause of LBW in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Premature birth:

  • In India, the most common cause of Low Birth Weight (LBW) is premature birth. LBW is defined as a birth weight less than 2,500 grams. Premature infants are born before completing the full term of pregnancy and often have lower birth weights.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Smoking during pregnancy: While smoking during pregnancy can contribute to LBW, it is not the most common cause in India.

Option B - Maternal tetanus: Maternal tetanus is not a common cause of LBW.

Option C - Intra-uterine growth retardation: Intra-uterine growth retardation (IUGR) can lead to LBW, but it is not the most common cause in India.

questions.text: The proposal to control malaria in towns named as Urban Malaria Scheme. According to Urban Malaria Scheme, Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: Scheme is not based on blood examination
Towns having a population more than 10,000

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Slide positivity rate more than 10%:

  • The Urban Malaria Scheme aims to control malaria in towns and cities. One of the criteria for implementing the scheme is a slide positivity rate (SPR) of more than 5% but less than or equal to 10%. Therefore, the statement "Slide positivity rate more than 10%" is not true.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - SPR between 5% and 10%: This range is a valid criterion for implementing the Urban Malaria Scheme.

Option C - Scheme is not based on blood examination : The scheme is not based on the blood examination slide rate but on the slide positivity rate.

Option D - Towns having a population more than 10,000: The scheme can be implemented in towns with a population more than 10,000.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male truck driver visited to the clinic with fever, skin rash, swollen glands and fatigue. The physician referred him to suraksha clinic. Which among the following is included in provision of services at Suraksha Clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - RTI/ STI services:

  • The Suraksha Clinic is a healthcare facility that provides services related to reproductive and sexual health. RTI (Reproductive Tract Infection) and STI (Sexually Transmitted Infection) services are included in the range of services offered at the Suraksha Clinic.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Immunization services: Suraksha Clinic primarily focuses on reproductive and sexual health services, and immunization services are not typically provided in this context.

Option B - Blood transfusion safety services: Suraksha Clinic does not specifically provide blood transfusion safety services.

Option D - Diarrhea control services: Diarrhea control services are not typically part of the services offered at the Suraksha Clinic.

questions.text: Ujjawala scheme is for prevention of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Child trafficking:

  • The Ujjawala scheme is a government initiative aimed at preventing and combating human trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. It focuses on rescuing and rehabilitating victims of trafficking, providing them with support services, and raising awareness about the issue.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Child abuse: While the Ujjawala scheme indirectly addresses the prevention of child abuse through its efforts to combat child trafficking, it specifically focuses on trafficking-related issues.

Option C - Child labour: The Ujjawala scheme primarily targets child trafficking rather than child labor.

Option D - Child marriage: Child marriage is not the main focus of the Ujjawala scheme; it primarily addresses human trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

questions.text: Peripheral blood smear sample for malaria is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Laboratory technician:

  • A peripheral blood smear sample for malaria is typically obtained by a laboratory technician. These technicians are trained and skilled in collecting blood samples and preparing blood smears for microscopic examination to detect the presence of malaria parasites.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & C  are not typically responsible for obtaining peripheral blood smear samples for malaria.

questions.text:
In a rural village, a government school conducted a comprehensive health check-up for all its students.

According to Vision 2020, which of the following centre will the teacher refer school children to in order to check their visual acuity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -Vision centre:

  • Under the Vision 2020 initiative, which aims to eliminate avoidable blindness, one of the strategies is to provide accessible eye care services. Vision centers are established to provide primary eye care, including vision testing and provision of eyeglasses, in areas where access to eye care is limited. Therefore, the teacher would refer school children to a vision center to check their visual acuity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Service center: The term "service center" is general and does not specifically relate to eye care or vision testing.

Option B - Training center: Training centers are focused on providing education and training rather than direct provision of eye care services.

Option C - Center for excellence: Centers of excellence generally refer to specialized institutions that excel in a specific field. While they may provide advanced eye care services, they are not typically involved in routine vision testing in schools.

questions.text: A school has a small outbreak were children are showing symptoms like runny nose, cough, fever and skin rash. The doctors identified it as measles outbreak. Which of the following is the correct time to give post exposure measles vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 3-4 days:

  • In the case of a measles outbreak, post-exposure vaccination is recommended within 72 hours (3 days) of exposure to the virus. Administering the measles vaccine within this timeframe can help prevent or reduce the severity of the disease in susceptible individuals.

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - 7-10 days: Waiting 7-10 days to administer the measles vaccine may delay the effectiveness of the vaccine and increase the risk of the disease spreading further.

Option C - 10-14 days: Similarly, waiting 10-14 days may not provide optimal protection against measles and could lead to further transmission of the virus.

Option D - 1-6 months: The correct timeframe for post-exposure measles vaccination is within 3-4 days, not 1-6 months.

questions.text: Cholera period of Isolation:

choices.text: 3 days after starting Tetracycline till 48 hours of antibiotics
Until 3 weeks of effective antibiotic therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option. A - 3 days after starting Tetracycline till 48 hours of antibiotics: 

  • During a cholera outbreak, infected individuals should be isolated to prevent the spread of the disease. The period of isolation for cholera patients typically begins 3 days after starting tetracycline treatment and continues until 48 hours after the initiation of antibiotics. This duration allows for effective treatment and reduces the risk of transmission.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - 7 days after starting Tetracycline: Waiting for 7 days before isolating cholera patients may result in a prolonged period of potential transmission.

Option C - 7-14 days: Isolating cholera patients for 7-14 days may not align with the recommended treatment timeline and could lead to further spread of the disease.

Option D - Until 3 weeks of effective antibiotic therapy: While treatment with antibiotics is crucial in managing cholera, isolating patients for the entire duration of effective antibiotic therapy is not necessary. Isolation can be discontinued after 48 hours of antibiotic initiation.

questions.text: What is the additional amount of energy needed on a daily basis during pregnancy? (in Kcalories)
questions.solution:
Correct option. C

  • During pregnancy, there is an increased energy requirement to support the growth and development of the fetus. The additional energy requirement is generally estimated to be around 350 kcal per day. This extra energy intake helps meet the nutritional needs of the mother and supports the healthy development of the baby.

Incorrect options 

Option A. +300 kcal: While a slight increase in energy intake may be beneficial during pregnancy, the recommended additional energy requirement is typically higher, around 350 kcal per day.

Option B. +600 kcal: A 600 kcal increase in energy intake would be excessive and could contribute to excessive weight gain during pregnancy, which is not recommended.

Option D. +520 kcal: The recommended additional energy requirement during pregnancy is around 350 kcal per day, not 520 kcal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the hospital with fever, dry cough, sore throat, and muscle pain. RT-PCR confirmed the patient to be positive for COVID 19. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the epidemiology of Covid-19?

choices.text: 1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 50 years
> 5% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 80 years
Mode of transmission is droplets, contacts
Remdesivir is an emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for COVID-19

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 50 years:

  • The incorrect statement is "1% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 50 years." In reality, the case fatality rate for COVID-19 is generally higher in older age groups, especially in individuals aged 50 years and above. Older age is considered a significant risk factor for severe illness and mortality from COVID-19.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - 5% Case Fatality rate in age ≥ 80 years: This statement is generally true. The case fatality rate tends to increase with age, and individuals aged 80 years and above are at higher risk of severe illness and mortality.

Option C - Mode of transmission is droplets, contacts: This statement is generally true. COVID-19 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks, or breathes. It can also spread by close contact with an infected person or through contact with contaminated surfaces or objects.

Option D - Remdesivir is an emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for COVID-19: This statement is correct. Remdesivir initially received emergency use authorization (EUA) from the FDA for the treatment of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, However is no longer considered the recommended or first-line treatment for COVID-19 in many countries.

questions.text: Which contraceptive method has the highest reported failure rate?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • The correct answer is "Spermicidal methods." Spermicidal methods, such as spermicide creams, gels, foams, or suppositories, have higher failure rates compared to other contraceptive methods. They are generally used in combination with barrier methods, such as condoms, to enhance effectiveness.

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Implant: Implants are highly effective long-acting reversible contraceptive methods and have a very low failure rate.

Option C. Oral contraceptive pills: Oral contraceptive pills, when used correctly, are highly effective in preventing pregnancy and have low failure rates.

Option D. IUD: Intrauterine devices (IUDs), both hormonal and non-hormonal, are highly effective contraceptive methods with very low failure rates.

questions.text: During the introduction of a novel national health program and policy, the concept of population attributable risk is evaluated. Which of the subsequent statements provides the most accurate explanation of population attributable risk?

choices.text: Incidence of disease among exposed is so many times higher as compared to that among non-exposed
So much disease can be attributed to exposure
If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population:

  • Population attributable risk (PAR) quantifies the proportion of disease incidence in a population due to a specific risk factor. It indicates the potential reduction in disease if the risk factor were modified or eliminated.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Incidence of disease among exposed is so many times higher as compared to that among non-exposed: Describes relative risk, comparing disease risk between exposed and non-exposed groups.

Option B - So much disease can be attributed to exposure: Too vague, lacking specificity about PAR's quantification of disease incidence.

Option D - None of the above: Incorrect, as Option C accurately defines PAR.

questions.text: Human anatomical wastes are disposed of in the ____ BMW category?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Yellow :

  • Human anatomical wastes, also known as biomedical waste or BMW, are disposed of in the yellow BMW category.
  • The yellow bag is used to dispose of infectious or pathological waste, such as anatomical waste that includes human tissues, organs, body fluids, and body parts.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Red: The red bag is used to dispose of contaminated waste that is recyclable.

Option C - White: The white bag is used to dispose of waste sharps.

Option D - Blue: The blue bag is used to dispose of glassware or metallic body implants.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below pertains to the field of Disaster management, which deals with the mitigation and response to abrupt, devastating incidents that significantly impede the operations of a community or society, resulting in human, material, and economic or environmental consequences?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Ministry of Home :

  • The Ministry of Home, or the Ministry of Home Affairs, is typically responsible for disaster management in many countries. This ministry oversees and coordinates various aspects of disaster management, including disaster response, relief operations, and coordination with other relevant agencies and stakeholders.

Incorrect Options :

Option A. Ministry of Health: The Ministry of Health is vital in public health emergencies, but it may not lead overall disaster management.

Option B. Ministry of HRD: The Ministry of HRD focuses on education and human resource development, not necessarily disaster management.

Option D. Ministry of Agriculture: The Ministry of Agriculture focuses on agricultural policies and food security, important during disasters, but may not lead disaster management.

questions.text: What is the phase(s) of the disaster cycle that occurs before the impact of the disaster?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Mitigation and preparedness :

The phases of the disaster cycle are a framework used in disaster management to understand and address the various stages of a disaster. "Mitigation and preparedness" phases occur before the actual impact of a disaster. Disaster mitigation aims to reduce risks and vulnerabilities through activities like risk assessment and preventive measures. Preparedness involves planning, training, and stockpiling supplies for effective disaster response.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. Disaster response: This phase occurs during and immediately after a disaster when emergency response efforts are initiated.

Option B. Medical relief and rehabilitation: This phase is part of the recovery phase and involves providing medical assistance and rehabilitation services to affected individuals.

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is a phase of the disaster cycle that occurs after the immediate response and focuses on restoring and rebuilding the affected areas.

questions.text: At a PHC, vaccine storage is done in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR):

  • ILRs are designed for storing vaccines and medications.
  • They maintain stable temperature ranges required for vaccine storage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaccine carrier: Used for transporting vaccines, not long-term storage.

Option C - Walk-in Cold rooms: Large refrigerated spaces, not typically found at PHCs.

Option D - Ice packs: Provide temporary cooling during transportation, not long-term storage.

questions.text: Which group is excluded from targeted interventions, a specific set of services and interventions provided to individuals in the population who are at high risk of or have reported high risk of HIV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Doctors and nursing professionals: 

  • Targeted intervention refers to a specific package of interventions and services designed to reach and address the needs of populations at high risk of HIV or those who have reported a high risk of HIV. Doctors and nurses are not high-risk group but suffer accidental injuries.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Migrant labourers: Migrant labourers, who often move across regions or countries for work, are considered a high-risk group due to factors such as mobility, separation from families, and engagement in risky behaviors.

Option B - Street children: Street children, who may lack stable housing and support systems, are vulnerable to various health risks, including HIV infection.

Option C - Long-distance truckers: Long-distance truckers, who frequently travel across different regions or countries as part of their occupation, are at increased risk of HIV.

questions.text: What is the purpose of administering ORS plus Zinc to a patient from a rural village?
questions.solution:
Correct option. C

  • ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution) is a solution that contains a precise balance of salts and sugars to replace fluids and electrolytes lost during diarrhea. It is a well-established treatment for diarrhea and helps prevent dehydration in affected individuals.
  • When ORS is combined with zinc supplementation, it has been found to have additional benefits in the management of diarrhea, especially in children. Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in various bodily functions, including immune function and growth. The combination of ORS and zinc has been shown to:
    • Reduce the duration and severity of diarrhea episodes: Zinc supplementation along with ORS has been found to reduce the duration of diarrhea, leading to faster recovery.
    • Improve overall treatment outcomes: The combination therapy has been associated with lower treatment failure rates and a reduced need for additional medical interventions.
    • Support overall health and nutritional status: Zinc is important for proper growth and development, and its supplementation helps replenish zinc stores that may be depleted during diarrheal episodes.
  • Therefore, ORS plus zinc is an effective approach in the management of diarrhea, particularly in children, as it not only helps rehydrate the body but also reduces the duration of the illness and improves overall treatment outcomes.

Incorrect options: 

Option A. Reduces infection: While ORS plus zinc can support the body's overall immune function, it does not directly reduce the infection itself. It primarily focuses on rehydration and reducing the duration of diarrhea.


Option B. Antispasmodic: Antispasmodic medications are used to relieve muscle spasms and cramping. ORS plus zinc does not have antispasmodic properties.


Option D. Enhances sodium absorption: ORS itself is designed to help restore the balance of electrolytes, including sodium, in the body. Zinc supplementation in combination with ORS primarily contributes to reducing the duration of diarrhea, rather than specifically enhancing sodium absorption.
